fields.headline: FA seek manager who has 'integrity'
fields.trailText: The Football Association yesterday announced such steep criteria for the appointment of a new England coach that it is hard to see anyone matching up to the requirements, least of all Terry Venables.
fields.body:
The Football Association yesterday moved a step closer to appointing the new England manager, and it looks less and less likely to be Terry Venables.

The special committee charged with the task of finding a replacement for Kevin Keegan has laid down such a tough set of criteria for the new man to meet that it is hard to see the so-called "people's favourite" - or many other managers - matching up to the requirements.

Among the list of virtues that the new coach must possess are integrity, sustained football success as a coach or manager and long-term commitment.

Although Venables supporters point out that the England job only involves coaching, the FA is clearly looking for someone with personal probity too. In 1998 Venables was so heavily criticised by a Department of Trade and Industry report, which followed a three-year investigation, that he was banned from being a company director for seven years.

The DTI report followed comments by one judge who called Venables's evidence "wanton" and said he could not accept his evidence as "entirely reliable, to put it at its most charitable". As for the FA's requirement of "sustained football success", sustained is not something that Venables can boast, even though many rate him highly as a coach.

Since winning the Spanish title with Barcelona in 1985, Venables's only other successes was in leading Spurs to an FA Cup victory in 1991 and taking England to the semi-finals of Euro 96. Since then he has been coach to Australia and Crystal Palace, both without tangible success.

The FA's special committee met for the first time as a group yesterday, taking four hours to go through the list of prospective candidates and formulate the attributes needed.

The committee comprises the FA chief executive Adam Crozier, who is chairman, the FA's technical director Howard Wilkinson, chairman of the FA international committee Noel White, the Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein, the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale, the Premier League chairman Dave Richards, and the FA's executive director David Davies.

"The FA group discussed all the potential candidates, and the criteria on which to judge them," they said in a prepared statement. "These focused on evidence of their sustained football success as a coach/manager, their international experience, their standing among players, clubs and supporters, and their tactical astuteness.

"Other criteria included integrity, handling of outside pressures, capacity to focus solely on the job, decision-making and communication skills, long-term commitment, ability to inspire a team and operate within it and their consistency of purpose."

The committee said that it would make no statement until next week. This is expected to detail how the negotiations with various candidates are proceeding, or to announce the choice of caretaker manager to take charge of the England team for the friendly with Italy on November 15.

Yesterday the former Germany coach Berti Vogts claimed that he had been approached about the England job. "There has been an inquiry from a go-between," he said. "People in England know how I work. They know about my honesty, my tactical knowledge and the fact that I keep a straight line. Those are qualities England need."

However, the FA immediately dampened any speculation. "These reports all seem very premature," said the FA spokesman Nick Barron. "Adam Crozier will be the only person approaching anyone about the job. We won't be using any intermediaries.

"People shouldn't expect any candidates to be announced. We are still looking at all the options and still speaking to people."

fields.headline: Decline of the Leeds piano competition
fields.standfirst:
Alessio Bax
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
**
fields.trailText:
Alessio Bax
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
**
fields.body:
There was a time when the first London recital by a winner of the Leeds International Piano Competition would guarantee a full house at the Queen Elizabeth Hall, but not any more. For Alessio Bax's recital on Wednesday the auditorium was barely half full. That suggests the allure that used to go with winning at Leeds is not what it was. It also suggests that a competition that for so long has basked in the glory of having "discovered" a whole raft of front-rank pianists in the 1970s - Lupu, Perahia, Uchida, Schiff, Alexeev - has finally been exposed as having no better a track record than any of its rivals when it comes to sifting out the truly talented artists from the seemingly endless supply of efficient keyboard technicians.

To judge by this appearance, I fear that Bax is not going to restore the reputation of the Leeds. The 22-year-old Italian won the 2000 competition last month - a unanimous decision, apparently - playing a Brahms concerto in the final. But whatever qualities made that performance so worthy of the top award were certainly not on show here.

He has a lissom yet sturdy technique, shown off to best advantage in the piano arrangement of Ravel's La Valse, with which he ended his programme. He is also capable of dealing competently with everything that Rachmaninov can throw at him. He was well on top of the Corelli Variations and negotiated a clear path through a group of preludes from the Op 23 set.

Yet these were never characterful performances. The Ravel is dangerous music, teetering on the edge of chaos. But Bax never suggested any risk, and never got to the heart of the Corelli Variations.

Had Bax played these works before tackling a Schubert sonata (the A minor D784) then the unfocused details might have gone unnoticed. But the sonata had come first, and so much of it had been incoherent - the opening Allegro, one of Schubert's rawest tragic statements, had such an unstable pulse the whole momentum of the movement was destroyed. The Andante went for nothing and the elements of the finale lacked any kind of integration. The result of all this was that the same shortcomings seemed magnified through the rest of his programme.

The event was presented as the Yamaha Piano Centenary Concert, and the company had turned half of the QEH foyer into a showroom for the evening. One hopes that the instruments on display there were more impressive than the shallow, wiry-toned example that Bax was contending with in the hall.

fields.headline: RLPO/ Goodman
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonic Hall, Liverpool
***
fields.trailText:
Philharmonic Hall, Liverpool
***
fields.body:
The Bach year is hard to avoid. But for a normal symphony orchestra it is also hard to celebrate, because the public now prefers its orchestral Bach with the slimline forces and execution of original- instrument groups. Though they can once again accept his keyboard music played on the piano, they are less happy with a modern orchestra; the disappointing turnout for the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic's Bach family celebration is the evidence for that.

But the absentees missed some marvellous playing that bodes well for their B minor Mass performance this Saturday with the country's best vocal soloists, also to be conducted by Roy Goodman. For Wednesday's concert he used a very small ensemble, who showed an admirably light bowing style that emulates the lead of the specialist groups. Particularly the bass lines had a springy approach that propelled the Third Orchestral Suite into buoyant mood. The modern wind and trumpet players caught the spirit and were in every way splendidly stylish. And the Third Brandenburg Concerto, done entirely with solo instruments, had a degree of bite and verve that left nobody regretting the use of modern instruments.

Playing like that can easily restore Bach to the staple fare of the modern orchestra. If things went less well earlier on, that could be partly because the music was less idiomatic or less good. Goodman's own arrangement of the six-voice keyboard Ricercar from the Musical Offering cruelly exposed the string group, who may have been under-rehearsed. And two concertos by Emanuel Bach - both of them perhaps originally for different instruments - tended towards the routine.

Jonathan Small played the E flat Oboe Concerto with a controlled elegance that failed to generate much visceral excitement. For the D minor Flute Concerto we heard what was charmingly announced as a world premiere, because it included two previously unknown horn parts - parts that on this occasion sounded seriously uncomfortable and unidiomatic. (Can they really be original?) But the solo playing of Laura Jellicoe communicated vividly, and her glittering virtuosity in the last movement effortlessly overcame any doubts about the work's viability.

fields.headline: Regina Carter becomes a star
fields.standfirst:
Regina Carter
Ronnie Scott's, London
****
fields.trailText:
Regina Carter
Ronnie Scott's, London
****
fields.body:
Regina Carter, the young American jazz violinist, was not big enough to be considered a headline act at Ronnie Scott's a year ago. Now she is not only the main attraction, but she is eliciting a more vociferous response from the audience than has been heard there in a while.

Carter is a technically skilful violinist with a classical player's subtlety of nuance and dynamics. She is also a formidable improviser with an uninhibited relationship with her instrument. This leads her to swerve from fragile sounds to raucous hoe-down dissonances and back. Her current sojourn in London finds her with a group of her own making - and it's fascinating how direct and funky it is. Hard-hitting Latin fusion and African music play as big a part as the effervescent, Stephane Grappelli-like swing that is the orthodoxy for most violinists in jazz.

Compared with her wonderful duet performance with the pianist Kenny Barron in London earlier this year, this gig did not present the ideal opportunity to savour Carter's thoughtfulness and melodic imagination. But if this week's performance was more inclined towards big effects, there was still a lot of cliff-edge improvising in it, and the quartet is tight, well-matched and full of ideas. Milt Jackson's Motor City Moments (the title track of Carter's current CD) plays a prominent part, and a heated Latin-jazz feature, For Someone I Love, makes the quintet sound a lot bigger than it is - not least for Carter's singing and playing operating in engaging call-and-response mode, and Cuban percussionist Mayra Casales's furious drumming.

For Someone I Love tapped Regina Carter's openness to vocalised effects on the violin - laconic slurs, descending phrases like laughter - but Lady Be Good explored the grace of her playing, with vibrato-packed sounds turning into glittering swing. Drummer Alvester Garnett confirmed that he is a true expert in the demanding art of sounding expressive and supportive with brushes rather than sticks.

 Ends tomorrow. Box office: 020-7439 0747.

fields.headline: 23 Skidoo
fields.standfirst:
Scala, London
**
fields.trailText:
Scala, London
**
fields.body:
Against the background of Deckwrecka's lo-fi hip-hop set, 23 Skidoo sauntered on from stage left and began playing the distinctive trance-funk of The Gospel Comes to New Guinea. This unobtrusive entrance was typical of the band's performance. Unflashy and unpretentious, Alex Turnball (drums and percussion), Johnny Turnball (guitar), Fritz Catlin (drums and percussion) and Sketch Martin (bass) seemed overawed by their first gig in 16 years, and they came across as a little sedated.

Rhythm has always been central to the 23 Skidoo sound. Twenty years ago, they applied their feral swathes of noise, loops and frenzied percussion to the US funk of James Brown and the Afrofunk of Fela Kuti. It was revolutionary then, but now it is as commonplace as a loaf of white bread. As the "original punks on funks" they have seen their legacy appropriated by jungle, drum'n'bass, techno and big beat and extended their reach to UK hip-hop with the Ronin label.

Their old shows reputedly used to scare the hell out of their audience. But that has all changed. Older and wiser, 23 Skidoo have moved on, appearing laid-back, mellow elder statesmen. The show was divided on almost generational lines. On one side there was the old guard from the 1980s: Loose Ends' former singer, Carl McIntosh and the Aswad horn section. On the other, rappers Rodney P, Skitz and Roots Manuva took on the baton for the younger generation.

For a band that make such beautiful music 23 Skidoo took great pains to present it in an offhand manner. It was as if they were admitting that their work was dull and mainstream. The fire has gone from their bellies. That said, the evening would have been an entirely different experience if the sound quality had not been so awful throughout. Things improved when a brass section arrived for the neo-tropical Crossfire. Dennis Rollins on trombone, Ray Carless on saxophone and Eddie Thornton on trumpet propelled the music onwards with fast, funky playing. Their sophistication allowed them to invade the rest of the music rather than play against it.

The rappers fared worse. Skitz and Rodney P hit the stage running, but their requests for "arms in the air" went unheeded. To their credit, they did try to orchestrate their flow around the brass section and some ferocious drumming by Alex Turnball. 23 Skidoo's boisterous playing reached a manic peak on Where U At, the duet between Roots Manuva and Carl McIntosh.

With McIntosh crooning the title, the eminently likeable Manuva showed why he is one of the best MCs in the UK. His display highlighted his verbal and rhythmic dexterity to devastating effect.

The material that followed - IV, Apocalypse, Meltdown and Dusk to Dawn - operated in that grey area called "the jam". With little to differentiate these jazz-funk-lite instrumentals from each other, the band could not quite escape that fiddly non- committal rut - I mean groove - that is the undoing of so much contemporary music. However, they did treat us to a rousing rendition of a track that has caused much controversy in recent years. As the bass-line riff of the 1982 hit The Coup reverberated around the venue, you could not deny that it sounded remarkably like the Chemical Brothers's Grammy-winning hit, Block Rocking Beats.

fields.headline: The lava-lamp approach to dance
fields.standfirst:
Siobhan Davies Dance Company
Sadler's Wells, London
****
fields.trailText:
Siobhan Davies Dance Company
Sadler's Wells, London
****
fields.body:
The title of Siobhan Davies's latest work, Of Oil and Water, makes us think inevitably of things that don't mix. Or rather, as we watch its eight dancers moving within a crimson-lit space, it makes us imagine the stage as some giant lava lamp. The dancers' bodies rise and fall like bubbles, suspended in the vivid medium of the air, and their paths merge only as the currents of choreography bring them into contact.

But the music that accompanies Davies's movement gives it a much less abstract slant. Orlando Gough's layered whispers, chants, cries and song within a jazzy saxophone frame create an intensely social world of sound. So, as Davies's choreography evolves, we start to see the dancers not as separate modules, but as people in a group. They are held together by the tension of history and proximity, even though their emotions and impulses set them apart.

Two couples, for instance, start to emerge from the choreography, yet even while Davies is at her most inventive in weaving their steps together, they frequently dance with their heads turned away from each other. Phrases of movement eddy from one dancer to another, connecting them like brightly articulate ripples of conversation. Yet all the while we are aware of the performers' individual personalities standing alone. One of Davies's greatest gifts is to make her dancers look extraordinarily themselves, and in this work she surpasses herself, containing within the brilliant logic of her choreo-graphy the wheeling energy of Matthew Morris, the distracted virtuosity of Henry Montes and the almost confrontational precision of Sarah Warsop.

The work offers an unsentimental but profoundly affecting view of the ways in which we survive as social beings, and it is given a dark sense of mortality by David Buckland's staging. A tightly cropped video projection acts as a window on to a busy public world that is oblivious to our inner lives. A travolator, upon which the dancers enter and exit, suggests another kind of death. When the dancers move against its momentum they look as if they are striding purposefully into the arena of their lives - creatures of energy and power. When they are passively carried away on it, they seem to be leaving the stage against their will, borne away by forgetfulness or time.

Just as eloquent is Peter Mumford's lighting - perhaps the most beautiful I have seen - which changes the stage from sensual reds to brooding shadows to a haunting green. The fact that the work's magic falters for about five minutes close to the end is not a problem. Of Oil and Water offers an hour of pure dance, during which our hearts and our brains are intently engaged. That it doesn't quite make the stretch simply emphasises the passionate ambition of its enterprise.

 Ends tomorrow. Box office: 020-7863 8000. Then at the Lowry, Salford (0161-876 2000), on November 9 and 10.

fields.headline: The Idea of North
fields.standfirst:
City Art Gallery, Leeds
**
fields.trailText:
City Art Gallery, Leeds
**
fields.body:
What is the north, where is the north, and why doesn't this exhibition come up with anything resembling an answer? No one's mental map of the north coincides, of course, and the purpose of this show, surveying visual art at the turn of the past three centuries, is to flick back and forth between the margins of disagreement.

The outcome was always likely to be fairly random, though the contents of the main room stretches credulity somewhat. Dotted around are a few photographs of Gals- worthy ice sculptures, five Richard Long rocks in the middle of nowhere and some velvety Thomas Joshua Cooper shots of a raging torrent on the Swedish-Finnish border. All very frozen and northerly, but curious companions to a large video of tropical fish on the opposite wall.

It transpires that FedEx's contribution to the show has been to send Annelies Strba's Shades of Time to Alaska by mistake. On the wall is a hasty fax from Strba's representatives at the Frith Gallery apologising for the error, and offering the fish in compensation. One might interpret this as a piece of conceptual fun, were it not for a further note from the curators assuring us that Strba's specially commissioned piece about personal geographies will be with us as soon as it makes its way back from Anchorage.

Meanwhile, in the Projects Room, we are invited to navigate through artists' conceptions of the north, test pre- conceived notions and create our own. This is where Nina Pope and Karen Guthrie have pledged to build an island representation of a "textual landscape" devised by visitors to their website; though all that could be found on preview night were the artists presiding over a large model-railway layout and lamenting that they couldn't get the lights in all the little houses to work.

And standing glumly on the sidelines is the greatest missed opportunity of all - Antony Gormley's maquette for the 100ft Brick Man, which would have brought Leeds the greatest piece of public sculpture in the country had it not been rejected. If any one work of art has truly come to encapsulate the idea of the north in the public imagination, you won't find it here. It is standing, wings outstretched, on a hill outside Gateshead.

 Until January 7. Details: 0113-247 8248 .

fields.headline: Madame Melville
fields.standfirst:
Vaudeville Theatre, London
****
fields.trailText:
Vaudeville Theatre, London
****
fields.body:
I have grave doubts about the transformation of the West End into a playground for resting movie stars. But those doubts are swept aside by the presence of Irène Jacob and Macaulay Culkin in Richard Nelson's elegant account of a sentimental education.

Nelson, in his 100-minute play, intertwines two familiar themes: the sexual initiation of the young and the confrontation of American innocence by European experience. His hero, Carl, now married with children, reminisces about Paris in 1966. We see how, as a 15-year-old student at the American School, he falls under the spell of a literature teacher. One night, after a film excursion, he stays behind in her flat. For him this offers a magical introduction to the world of art, music, adult emotion and Kama Sutra sex. For Claudie, the teacher, the encounter is a way of overcoming her devastation at the break-up of an affair.

Admittedly there are times when the atmosphere of cultural sophistication is a little stifling. The air is thick with references to Proust, Racine, Mozart, Bonnard and Ingres. But what gives the play its peculiar charm is the tender collision between two people at different stages of their emotional cycle.

Nelson also writes with observant wit. Claudie's endless erotic manoeuvres to get Carl into bed, including the sexual deconstruction of a Bonnard painting, are extremely funny. And Nelson undercuts the contrast between American rawness and European knowingness. Carl is clearly no hick and shows surprising tenacity as a lover. Claudie, for all her worldliness, has an orphaned quality. In the end, you're not altogether sure which is the pupil and which is the teacher.

But much of the pleasure, under Nelson's direction, lies in the playing. Culkin is adept at suggesting that his gaucherie conceals a hard-nosed sexual determination. Jacob is even more remarkable as Claudie. She combines tactile flirtiness with a sense of quiet desperation. Above all, you come out feeling that the visiting stars have more than earned their keep and that Nelson has pinned down with exact compassion what happens when two worlds collide.

 Booking until March. Box office: 020-7836 9987.

fields.headline: Show Off
fields.body:
Three years ago in Edinburgh, Ursula Martinez presented a brilliant show that stripped bare her relationship with her parents and their relationship with each other. This latest performance strips bare Martinez herself.

If it is not so interesting, that is not because Martinez's new work is any less quirky or entertaining than her last show. It is simply because part of the appeal of A Family Outing was that we all have families, and the dysfunction of Martinez's seemed to be in some way universal. Show Off - part of the British Festival of Visual Theatre - suffers from the fact that it is about Ursula Martinez and, although she is very interesting, we are not all Ursula Martinez.

In fact the question of who the real Ursula Martinez is, is at the core of the piece - in which the illusion of theatre and the images of ourselves that we present for public consumption collide and explode. Is the Ursula Martinez who makes solo work about her life the same Ursula Martinez as the one who walks down a street? Is she how she is because she is a performer or did she become a performer because of how she is?

Similar questions occupied many of the long dull years of my adolescence. Although Martinez's show does not really rise above that level of teenage philosophical inquiry, it is all done with such wit that it somehow seems more substantial than it really is.

The body of the show, which lasts about five minutes, consists of Martinez performing a striptease while doing a conjuring trick with a hanky that miraculously keeps disappearing and reappearing out of the next garment to be discarded. When she is stark naked, the hanky appears from out of her vagina. Martinez proceeds to answer a series of after-show questions. These go along the lines of: "How difficult is it to play yourself?" (answer: "What I find most difficult is to imitate my own accent") and "What are the politics in your show?" (answer: "Ah, I knew I'd forgotten to put something in. I had a checklist").

It would be very easy for the piece to become merely irritating, but Martinez's (carefully contrived) persona is so engaging and she has so much theatrical trickery up her sleeve that it is impossible not to want the real Ursula Martinez to stand up for rather longer than just an hour.

webTitle: Grimandi's beauty is in the eye of the beholder

fields.headline: Grimandi's beauty is in the eye of the beholder
fields.trailText: After Arsène Wenger claimed yet again that he had not seen a nasty incident involving one of his players, Roy Collins reports on those managers who have turned 'doing a Wenger' into an art form.
fields.body:
If there was one splendidly predictable reaction after Gilles Grimandi's perfectly executed short right into the face of Lazio's Diego Simeone in Rome on Tuesday, it was the one delivered by Arsenal's manager Arsène Wenger.

Wenger, the man acclaimed as a footballing visionary despite being inflicted by eyesight that would seem to be on a par with Mister Magoo's, claimed that he had not seen the incident, just as he has failed to get a clear look at any other transgression by an Arsenal player in his four years at Highbury. One doubts that he would even be capable of picking out Grimandi in an identity parade.

Wenger really should pop into Specsavers to get the red-tinted lenses in his glasses changed. He could, of course, be suffering from amblyopia, a condition in which one's vision deteriorates without any discernible change in the eye, though in the incident at Sunderland that led to his 12-match touchline ban, he could have blamed tunnel vision.

It is, in any case, a well known medical fact that football managers can develop a peculiar strain of colour blindness, in which only bad incidents involving players in the other team's shirts make any impression on the surface of the eye. So though Wenger is the manager most renowned for seeing, speaking and hearing no evil where his players are concerned, he is not the only one to suffer from selective blindness.

Managers are naturally defensive about admitting what they see because of the danger of putting both feet in their mouth and incurring the wrath not just of the FA but, more crucially, their players. And Wenger is an apostle of the managerial style which advocates that, short of one of your players committing mass murder, you defend them against all charges.

It was a style which allowed the late Sir Alf Ramsey to win the devotion of his players, as tough on them as he was in private. And Sir Alex Ferguson never publicly criticises his players, though naturally he believes it is quite OK to slaughter his best player in print when he has an autobiography to sell.

Pleading the fifth, however, or, as it should be known in the football fraternity, "doing a Wenger", is not the only method to ensure dressing-room harmony. Ferguson, who believes that everyone outside Old Trafford detests Manchester United (they do), has adopted the position of a parent of a recidivist child, denying that his little darlings can do any wrong. Why not, when even Violet Kray insisted that she reared a couple of little angels.

John Gregory of Aston Villa takes up more middle ground, a practitioner of the mocking tone in which he can openly castigate a player without hurting his feelings. Thus after Lee Hendrie was sent off at Highbury on Saturday for a second bookable offence (an incident which, miraculously, Wenger saw in pinpoint detail), he said: "Frankly, he was a prat."

Peter Reid of Sunderland favours straightness, assuming the paterfamilias manner of a dad taking a strap to his son while telling the lad: "This is going to hurt me more than it hurts you."

He made no excuses for Kevin Kilbane, who was sent off against Chelsea for pushing Graeme le Saux, which many would have thought deserving of a pay rise rather than a club fine. But Reid admitted the referee was right and added: "We have a code of conduct at the club and Kevin will be fined. I don't like handing it out because he is a model pro but rules are rules."

The Chelsea manager Claudio Ranieri, who is still adapting to English ways, felt it was safest to do a Wenger, saying of the challenge that led to Le Saux's dismissal, "I didn't actually see it," though as his thoughts had to be translated from Italian, one would like to believe that the word prat had been in there somewhere.

Ranieri was right to err on the side of caution since there is a fragile trust between a manager and his players and one breach can destroy dressing-room morale. Frank Leboeuf's open criticism of his previous manager Gianluca Vialli destroyed the illusion of a contented Chelsea dressing room, though given their recent history, that would appear to be an oxymoron.

Ruud Gullit also discovered that when you lose your players you lose your job, not just at Chelsea but at Newcastle too. And the best way to lose them, as Glenn Hoddle found out after the publication of his infamous England diary, is through indiscretion.

There is no danger of that from Wenger, which explains why his players will not only run through walls for him but continually scale them to escape from seemingly impossible holes, as they did again in Rome. Not seeing is believing.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Lazio player called me 'monkey' says Vieira

fields.headline: Lazio player called me 'monkey' says Vieira
fields.trailText: Uefa launched an investigation last night into allegations that Patrick Vieira was racially abused by Lazio's Sinisa Mihajlovic throughout Arsenal's Champions League game in Rome.
fields.body:
Uefa launched an investigation last night into allegations that Patrick Vieira was racially abused by Lazio's Sinisa Mihajlovic throughout Arsenal's Champions League game in Rome.

Vieira has claimed the abuse heaped on him by the Yugoslavia defender was the worst he had heard.

The behaviour of Lazio fans, who taunted Arsenal's black players and hurled objects at the team at the end of Tuesday's 1-1 draw, will also be investigated.

"Mihajlovic called me a fucking black monkey and when you are a player you are not happy to hear that," said Vieira, who in the past might easily have lost his cool in the face of such provocation. "What is really surprising is it has come from a player who is a foreigner in Italy.

"It started in the first game at Highbury and I thought maybe it was just because we won the game that he was upset. When a fan does it it's stupid, when a player does it it's unbelievable. It is the worst abuse I have ever heard and it never stopped from the moment the teams were shaking hands at the start. I told him he'd said enough.

"You could see in his eyes that he was really thinking about what he said. It was very hurtful and difficult to accept when another pro player says things like that.

"When fans do it, you can do something about it; they can be identified. But when a player says it to you on the pitch it is difficult to prove. I feel I have to speak out about this and do something. You have to tell the truth."

Mihajlovic admitted last night he had made reference to Vieira's colour but denied the insults were racist and claimed Vieira had started the squabble by calling him a gypsy. "Yes, it's true I said 'black shit', but he provoked me by saying 'gypsy shit'," he said. "I called him black but I might just as well have called him French. If I'm a racist then at this point so is he for calling me a gypsy.

"I don't have anything against blacks. I didn't want to insult him because of the colour of his skin, just as I'm sure he didn't want to insult me by calling me gypsy."

Depending on what is included in the report filed by the German referee Helmut Krug, and possible evidence presented by other independent witnesses, Uefa may have trouble making charges stick against Mihajlovic.

But Lazio face a fine at the very least. Uefa recently fined Red Star Belgrade £16,000 after their fans hurled flares at Leicester supporters and shouted racist abuse.

"Uefa absolutely condemns all forms of racist abuse," said its director of communications Mike Lee. "When any allegation of this kind is made we take it extremely seriously."

Lazio are known for attracting an extreme right-wing fringe and their president Sergio Cragnotti has apologised for Tuesday's racist behaviour of a section of fans. But Lazio insisted the abuse was the work of "a few hundred imbeciles" and hit out at a "defamatory campaign" to brand the club and its supporters as racist.

Having received the reports of Krug and its match delegate, Uefa is also investigating the ill-tempered squabbles that marred the evening. They included Arsenal's Gilles Grimandi striking Diego Simeone, leaving the midfielder with a cut above his eye, and an after-match fight involving Grimandi, Mihajlovic and his Lazio team-mate Alessandro Nesta.

Grimandi, who said he pushed Simeone away after having his shirt tugged but did not punch him or try to hurt him, can expect a suspension.

Mihajlovic claimed the Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein was "involved in the uproar at the end", but that was denied by Dein.

 Rome prosecutors have asked for Lazio's president Sergio Cragnotti and Juan Veron to be indicted over alleged document-faking to get the Argentine an Italian passport. It is claimed that Veron's dual citizenship helped Lazio field an extra, prohibited non-European Union player in some games last season.

fields.headline: Seven in 'no-play' threat to Miandad
fields.trailText: Five days before England's first one-day international against Pakistan the home team are in disarray, after a row between the coach Javed Miandad and his seven most senior players.
fields.body:
Five days before England's first one-day international against Pakistan the home team are in disarray, after a row between the coach Javed Miandad and his seven most senior players.

Last night the two sides, despite emollient words from the Pakistan Cricket Board's all-powerful chairman Lieutenant-General Tauqir Zia, were said to be bitterly divided and scarcely talking to each other.

Yesterday morning Dawn, the leading national newspaper, reported that the seven had clashed with Miandad over the distribution of prize money earned from the recent ICC Knockout tournament in Kenya, where Pakistan were beaten by New Zealand in the semi-finals.

Later the Reuters news agency reported that the seven, understood to be the captain Moin Khan, Wasim Akram, Waqar Younis, Saqlain Mushtaq, Ijaz Ahmed, Inzamam-ul-Haq and Saeed Anwar, would not play against England in the one-day series unless Miandad was removed as coach.

At first Tauqir Zia denied a rift. "If there was any dispute with the players I'm sure the management would have told me. But they didn't," he said. "So I called the players together and they denied there was any dispute. Miandad will be coach until 2003."

But later the chairman did concede that coach and players did not always see eye to eye. "As far as his cricket ability is concerned they respect him a lot. There are minor differences, which will always happen in a family. But they are not the ones that would destroy the unity of the team."

When asked whether Miandad still regarded himself as a player he replied: "I guess so. He is so enthusiastic; he drives the players."

Last night one of the country's most respected cricket writers said: "There could be big trouble ahead. The players and Miandad are not really talking with each other. The trouble is less to do with money than the fact that Miandad wants to run everything. He wants to be big and fill every position in the dressing room.

"Moin, the captain, and Wasim, who has had his differences with the coach, are the main men against him."

Miandad, 43 and the country's most successful batsman, is in his second stint as coach after four spells as captain. He played a dark hand in the infamous series of 13 years ago when the then England captain Mike Gatting and the Lahore umpire Shakoor Rana apparently agreed to apologise to each other after a confrontation on the second day of the Faisalabad Test. Miandad, then the Pakistan captain, is believed to have advised Shakoor not to back down. His brilliant batting never disguised a sometimes confrontational style.

The Pakistan Cricket Board, meanwhile, announced last night that Wasim, who has refused to pay the £3,750 fine imposed after the Qayyum report on match-fixing, will have that amount deducted from his pay unless he appeals by tomorrow.

Yesterday morning Dawn, the leading national newspaper, reported that the seven had clashed with Miandad over the distribution of prize money earned from the recent ICC Knockout tournament in Kenya, where Pakistan were beaten by New Zealand in the semi-finals. Later the Reuters news agency reported that the seven, understood to be the captain Moin Khan, Wasim Akram, Waqar Younis, Saqlain Mushtaq, Ijaz Ahmed, Inzamam-ul-Haq and Saeed Anwar, would not play against England in the one-day series unless Miandad was removed as coach. At first Tauqir Zia denied a rift. "If there was any dispute with the players I'm sure the management would have told me. But they didn't," he said. "So I called the players together and they denied there was any dispute. Miandad will be coach until 2003." But later the chairman did concede that coach and players did not always see eye to eye. "As far as his cricket ability is concerned they respect him a lot. There are minor differences, which will always happen in a family. But they are not the ones that would destroy the unity of the team." When asked whether Miandad still regarded himself as a player he replied: "I guess so. He is so enthusiastic; he drives the players." Last night one of the country's most respected cricket writers said: "There could be big trouble ahead. The players and Miandad are not really talking with each other. The trouble is less to do with money than the fact that Miandad wants to run everything. He wants to be big and fill every position in the dressing room. "Moin, the captain, and Wasim, who has had his differences with the coach, are the main men against him." Miandad, 43 and the country's most successful batsman, is in his second stint as coach after four spells as captain. He played a dark hand in the infamous series of 13 years ago when the then England captain Mike Gatting and the Lahore umpire Shakoor Rana apparently agreed to apologise to each other after a confrontation on the second day of the Faisalabad Test. Miandad, then the Pakistan captain, is believed to have advised Shakoor not to back down. His brilliant batting never disguised a sometimes confrontational style. The Pakistan Cricket Board, meanwhile, announced last night that Wasim, who has refused to pay the £3,750 fine imposed after the Qayyum report on match-fixing, will have that amount deducted from his pay unless he appeals by tomorrow.

fields.headline: ICC pose five fixing questions
fields.trailText: International cricketers, umpires and officials have six weeks to sign a confidential declaration regarding the extent of their involvement in match-rigging.
fields.body:
International cricketers, umpires and officials have six weeks to sign a confidential declaration regarding the extent of their involvement in match-rigging.

The International Cricket Council questionnaire will demand five yes-or-no answers designed to determine whether those quizzed have been approached about, or involved in, rigging matches, deliberately breaching the laws of cricket or the ICC's code of conduct, offering selection or weather information for financial gain, playing badly to contrive a result, or corruption in any form.

Solving crime by asking potential criminals whether they have done anything wrong went out of fashion when the BBC abandoned Dixon of Dock Green, so the ICC must brace itself for further accusations that its leadership is irredeemably weak and confused.

For once that accusation is somewhat unfair. These seemingly naive questions do at least carry the warning that anybody failing to disclose full information about corruption leaves himself open to disciplinary action and "heavy penalties". Anything that might one day assist the legal process is to be welcomed.

Anybody answering yes to any of the questions will be obliged to provide details to the head of the ICC's anti-corruption unit, Sir Paul Condon.

The ICC properly chose to make no get-tough gestures prior to Lord Griffiths's report into match fixing, which is due for completion in the spring. By electing for what its chief executive David Richards termed "a thorough investigation" rather than a knee-jerk reaction, they ignored the crass calls of Lord MacLaurin, chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, for anyone under suspicion to be suspended until they had been investigated.

With England embarking on their first tour of Pakistan for 13 years, his call was also politically insensitive: six Pakistani players have been punished, two suffering life suspensions. The ICC might eventually judge those sentences inadequate. But for the moment Lord Griffiths has expressed his faith in the Pakistanis' determination to root out corruption and has been asked by the ICC to press them for further details.

webTitle: Cash boost for hard-up Real Madrid

fields.headline: Cash boost for hard-up Real Madrid
fields.trailText: The weight of an enormous financial deficit has eased slightly for Real Madrid after the club announced a £46m merchandising deal with the Caja Madrid bank.
fields.body:
A day after qualifying for the lucrative second stage of the Champions League, Real Madrid received a second boost when they announced a merchandising deal with the Caja Madrid bank worth 13bn pesetas (£46m) to the cash-strapped Spanish club.

The deal will see the club and Caja Madrid jointly exploit the club's internet rights, as well the image rights of the club and players, over a period of 11 years.

Real will keep 80% of the proceeds, with the remainder going to the bank. Real's chairman Florentino Perez, who announced last month that the club were more than £166m in debt, said the proceeds from the agreement would make up the deficit in the budget for the 2000-01 season.

"The short-term problem is now solved and we're studying the situation over the medium and long term," said Perez, who was elected to the post ahead of Lorenzo Sanz during the summer after promising to spend £37m on bringing Luis Figo from Barcelona. "What I want is for Real Madrid to be the richest as well as the best club in the world."

A 5-3 victory over Bayer Leverkusen at the Bernabeu stadium booked the champions' passage to next spring's second stage alongside Arsenal and last season's runners-up Valencia, who won 2-1 in Lyon after Marc-Vivien Foé was sent off for the French team.

The win put Valencia six points clear at the head of Group C ahead of Greece's Olympiakos. In Group A Spartak Moscow need only a point from their next two games to be sure of qualifying alongside Real Madrid.

fields.headline: Social services brace for squeeze
fields.standfirst: As a survey reveals overspending, chiefs warn that cuts will increase pressure on the NHS
fields.trailText: Directors of social services have warned of a round of emergency spending cuts this winter that will increase pressure on the NHS during the most politically dangerous phase of the government's health service reforms.
fields.body:
Directors of social services have warned of a round of emergency spending cuts this winter that will increase pressure on the NHS during the most politically dangerous phase of the government's health service reforms.

They are bracing themselves for a squeeze on services that help thousands of older people stay out of hospital or get speedy discharge.

A confidential survey of 71 social services departments in England has revealed a projected overspend averaging 2.1%. To balance the books over the final six months of the financial year would require cuts worth more than £160m.

Jo Williams, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, said councils would do their utmost to co-operate with the NHS to reduce pressure in hospital beds. "But in some areas we are heading for cuts, we are between a rock and a hard place."

The cuts are likely to include less domiciliary care and delays in the assessment of older people's needs, but would inevitably lengthen their stay in hospital.

Earlier this year the government allocated an extra £60m to reduce "bed blocking" by providing additional social services to speed the discharge of elderly patients.

But this sum has been dwarfed by unexpected extra demands on the 150 social service departments' in England. These include more children coming into council care, more spending on services for disabled children, and more demand for services from older people.

The survey of a representative sample of 71 local authorities found 22 are projecting an overspend of 3% or more and 27 of between 2% and 3%. None was under-spending and a few were exceeding their budget by up to 6%.

The figures were revealed at a private meeting of directors during the annual social services conference in Edinburgh.

Mrs Williams said: "When we talk to our NHS colleagues they are anxious about us not being able to provide the money to get people into nursing or residential care.

"We will do everything we can to work in partnership with colleagues in the health service, as we did successfully last year. But there is a capacity problem and there is an issue about the amount of money in the system."

Ministers are giving maximum priority to avoiding a winter crisis in the hospitals that could expose the NHS reform plan to attack from the Conservatives in the run-up to the election.

A Department of Health source said: "We appreciate that some local authorities have severe winter problems. They have tended to slow down assessments, particularly of older people, to delay discovery of legal obligations to look after them. While that is superficially sensible for the local government, the difficulty for us is that it causes bed blocking ... We want health and social services to recognise there is a shared problem."

Rita Stringfellow, chairwoman of the Local Government Association's social affairs and health executive, told the conference: "There is a nervousness about how we will cope this winter."

 The National Council for Voluntary Organisations last night told ministers that the NHS reform plan will fail unless they consult more with local communities and voluntary groups. Stuart Etherington, chief executive, will tell the conference today: "I have no sense that the plan recognises the fundamental importance for voluntary organisations in health and social care, and the diverse range of roles that voluntary organisations play in those fields."

fields.headline: Buzz Lightyear to GMTV and beyond
fields.trailText: 5pm: Buzz Lightyear mania is set to rip through Britain again after GMTV signed up a 65-part TV series writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Buzz Lightyear mania is set to rip through Britain again after GMTV signed up a 65-part TV series based on the hit character from Toy Story.

Disney Channel will screen the series on its British TV channel in January followed by the breakfast station later in the year.

In the Toy Story films, Lightyear - who is voiced by US comedian Tim Allen and has the catchphrase "To infinity and beyond" - is a toy who thinks he is actually a Star Command space ranger fighting the evil Emperor Zurg.

In the TV spin-off, titled Star Command, Lightyear is no longer a toy, but a real space ranger battling to save the universe from his arch enemy Zurg.

Star Command will be available to pay-TV viewers from early January 2001 on Disney Channel UK.

Paul Robinson, the managing director of Disney's UK TV operation, said the 65 x 30-minute series would air daily at 4.30pm. GMTV will give the show, which has been produced by Disney's LA-based animation studio, its terrestrial premiere from September.

fields.headline: Train derailed outside Stafford
fields.trailText: A rush hour passenger train has been derailed outside Stafford station, British Transport Police said.
fields.body:
A rush hour passenger train has been derailed outside Stafford station, British Transport Police said.

The first two carriages of a Virgin train from Birmingham New Street to London left the tracks at about 17.53 while travelling at about 15mph; no one is thought to have been injured. All the passengers were evacuated and taken to Stafford station.

A Railtrack spokesman confirmed that two wheels of the two front coaches of the Virgin Cross Country train had come off the rails, but that all coaches had remained upright.

He said: "It was the 16.57 train from Birmingham New Street, due to arrive in Manchester Piccadilly at 18.42.

"It was a very low speed derailment, at about 15mph, and initial reports are that the front two wheels of the two leading coaches came off the rails.

"All of the coaches remained upright. A full investigation has begun," he added.

webTitle: Old universities warm to vocational degrees

fields.headline: Old universities warm to vocational degrees
fields.trailText: Traditional universities are bidding in unexpectedly high numbers to run the governments new two year vocational degree.
fields.body:
Traditional universities are bidding in unexpectedly high numbers to run the governments new two year vocational degree.

Just under a third of applications to pilot the first foundation degrees at the start of the next academic year involve some of the biggest research players in the academic sector, officials have disclosed.

Their enthusiasm is a huge boost for David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, who is desperate to secure credibility for these new vocational qualifications with employers and potential students.

Warwick University, Birmingham University and the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology are among those entering the competition to run the technical training courses, launched by the Higher Education Funding Council for England in July.

Education ministers hope foundation degrees will address a shortage of people in the country with intermediate-level skills, needed for technical, administrative and skilled trade professions such as graphic designers, legal executives and finance analysts.

But Blunketts initiative initially received a frosty reaction from many academics concerned that the two year vocational course would devalue the international reputation of the UKs traditional three year academic degree. It was thought that most older universities would spurn vocational training courses and stick to their core academic degrees.

Yet while the majority of bids for the new courses involve former polytechnics, 17 of the 57 applications are led by old universities. Partnerships bidding for funds to develop foundation degrees must consist of : a higher education institution that will award the degree; employer representatives who will shape the course for their needs; and institutions that will deliver the course, usually further education colleges. About 2,000 students will be able to take up the new courses, offered by between 10 and 20 partnerships in 2001-02. The results of the competition are due to be announced in November.

fields.headline: The after-life
fields.standfirst: Few former stars of the political firmament can expect the same high regard in which Donald Dewar is held
fields.trailText: Among the many words uttered in eulogy for Donald Dewar in Glasgow cathedral yesterday few, if any, were indelicate enough to suggest that Scotland's first first minister in 300 years was lucky in the manner and timing of his death. Such talk is too soon for those who mourn him most.
fields.body:
Among the many words uttered in eulogy for Donald Dewar in Glasgow cathedral yesterday few, if any, were indelicate enough to suggest that Scotland's first first minister in 300 years was lucky in the manner and timing of his death. Such talk is too soon for those who mourn him most.

Yet in the longer perspective it is true. Donald Dewar was a rare politician in all the ways that people wrote and talked about last week, including many who had been abusing him only days earlier. But to die quickly - surrounded by affection - after being instrumental in bringing one's lifetime ambition to fruition is not a fate given to most of us, let alone to the restless souls of politicians.

Contrast the man they buried yesterday with his great friend, John Smith. The contrast is a cruel one. Smith, like Hugh Gaitskell to an earlier Labour generation, remains a might-have-been leader, struck down in 1994 - mercifully quickly, which is better than the long decline which beset such people as Harold Wilson.

But it happened before he had the chance to lead Labour to victory in 1997. A smaller victory than Tony Blair's perhaps, but who knows whether it would have been a smaller government.

No such ill luck for Donald. Devolution may go belly-up from now on, one way or another. It may prove a shining success, as even the Scottish Nationalists under John Swinney quietly embrace the Catalan model (lip service to independence and maximalist autonomy within the Spanish state).

Either way, Dewar's place in his country's history and affections is likely to remain secure long after the hospitals and schools named after him have crumbled. It will not be his fault.

Things do not work that way for most politicians. The mordant Enoch Powell once wrote that "all political careers end in failure." He was thinking of his hero, Joseph Chamberlain, who walked out of Gladstone's Liberal government over Irish home rule, then wrecked the Tory party too over "imperial free trade" but - like Powell himself - lived long enough to see most of his destructive genius brought to nought.

That is the general rule. Churchill said in 1940: "I did not become his majesty's chief minister in order to preside over the dissolution of the British Empire." But of course he did. It is true that not a square foot of territory was decolonised in Churchill's second term (1951-55), but India had already gone under Labour (1947) and by his death in 1965 the bankruptcy sale was almost over.

In his 10-year retirement Churchill, so his doctor later wrote, had longed to die, but couldn't. At least he resigned office just in time. Among his contemporaries Tito of Yugoslavia, Franco of Spain and Charles de Gaulle all hung on both to life and office. For each it ended in tears - tears are still being shed in Belgrade.

FDR, by way of contrast, died, exhausted, a few days before Hitler in April 1945, with victory all but assured. He is with the immortals. Jack Kennedy, a somewhat lesser figure, is too, simply by virtue of a premature martyr's death, grace and style wantonly destroyed - just like Jimmies Dean and Hendrix (but not Elvis), like John (but not Yoko). And like Princess Di.

Old age need not be a burden to the great and good. In our own time both Ted Heath, Conservative prime minister from 1970-74, and Labour's Jim Callaghan show every sign of having embraced greater serenity in old age than in office. Unlike Heath, Callaghan has rarely uttered a word of criticism against his successors. But Sir Edward, now 84, has gamely hung on in the Commons (he will surely retire next time) and seen off the woman who blighted his career. He may even be vindicated on Europe in his lifetime.

Barbara Castle, 90 this month, has stayed magnificently on the ball: a policy player. But Lady Thatcher ... oh dear. Just as it is wholly predictable that amiable John Major will enjoy his retirement, so it was equally certain the day she shed that tear as she left Downing Street in November 1990 that the years ahead would be like Norma Desmond's in Sunset Boulevard. Mr Major's political body may be floating facedown in her swimming pool (will Hague's too?) but her frantic spirit seems to find little peace.

I'm still big, she tells adoring paying audiences in Japan or America, it's the movies that got small. But events have not been kind to her in so many ways, from Pinochet to the former Soviet bloc, as Lech Walesa has just discovered the hard way - 1% of the vote in Poland. Even the credit for Thatcher's ruthless economic reforms may go to others. Poland no longer needs its shipyard hero either. Nothing is more painful than the realisation that the world has moved on. What mattered then does not matter now.

At least Lady Thatcher has Denis, a man who deserves to be a feminist icon for his loyal self-effacement. But even here her arch-rival, Michael Heseltine, has out-smarted her. Hezza too has his family. But he also has his beloved arboretum, painstakingly created at his country seat near Banbury. Trees, like Scottish parliaments, last a long time.

michael.white@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Survey sheds light on Oxbridge access
fields.standfirst:
Family and school links help smooth way to top universities

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: One in five students at Cambridge University has a parent who studied there or at Oxford, according to research out today.
fields.body:
One in five students at Cambridge University has a parent who studied there or at Oxford, according to research out today.

Among students from non-selective state schools, one in three Cambridge undergraduates were the only pupils from their school year to go to Oxbridge. But that experience was true for only one in 20 students from private schools. About 40% of private school students knew of 11 or more of their contemporaries going on to Oxford or Cambridge.

The investigation by the Cambridge Student newspaper shows a strong although not decisive link between going to Cambridge and knowing headteachers, subject teachers or family members who had studied there. It was welcomed as reinforcing the need for top universities to do more to attract working class and state school students.

In the poll 20.1% of students had a parent who attended Cambridge or Oxford; 14.2% had at least one parent who went to Cambridge; 4% had a parent who attended the same college; 39.6% had a family member - parent, grandparent, uncle, aunt or older sibling - who went to Oxbridge; 77.7% knew of a headteacher, tutor or main subject teacher who went to Oxbridge and more than half knew one who went to Cambridge.

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said last night: "This reveals, more than any of the previous surveys, that it is not a level playing field. If the universities don't want to exercise positive discrimination they still have to implement positive policies.

"It confirms the widely held view among headteachers and bright students in comprehensive schools that it is difficult to gain entry to one of the Oxbridge colleges unless you are familiar with the system."

Peter Lampl, adviser to the higher education funding council for England, said: "These figures show the influence that teachers, family and other students at the same school have on admissions to top universities. They show the importance of summer schools and of universities appointing more admissions officers to go out to state schools from which they do not normally recruit students."

The survey adds depth and texture to the arguments about the admissions policy of top universities since the Laura Spence affair, which have focused on the disparity between state and independent schools and on social class.

The sample of 472 students was weighted, taking into account ratios of gender and previous schooling across the most recent three years at each undergraduate college for non-mature students. Roughly one in 23 students of the eligible 11,000 at the university was interviewed. One question was: "Apart from yourself, how many people from your year in school went to Oxbridge?" Across the survey the answers were: none, 13.6%; one to five, 40.3%; six to 10, 21.6%; 11 or more, 24.6%.

But the mean figure disguises the most marked disparity between private and public school experience brought out by the poll. Among students from private schools, 4.5% were the only ones from their school year to attend Oxbridge; 40.5% knew 11 or more who attended, and 65% knew six or more. Of those from non-selective schools, 29.3% were the only ones to attend Oxbridge. Only 17.2% were at schools where they and six or more others went on to Oxbridge; only one in five were at schools where 11 or more went to Oxbridge.

When family background and schools are linked, students from comprehensive schools are about as likely as grammar school pupils to have parents (about 10%) or close family (about 25%) who attended Cambridge.

Private schools show a 10-point advantage in each category.

Susan Stobbs, director of admissions at Cambridge, said: "We are trying to encourage people who don't have family or school encouragement to think about coming to Cambridge."

Owain James, president of the National Union of Students, said: "There are some great access schemes, but more needs to be done both at local and national level. It proves the case even more for top-up fees being ruled out. We have enough of an access problem as it is."

fields.headline: Banks follow Branson lead
fields.standfirst:
Barclays and Royal Bank ready to take all-in-one route

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Two of the biggest high street banks, Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland, are ready to follow the lead set by Sir Richard Branson's Virgin One and allow customers' salaries to automatically reduce their mortgage payments.
fields.body:
Two of the biggest high street banks, Barclays and Royal Bank of Scotland, are ready to follow the lead set by Sir Richard Branson's Virgin One and allow customers' salaries to automatically reduce their mortgage payments.

The move could potentially save millions of bank customers hundreds of pound a year, but it will also send reverberations around an industry where the main lenders are already locked in a vicious battle for custom.

To date, products such as all-in-one accounts, which allow customers to offset interest earned on credit balances against the costs of debts such as a mortgage, have been restricted to internet banks and other small new entrants, such as Virgin One, which began as a joint venture with Royal Bank three years ago.

These products work by eliminating the artificial barriers that keep current accounts, savings and borrowings, such as personal loans, credit cards and mortgages, separate.

Following the completion of its acquisition of Woolwich next week, Barclays is expected to start targeting specific customers with Open Plan, Woolwich's version of an all-in-one account.

City analysts expect Royal Bank of Scotland to replicate the experience it gained in devising Virgin One, one of the first of these types of accounts, through its own branches and those of NatWest, the clearing bank it bought earlier this year.

The City, though, does not expect Royal Bank-NatWest to operate a full all-in-one account, offering offsets only against mortgages and current accounts rather than credit cards, personal loans and savings. Royal Bank refused to comment on its plans.

The new product arsenals are being drawn up at a time when the stock market is worried over increased competition among the high street banks, fearing the impact on profits.

Recent research by analysts at investment bank Fox-Pitt, Kelton has highlighted the potential for a 9% fall in the profits of the leading clearing banks if they change their strategy on current accounts.

Barclays said last night that once the £5.5bn acquisition of Woolwich was completed it would "target certain groups of customers, mainly those who have one product with us", with Open Plan.

This decision, however, might find the bank having to explain to its customers who might benefit most from the new account - those with more than one product - why they are not being targeted.

Industry executives appear divided over just how much demand there is for such products which are likely to be attractive to only certain groups of customers. For instance mortgage products like the one which Royal Bank is thought to be planning might be most useful to people who receive large bonuses with which they could pay off their mortgages.

But some senior bankers believe that the products may be too confusing for some customers who prefer to keep their money and debts in different "pots", the traditional way of doing banking.

Bankers also suggest that particularly in the race for people with more than £50,000 to invest, more sophisticated products are likely to emerge. One admitted last night that customer behaviour was also harder to judge than in the past which is why banks were likely to introduce more niche products.

One bank which is aiming to take the all-in-one concept further than many others is Halifax's new telephone bank, Intelligent Finance.

fields.headline: Blunkett backs actors' scholarship funding
fields.trailText: Education secretary David Blunkett yesterday reinforced the government's commitment to its new scholarship scheme for dance and drama students. The scheme replaced the previous system of discretionary funding by local authorities.
fields.body:
Education secretary David Blunkett yesterday reinforced the government's commitment to its new scholarship scheme for dance and drama students. The scheme replaced the previous system of discretionary funding by local authorities.

Mr Blunkett was speaking at the opening of the new £22m George Bernard Shaw theatre at RADA where he watched a new production of Shaw's Great Catherine, produced in collaboration with the St Petersburg Theatre Arts Academy, the oldest theatre school in Russia.

Mr Blunkett said British actors receive highly sophisticated and thorough training and that the government was committed to ensuring that all young people of exceptional talent and determination were able to realise their potential by training at the top drama schools.

He noted that there were now 1,600 young actors, dancers and stage managers in training schools funded by the new scholarship. He said the government had inherited a "catastrophic" funding system from the Tories, based on local authorities handing out grants on a discretionary basis.

The new scheme also attracted the backing of RADA graduates attending the show including Steve McFadden, who plays Phil Mitchell in EastEnders. Mr McFadden said: "I was only able to come here because I got discretionary funding from my local authority, but I still had to work in a pub to make ends meet. I think the government's new scheme is a lot fairer than what was in place before, and is to be welcomed".

webTitle: Carlton Interactive appoints design agency Attik

fields.headline: Carlton Interactive appoints design agency Attik
fields.trailText: 8am: Carlton Interactive has appointed design agency Attik to develop a raft of new programme-oriented websites, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Carlton Interactive, the interactive development arm of Carlton Communications, has appointed design agency Attik to develop a raft of new programme-oriented websites.

The first site, Carlton.com/babybaby, went live on Tuesday as an accompaniment to Carlton's new daytime TV series, Baby Baby. Two more sites are in development and plan to launch within the next few months.

The Baby Baby site, which is aimed at young mothers and grandmothers, offers practical advice to pregnant women and those with young children. The site has links to Webbaby.co.uk, which sponsors the TV series, and also features presenter Melinda Messenger.

Steve Aston, marketing director at the website's developer, Attik UK, said: "The website is a valuable extension of the Baby Baby series and is a good example of how broadcasters can give added value and information to viewers through interactive channels. At Attik we felt it was important that the online brand captured the fun, insightful personality of the show."

Attik is a global multi-platform agency that specialises in design and strategy based in Huddersfield, London, New York, San Francisco and Sydney.

webTitle: Press review: what the Middle East papers are saying

fields.headline: 'Days of fire and of fighting'
fields.trailText: As the street violence subsides, some of the fire and brimstone is also ebbing from the regional coverage of events. Jordan state radio and TV, for example, is reporting the shaky ceasefire dispassionately, noting that Israel has ordered its troops where possible to avoid lethal action.
fields.body:
As the street violence subsides, some of the fire and brimstone is also ebbing from the regional coverage of events. Jordan state radio and TV, for example, is reporting the shaky ceasefire dispassionately, noting that Israel has ordered its troops where possible to avoid lethal action.

The Gulf Times, in Qatar, leads with the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, warning of difficult days ahead, "days of fire and of fighting". The paper looks ahead to the weekend summit of Arab nations in Cairo, only the second such meeting since the Gulf War of 1991. Eighteen out of 22 member states of the Arab League have said they will attend. In its comment columns, the paper notes that Israeli agents have snatched eight men allegedly responsible for the Ramallah lynchings last week, and notes caustically: "If the report is true, the Palestinian people will be asking their leaders what action is to be taken against Israeli soldiers and settlers who have gunned down so many people, particularly those who have murdered Palestinian children."

The Palestinian Ministry of Information, in its daily roundup of the local press, also chides the Western media for implying there is a conflict between equals: "Western media, journalists and diplomats are cheating their people and misleading their audiences. It is time for them to show the picture as it is, a Palestinian unarmed population confronting a huge military power occupying the Palestinian land with stones."

The Khaleej Times, in the United Arab Emirates, has an interesting look at the American view of the region in the aftermath of the suicide attack on the destroyer Dole, which killed 19 sailors. The paper says that many US commentators assume the region is infected with pathological anti-Americanism. It notes drily: "Rare is the American analyst who tries to understand the theory of relativity that governs political perceptions, meaning that what may seem like an even-handed peace accord to an ordinary American Joe may look extremely discriminatory to a Palestinian living in occupied Jerusalem."

Arab diplomatic moves also feature strongly in the Jordan Times, which looks ahead to a potentially significant visit to Amman by the Syrian president, Bashar Assad. Jordan's relations with its northern neighbour were at a low ebb through much of the 1990s, with Bashar's despotic father and predecessor, Hafez, bitterly critical of King Hussein's policy of rapprochement with Israel. Now both countries have new rulers, and the paper notes that King Abdullah has already made several visits to Damascus. Both leaders, it says, "have managed to develop a cosy relationship in the past several months, are free from the past sensitivities that marked the often tense ties between the two countries and are committed to improving their national economies and the standard of living of their peoples in the era of globalisation."

The Arab Media Internet Network has an analysis by Daoud Kuttab, one of the shrewdest Palestinian commentators, in which he talks of Israel's three million Arab hostages. He argues that the "closure" which prevents Palestinian movement within the occupied territories, as well as across the border with Israel, is actually fuelling their demands for a separate state: "The way that Barak tried to make political gains out of lifting the blockade produced an angry response.

"Discussions in homes often centred on the absurdity of the situation. People commented on how Israel places a blockade and then begins negotiations with the Palestinians on what it will get in return for lifting this blockade. Such absolute disregard for a civilian population is not much different than their release for money. The difference is that this time three million people are held hostage by a country, which claims to be a democracy."

In Israel, the Jerusalem Post crows over the reported abduction by the Shin Bet or secret service of eight Palestinians held to have taken part in the lynching of two Israeli soldiers last week: "Aside from the simple fact that such barbaric behaviour must not be allowed to go unpunished - although the Palestinian Authority seemed to think differently - the capture of these men once again proves that Israel still has the capability and, more importantly, the determination, to retaliate if the circumstances demand it."

The liberal daily Ha'aretz is concerned about what it sees as a swell of global antisemitism: "Two recent developments have aggravated matters. The first, a quiet and continuing trend, is the erosion of the taboo against anti-Semitism in effect since the Holocaust among elite Western European groups, particularly in Germany. The second, a more visible and forceful trend, involves the support that Arab immigrants in their new countries give to those who attack Jewish institutions."

Also in Ha'aretz, veteran commentator Meron Benvenisti has a thoughtful piece about the torching of forests by Arab Israelis, as part of their violent campaign in support of the Palestinians. The arson attacks have caused outrage in Israel, but as Benvenisti points out: "Many of the forests that were set ablaze were planted to hide the remnants of the Arab civilisation that once existed in this land - villages, cultivated fields, plantations and cemeteries. The planting of these "camouflaging" forests was intended to bury an important stratum in the history of this land and to ensure the burial would not be accompanied by any gravestone or marker. Those who have picnicked in the forests ... and are shocked by the attempts to set those forests ablaze, should remember they are living in the same land with people whose homes have been covered by such forests and who consider the green trees a memorial to their disaster."

fields.headline: Sun's shine bolsters Nasdaq
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Sun Microsystems appeared to have salvaged Nasdaq's battered reputation yesterday when the computer heavyweight reported a jump in sales, sending its shares soaring and reversing the hi-tech index's early morning dive.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York and  John Cassy
fields.body:
Sun Microsystems appeared to have salvaged Nasdaq's battered reputation yesterday when the computer heavyweight reported a jump in sales, sending its shares soaring and reversing the hi-tech index's early morning dive.

Earlier in the day the Nasdaq plunged more than 200 points but later recovered after Wall Street digested Sun's results.

The shares of Sun Microsystems surged nearly 10% after the company prematurely reported sales increased 60% on its website.

Nasdaq's rally, however, was too late to save many European telecoms, media and technology stocks. The Dow Jones European Technology Stoxx 50 index fell 4.8% to 793 points, a new year low.

Nokia shrank 6% while Britain's biggest internet service provider, Freeserve, lost 11%. In London QXL the online auctioneer, lost 12%, slumping to a new low of 22.75p, giving it a market value of just £99m from its peak of £2.6bn.

"Anything which is not profitable or is based on future assumptions is being killed out there," said Peter Misek, analyst at Chase H&Q.

Many internet executives have been quick to defend the sector. Gerald Levin, chairman and chief executive of Time Warner, said: "There's been a lot of swirl around the advertising market, particularly related to the so-called dot.com shake-out. Let me make this particularly clear, I don't buy it and I don't get it."

Mr Levin yesterday sought to allay concerns that regulatory pressures or a plummeting share price would upset the media group's merger with America Online.

webTitle: Airline bars disability campaign chief with wheelchair

fields.headline: Airline bars disability campaign chief with wheelchair
fields.trailText: Bert Massie, the chairman of the Disability Rights Commission, is at the centre of his own discrimination case after being barred from boarding a flight to Edinburgh because he uses a wheelchair.
fields.body:
Bert Massie, the chairman of the Disability Rights Commission, is at the centre of his own discrimination case after being barred from boarding a flight to Edinburgh because he uses a wheelchair.

This morning's incident came a day after the commission launched a high-profile legal challenge against a school that banned a pupil from foreign school trips because he is diabetic.

On arrival at London's City airport Mr Massie was given a boarding pass for his Scotairways flight, but as other passengers boarded he was left waiting in a corridor. When a baggage carrier took him to the plane the doors had been closed.

Mr Massie - who had told Scotairways in advance that he used a wheelchair - offered to "bumshuffle" up the stairs and store the wheelchair in the hold, only to be told by airline staff that they did not take passengers who used wheelchairs.

Scotairways boasts on its website that it is "happy to offer you a number of special services dependent upon your particular needs". It also promises to "get you to that important business meeting" - scant comfort to Mr Massie, who was on his way to Edinburgh to attend the annual social services conference.

The legal challenge launched last night is the first against a school under the goods and services section of the Disability Discrimination Act 1995. He was barred after he had his first severe hypoglycaemic attack on a skiing trip last February.

Now it looks as if the commission will have a second case to pursue, even closer to home.
