webTitle: Big ideas drive China's quest for super status

fields.headline: Big ideas drive China's quest for super status
fields.trailText: China has proclaimed its boundless confidence in the future with a set of grand plans which include placing a robot on the moon. Declaring that the robot "will be sent into space very soon", a leading Chinese researcher told the official news agency that this would be a first step towards manned space flights.
fields.body:
China has proclaimed its boundless confidence in the future with a set of grand plans which include placing a robot on the moon. Declaring that the robot "will be sent into space very soon", a leading Chinese researcher told the official news agency that this would be a first step towards manned space flights.

The "astro-robot" will investigate sites for astronauts, collect samples and send lunar images back to earth, says Sun Zengqi of Qinghua University in a report published yesterday.

China says it already has the technology to build small space laboratories staffed by robots. It also intends to take part in international missions to explore Mars.

Beijing's programme to put a man on the moon was launched in 1992 with the approval of President Jiang Zemin, but reaching for the moon is not the only massive project now under way in a country which has launched many epic enterprises - with mixed results - in the past five decades of communist rule.

Plans for the first railway to Lhasa across the frozen wastes of the Tibetan plateau were confirmed yesterday in Hong Kong. The project ground to a halt in the 1980s because of expense and technical difficulties.

Construction of the 700-mile link to the Chinese railway system will begin in 2002, said Xu Mingyang, vice-chairman of the Tibet autonomous region. The line should be completed, he said optimistically, within four years.

The route will scale a formidable moun tain pass to enter Tibet in the Amdo region, notorious for fierce winter blizzards. The Tibetan plateau has an average elevation of 4,000 metres (13,000ft).

The existing road to Tibet along the same route was built with heavy casualties by the Chinese army in the 1950s. It carries all of the oil and 85% of imports to Tibet, and is often cut by bad weather.

The rail link could tap Tibet's vast mineral resources as well as making it easier for Beijing to move troops into the region to deal with any security threat.

The railway to Tibet from Xining, the provincial capital of Qinghai, reached the town of Golmud, in the same province, in 1984 before being halted. Engineers were baffled by the problem of construction at high altitudes and over frozen soil.

Beijing has confirmed that another epic project - to divert the waters of the Yangtze river to drought-hit north China - has been finally approved. Premier Zhu Rongji has called for an "early start" to the three-stage project which some experts say will take 50 years to complete.

One route will use the ancient Grand Canal to siphon water from the lower Yangtze northwards to Beijing and Tianjin. This will require crossing the Yellow river by either aqueduct or tunnel.

A second route will cross central China linking the middle Yangtze valley with the north, while the third and most ambitious route would be excavated between the upper reaches of the two river systems.

The official People's Daily said on Monday that 94% of the Yangtze's water flows into the sea. China north of the Yangtze contains 63% of the country's arable land but has only 19% of its water resources.

According to one prediction, when the project is finished 110bn cubic metres of water could be piped north each year. This is twice the current volume of the Yellow river which has dried up with increasing frequency in its lower reaches in recent years.

The exact course of the three diversions is still under debate. Enthusiasts argue that the westernmost route will be relatively simple because the Yangtze source waters are at a higher altitude than those of the Yellow River.

Beijing's commitment to these major infrastructural projects shows its determination to build China into one of the world's leading powers in the 21st century.

Another enterprise already under way is the massive Three Gorges dam in the middle reaches of the Yangtze river, a project that reflects a long-standing belief, expressed most forcefully by Mao Zedong, the communist ruler who died in 1976, in the ability of the Chinese people to tame the elements on a grand scale. This led to tragic results in the Great Leap Forward of 1958-61.

Mao himself symbolically helped to shift earth to build a reservoir outside Beijing. But most of the new land created by irrigation became exhausted and hundreds of small dams silted up.

The backyard steel proved mostly unusable and the general chaos led to two years of near-famine in large parts of the countryside.

China launched a new campaign earlier this year to develop the backward western provinces by large-scale injections of funds and human expertise. Critics say that this could also lead to heavy losses if too many infrastructural projects are launched without careful planning.

Earlier in the 20th century, the nationalist leader, Sun Yat-sen, promoted ambitious schemes for economic construction - including an early plan to dam the Yangtze. A small number of Chinese environmentalists now question the wisdom of the Three Gorges dam and other big projects. But most Chinese still believe in Chairman Mao's assertion that China must "make a bigger contribution to mankind".

China's space-age ambitions were boosted last year with the first flight of an unmanned spacecraft around the earth. A second test flight is expected in the near future. "China deserves a place in the world of high technology," the head of the manned spaceflight programme was quoted as saying.

Success in space would have strategic implications for China's nuclear credibility. It would also please millions of Chinese who believe that China should be the equal of the west.

Great leaps forward

200BC The first emperor of China starts the Great Wall to keep out the 'barbarians'. Completed in the 14th-17th century Ming dynasty it extends 3,750 miles.

1950s After the communist victory, Mao's cadres fan out to tackle poverty and suffering. Mass education wipes out illiteracy, with schools set up in the deepest countryside. A nationwide health campaign cuts infant mortality and defeats VD.

1958-60 In the Great Leap Forward, millions of peasants build new dams and melt pots and pans to make steel. Mao's belief that man can conquer nature is proved disastrously wrong: up to 20m may have died from starvation and illness as a result.

1966-76 In the Cultural Revolution, millions follow the famous "model village" to level hills and open up new land. Forests are cut down with serious ecological results.

1980s The post-Mao policy of economic "opening up" attracts foreign investment. Urban China sprouts modern public buildings and millions of new flats.

1990s A second wave of economic reform brings more investment in transport with new railways and China's first motorways. These are followed by a mobile phone revolution and now by the internet. In 1999 China joins the space club with the launch of its first unmanned spacecraft, Shenzou.

2000 The controversial Three Gorges dam, now under construction, will raise the Yangtze by 70 metres with waters backing up for 150 miles. It should provide more power for new industries, but more than a million people will have to leave their homes.

fields.headline: The China syndrome
fields.standfirst: Rural China is still struggling to escape the long decades of poverty, reports John Gittings in Hong Kong
fields.trailText: 19 October, analysis: Rural China is still struggling to escape the long decades of poverty, reports John Gittings in Hong Kong
fields.body:
In a brand-new Shanghai shopping mall, well-dressed urbanites relax at tables in a foreign franchised coffee shop. On the marble pavement outside, peasant migrants from the Chinese interior laboriously scrape away blobs of chewing gum and dirt by hand, using bare razor blades.

Such contrasts are familiar in booming China today, but what is the real extent of rural poverty? In cold statistical terms, the problem is illustrated by two recent sets of figures released this month in Beijing. China recorded solid economic growth of 8.2 per cent year on year in the first nine months of 2000, said the State Statistical Bureau. The Bureau now expects the trend of slowing growth, visible since the early 1990s, to be reversed.

The Chinese economy also got an encouraging boost at the beginning of October during the National Day holiday - extended to a week to encourage consumers to spend their savings in the shops. Nearly 60 million went travelling around the country and were reckoned to have spent about 23 billion Renminbi (£1.9billion).

From the Ministry of Agriculture came a different sort of statistic in its annual white paper. "The price of farm produce (will) stay deplorably low this year, and township and village-run businesses, plagued by fund shortages and a feeble market demand, (cannot) play a robust role as they once did in absorbing surplus rural labour and increasing farmers' income," said the Ministry as summarised by the official China Daily.

Other figures show a significant decline in product prices: wheat prices declined by more than 20 per cent between February 1999 and 2000. Egg prices declined by a staggering 35 per cent. It would be easy to infer from these disparities a classic "contradiction" between urban wealth and rural poverty, but this is an over-simplification.

Rural incomes have grown impressively over the past 20 years and many country dwellers are much better off. Average net rural incomes per capita grew from 134 Renminbi (£10) in 1978 to 2,090 in 1997.

The very term "peasant" to describe the rural population has become anachronistic. "1998 saw an extraordinary... watershed in the history of Chinese civilisation", writes editor Nick Young in the development magazine Chinabrief. "For the first time ever, less than half the working population was employed in agriculture (49.8 per cent), with the majority now divided between secondary (23.5 per cent) and tertiary, service industries (26.7 per cent)."

"For better or for worse," concludes Mr Young in a thoughtful analysis, "- and only the most conservative observer would see no liberating circumstances here - rural China is leaving its long history behind."

The issue of rural poverty is more subtle and harder to pin down. One problem concerns how to define the phenomenon. The Chinese government estimates that only 34 million are now below its poverty line. The figure rises to 106 million if one applies to World Bank criterion of the number with an income of less than one US dollar (equivalent) a day. Even harder to define is the number of "near poor". There are uncounted millions whose current lives are already fairly miserable and who could quickly sink below the line if the economic climate changes for the worse.

Whatever the claims of an "economic miracle", it seems very unlikely that poverty on a significant scale is about to be "eliminated" in China. "The evidence appears to suggest", says Chinabrief, "that poverty is becoming 'deeper', if not more extensive. There are fewer absolute poor, but they are more absolutely poor than before."

The trend is accentuated by the erosion of social welfare provision which has accompanied the Chinese economic reforms of the past two decades. With increased social mobility and a shift to smaller families, the traditional support of the extended family has also been weakened.

All of this suggests a complex set of problems awaiting to be solved which require a more sophisticated approach, both by the Chinese government and by international donors. Other countries suffering from acute poverty may feel that they would be lucky to share China's plight, but for millions of ordinary Chinese it is none the less real. And an economic downturn - either domestically or if the world economy slumps and with it the demand for Chinese export-oriented labour - could plunge millions more back below the line.

 Chinabrief, formerly China Development Briefing, is published quarterly in Hong Kong. More details available here.

fields.headline: Railtrack boss told to stay
fields.standfirst: Statement from Railtrack
fields.trailText: The Railtrack chief executive, Gerald Corbett, is to keep his job as the company admitted today that a broken rail at the centre of the Hatfield train crash should have been replaced sooner.
fields.body:
The Railtrack chief executive, Gerald Corbett, is to keep his job as the company admitted today that a broken rail at the centre of the Hatfield train crash should have been replaced sooner.

In a statement, the firm said the failure to replace the rail "was Railtrack's responsibility".

The board unanimously rejected Mr Corbett's offer to resign, saying he was the best person to lead the inquiry into Tuesday's derailment, which claimed four lives.

The company also said its preliminary view was that a broken rail caused the crash and that the condition of the rail was "wholly unacceptable".

Railtrack also revealed it had identified as many as 100 track locations "with similar characteristics to that at the stretch of track at Hatfield".

Mr Corbett offered to go yesterday, saying "I, personally, am distraught that another tragedy has occurred on our railways".

However, the rail industry generally welcomed the board's decision, which was announced at 6am after a six-hour meeting, which ended around midnight.

But former British Rail senior operations manager Peter Rayner dismissed the announcement as "a good piece of public relations" and asked why speed restrictions had not been in place at Hatfield.

The board met after Railtrack disclosed that the Hatfield section of line has been assessed for re-railing in January this year, with work starting in May.

The company added in a statement that whatever the cause of the crash was, the condition of the track was "not good".

It went on: "The condition of the rail, which was only five years' old, was wholly unacceptable.

"The probable cause of the fracture was gauge corner cracking. The rail was due to be replaced in November. The replacement should have been in place sooner and this was Railtrack's responsibility."

Four people died and 35 were injured when the Great North Eastern Railways 12.10pm London to Leeds high-speed train was derailed on Tuesday.

The Liberal Democrat environment spokesman, Don Foster, welcomed the decision to reject Mr Corbett's resignation. He said: "Disliking the heat in the kitchen does not always justify leaving it, especially when there is a large mess to clear up.

"If you look overall at safety on our railways, there is a lot of concern there, and Gerald Corbett is probably the best-placed person to help us sort these problems out."

There were fears within the rail industry that Mr Corbett's resignation would do little to improve rail safety. He even attracted support from the Paddington survivors' group, which had been sharply critical of him following last year's west London train crash.

webTitle: Comrades, Comedy, and Coming home to roost

fields.headline: Comrades, Comedy, and Coming home to roost
fields.trailText: TALKING ABOUT A REVOLUTION
fields.body:
TALKING ABOUT A REVOLUTION

If, in a few years time, Ipswich are calypsoing their way to Premiership glory while Manchester United languish in the First Division, a few wise men may remember 19 October 2000 and smile. "That was the day," they will tell little Johnny or Jolanda, "that the fat clubs finally went on a diet and the Premiership actually became interesting again." Daddy might then proceed to recount the unlikely story of how it all started when NTL pulled out of a £328m Pay-Per-View football deal.

OK, so a fairer, more exciting Premiership is unlikely. But it's probably a lot closer tonight than it has been for a while. Because the smaller clubs, already unhappy at the way big clubs take most of the TV money, are now in uproar about losing the £5m they were supposedly guaranteed from the PPV deal. And - according to the London Evening Standard - a delegation led by Coventry and supported by Southampton is going to do something about it. Revolutionary talk is in the air: some clubs are wondering about breaking away from the Premier League, and even more are arguing for a fairer distribution of Sky and ITV money.

There is, however, a problem. The small clubs need the support of 14 Premiership clubs if any demand for a more equitable distribution of dosh is to work - but at the moment they are one short. Therefore requiring one of Arsenal, Manchester United, Leeds, Liverpool, Chelsea, Newcastle or West Ham to switch allegiances (c'mon you Hammers!). "If we do not change the formula we have got, we will end up with a situation similar to that in Scotland where only a couple of clubs can realistically compete," warned Charlton chief executive Peter Varney today, as the Fiver nailed a hammer and sickle to its own face.

SINISA-Y, I SAY, I SAY

Do you fancy a fun night out? A right old laugh? Then why not pay a visit to Sinisa Mihajlovic's Embassy club? You can pull up a chair, order yourself a battered-pie-in-a-basket and swill several pints of foaming Bigot's Finger while old uncle Sin keeps you entertained with a hilarious tirade of witty racial abuse. And he's absolutely brilliant! But don't just take our word for it: here's some of today's matinee performance, when Sinisa did a quick improv session and came up with some observational stuff about Patrick Vieira and a "fucking black monkey".

"I insulted Vieira, but only as an answer to his insults," Sinisa told the crowd once he had brought an end to his classic 'Arkan made the trains run on time' routine. "He called me a dirty gypsy, so I answered back with dirty black. I did call him a black bastard, but I didn't call him a monkey. He doesn't look like a monkey, but if he did I would probably have called him that."

After the drum rolls and cymbal crashes died down, Sinisa continued his crazy skit. "Vieira provoked me not for the first time in games that we have played. This time I gave him some back. I don't care what colour his skin his, nobody does that to me and treats me that way." And just as the audience thought they could laugh no more, the punchline knocked them off their chairs: "I accept my responsibilities, but if there are going to be any bans, I should not be the only one to pay. If I am a racist, so is Vieira." He is a scream, isn't he? And remember - you won't ever hear him making fun of disabled kiddies.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"He was excessively relaxed, he was even singing in the dressing room and on the pitch he put in a fantastic performance. That's the English spirit" - Singing and deep breathing that's the essence of England. Robert Pires offers a few observations on teammate John Lukic.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

IS IT COS THEY IS BLACK CATS?

In 1999, the Fiver did something quite unfortunate. We said something nice about a football club, namely Sunderland AFC, and suggested that by keeping their admission prices low, they might actually be doing a good thing. We were reminded of that moment only this morning, when, two days after Chelsea and Newcastle dived into the red, the Black Cats (another, not-so endearing, innovation on the part of Sunderland's management) announced their profits had trebled in the last year.

In the sort of statement that market analysts might consider marrying, the Chief Executive of Sunderland PLC, John Fickling, said: "We have managed to increase turnover from sponsorship, gate receipts and other revenue streams, while keeping costs under control." The only real rise was in the percentage of the club's income spent on wages (going up from 40 to 50%), but with most players locked in longer-term contracts, the club feel it is unlikely to rise much further.

So while Chelsea attempt to suggest that pre-tax losses of £3.5m actually mean the club (or village, or whatever) are in rude health, Sunderland's most expensive season ticket remains only £10 more expensive than Ken Bates's cheapest. And while the Mags count the cost of paying off Freddie Fletcher, the "rottweiler" who sparked the Save Our Seats scandal, Sunderland are quietly reaping the rewards of treating supporters like fans. It's a funny old game, isn't it?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Edu may yet join Arsenal. The Brazilian, who was prevented from entering the UK after he arrived at customs with a fake Portuguese passport, believes he now has the correct documentation and that the Gunners still want to buy him. "I have spoken to Arsenal, who still want to sign me," he said. "I can't wait to go back and play for them."

Mark Bosnich has reportedly turned down an offer to join Coventry on loan.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Joe Kinnear has returned to football by taking up a consultant's role at Oxford United. The former Wimbledon manager is to assess the club's position and suggest improvements. Chairman Firoz Kassam said: "He will join us as a consultant with a view to discussing a longer-term arrangement."

Chelsea's England under-21 fullback Jon Harley has joined Wimbledon on a three-month loan.

Walter Smith has denied reports that Paul Gascoigne is to leave Everton for American Major League Soccer side Miami Fusion. The MLS outfit claim to have already opened talks with the 33-year-old, but Smith said today: "The report is rubbish. When Paul came here he signed a two-year contract and nothing has changed."

Laurent Charvet is expected to complete a £1.5m move from Newcastle to Manchester City within the next 24 hours.

Crystal Palace and Nottingham Forest have both been fined after being found guilty of "mass confrontation" by the FA. Palace have been fined £20,000 and Forest £15,000 after a fracas during their First Division fixture in August.

Eyal Berkovic has said he will consider leaving Celtic if first team opportunities are not forthcoming. "I don't want to destroy my career with Israel," he said. "I'm losing my fitness. It is not the best to sit on the bench but I will wait for my chance."

He Was He Is Emmanuel Petit was released from hospital today after doctors said he had not suffered any serious injury during Barcelona's 3-3 draw with AC Milan last night. Petit was stretchered off the field after a clash of heads with team-mate Philip Cocu.

Arthur Numan has opened negotiations with Rangers over an extension to his current Ibrox contract.

Uefa have refused to overturn Celtic midfielder Stilian Petrov's booking against Helsinki in the first round of Euro-Vase.

Derby are giving a trial to French defender Lilian Martin, 29, who plays for Marseille.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Football League Review (7pm) Fulham are nearly as tedious as Manchester United. Discuss.

Fifa TV (7.30pm) The latest episode in this award-winning sitcom sees Sepp Blatter trying to borrow a lawnmower from argumentative neighbour Lennart, without him noticing.

Spanish Football (8pm) Featuring analysis from that bloke who hasn't quite grasped the English language yet. But if Gerry Armstrong isn't available, that journalist chap from Spain will be on instead.

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm) Proving that it really is possible to hold a forced grin in place for a whole hour.

Sky Sports 3: Classic World Cup Football (10pm) Brazil v an injured Stan Lazaridis from the 1964 World Cup.

ONsport: Football (from 6.20pm) Possibly something to do with Big Cup. Is there anything else on this channel?

webTitle: Consumer: The difference between product and brand

fields.headline: Brands on the run
fields.standfirst: So you thought you chose Nike trainers just because you liked the colour? Well, think again. Why we buy what we buy is much more complex, say the experts. As the V&A unveils an exhibition devoted to the world's biggest consumer names,  Belinda Archer  discovers the difference between a mere product and a brand
fields.trailText: So you thought you chose Nike trainers just because you liked the colour? Well, think again. Why we buy what we buy is much more complex, say the experts. As the V&A unveils an exhibition devoted to the world's biggest consumer names, Belinda Archer discovers the difference between a mere product and a brand
fields.body:
Are you the sort of person who reaches for Kellogg's Corn Flakes rather than an indistinct own-label cereal packet on your weekly trawl round the supermarket? Would you sooner clothe yourself in Nike down the gym than some anonymous sports kit that doesn't carry that all-important swoosh? And what about your car? Is that a BMW, or VW Golf - or just any old thing that gets you from A to B?

I'm talking brands here, those clearly-labelled, highly-defined, sophisticated products that have somehow come to mean so much more than the mere packaging and stuff they are made of.

Brands are truly all around us. Today they can be anything from traditional FMCGs (marketing speak for "fast moving consumer goods" such as soap powder and baked beans) to major corporations, service companies, political parties and even people. Think Britney Spears, David Beckham and New Labour, as much as Virgin, Pepsi or BA.

Today the V&A in London is mounting a new show for three months called Brand.New, aimed specifically at scrutinising the role of brands in the early 21st century and decoding what they mean. The exhibition consists of a series of photographic case studies of global names such as Coca-Cola and Gap, lifting the lid on how these brands were established and looking at how we consumers relate to them.

But what exactly are brands? How can they be defined? What makes the difference, say, between one unmarked pair of perfectly nice, functional trainers and a pair of gleaming, box-fresh Nikes?

Robert Bean, chairman of leading brand consultants Banc, which has promoted such household names as the Body Shop and Covent Garden Soups, explains: "The principal difference between an ordinary product and a brand is the intangibles beyond the product itself. A brand goes beyond functionality, it is everything around that, how it is packaged, what it looks like, what colour it is - its personality, if you like. Put simply, product plus personality equals brand".

Not any old thing can achieve brand status: "Every great brand has an outstanding product feature at its heart," says Bean. Hence Rolex watches wouldn't be, well, Rolex watches if they didn't work rather well and look so fancy; Heinz Baked Beans wouldn't be Heinz if they didn't have a specially nice beany flavour and weren't consistently high quality. The same applies to Coca-Cola with its mystery ingredient, Rolls-Royce cars and any of the world's other leading power brands.

A product also needs time and to be promoted and communicated consistently to become a brand. Lord Leverhume at Unilever used to claim that repetition was the key to establishing a brand name: if you bang consumers over the head with the name again and again it will penetrate and they will get the message. While being a rather unsophisticated approach there is some truth to it.

"In a way BMW have done this very thing over the years, consistently positioning themselves in all their marketing communications as the ultimate driving machine. Now that's given consumers a very clear understanding of what they are about," says Bean.

But what really determines a brand is trust. This is why we consumers value them so highly and opt for known names and familiarly labelled goods over and above non-brands - because of the comfort element. They are, in effect, products with a "trustmark" rather than a mere "trademark".

Dr Nick Georgiades, an industrial psychologist who has worked with BA and helped BT devise the memorable "It's good to talk" advertising campaign, says: "If you see a brand as a trustmark it tells you that you have not been let down by it and that you can reduce anxiety by using it. Particularly today, in this crazy world of speed and noise and constant demands, we are all looking for a short-cut to anxiety reduction, so if you choose a trustmark you are reducing the possibility of new anxieties."

Georgiades explains that trust is "an historical concept" and we need "repeated interactions with associated good feelings" to build it; indeed, branding experts suggest it takes at least three years to establish this feeling of goodwill among consumers. But we don't need to have directly experienced something ourselves. Our mums, say, might have always used Nivea face cream and now enjoy an impressively wrinkle-free old age, hence we might plump for Nivea as a result.

Thus brands help us steer our way through the world. In a sea of consumer confusion, they are like a navigation point or a lighthouse, providing us with a sort of cultural map.

But perhaps the most important role of all for brands, is that they help us define who we are.

Peter York, the renowned style guru who runs his own brand consultancy SRU, says: "Community, church or regiment don't work any more as prescribed identities, but people like to identify themselves so they make some chains of their own by choosing particular brands. They now brand themselves, with greater or lesser degrees of subtlety. They even say things like 'I'm not sure if this is right for my personal branding'."

This "personal branding" might come in the shape of clothes and designer labels: by wearing Calvin Klein we are saying we are urban chic, for example, while Diesel suggests "cool and edgy". Similarly Country Casuals, Gap, and Dries van Noten all say quite different things about who we are or want to be.

"Cars and newspapers are particularly strong symbols or signals of what tribe we belong to and what we believe in - cars, whether they be sporty or functional or family, are a clear sign not least because most people know how much they cost so on a crude level they tell people how much money you've got," says Bean.

Interestingly, the V&A show includes a video installation of nine short films based around the stories of real people and their relationships with brands. One tells the tale of a taxi driver who has saved up for years to buy himself a Rolls-Royce; "I haven't got any style but the Roller has," he explains. Another features a man who is very loyal to just two brands: Marks & Spencer and Skoda. He proudly declares that he has had six Skodas in succession and that he buys all his clothes from M&S, suggesting that this makes him a somehow better, even more interesting person than those who don't.

Whatever happens next with brands probably depends on how deep manufacturers' pockets are. It takes time and money to build brands, but this particular marketing phenomenon is obviously here to stay.

York sums up: "Brands mean so much more than they did. The designer is the shaman of the 21st century - any bit that drops from him has a bit of magic about it. And the big, powerful, stretchy brands like Nike and Starbucks are also awash with promises and cultural meanings, suggesting that a little bit of their magic will rub off on you too if you use them."

webTitle: How much can you spend on...

fields.headline: How much can you spend on...
fields.standfirst: ... a pair of conkers
fields.trailText: ... a pair of conkers
fields.body:
Ah, the joys of autumn! One of the season's greatest pleasures is going out to collect conkers and returning home with your pockets stuffed full of them. But if you feel that scrabbling around in the mud is not really befitting after a certain age, then Boodle & Dunthorne has designed a marvellous alternative which will save you all the bother of collecting your own. The posh jeweller has gone "bonkers for conkers" and produced two very grown- up sets with very grown-up price tags to boot. They are available in silver and gold, priced at £90 and £100 respectively.

The Boodle & Dunthorne catalogue says that the conkers are"not very useful". In fact, they have a million and one uses - as napkin rings, as heavy pendants or as a luxury toy for your cat. And you could always use one as a pendulum to induce a trance-like state in your partner should he or she find the receipt. If this fails, you could always, at Boodle & Dunthorne's suggestion, "inflict pain".

fields.headline: Cybershopping
fields.standfirst: Board games
fields.trailText: Board games
fields.body:
Investing in a couple of indoor games is a sure way to make light of the long winter ahead. Whether you like to show off your general knowledge or manual dexterity, or to perform surgery in your living room, the internet offers a fantastic range of board games that can be gift wrapped and delivered to your home.

www.hasbro.co.uk has a huge range of games for families, adults and children. The old favourites are there, together with updated versions of classics, including variations of Monopoly - among them FA Premier Monopoly, in which football clubs become the Monopoly board properties, and a new European Monopoly, featuring all the countries of the European Union, to celebrate the launch of the euro. The site is bright and easy to navigate and includes an excellent "Daily Smile" page, offering a selection of fun articles and features aimed at children and parents.

If you see yourself as a budding Johnny Vaughan you'll probably like Vital Statistics from the Big Breakfast, at www.gibsongames.co.uk . The site is plain and lacks colour or fun visuals but is clearly set out and describes the games well.

However, if it's glamour and escapism you're after, it's worth checking out Cut&Run, a new board game, at www.CUTandRUN.com . The dark and smoky blue pages, complete with spinning dice, teach you the rules of the game, described as "more intellectually challenging than Cluedo" - which with luck will not deter those of us still scratching our heads over who did it in the conservatory with the lead piping.

The old favourites are there, together with updated versions of classics, including variations of Monopoly - among them FA Premier Monopoly, in which football clubs become the Monopoly board properties, and a new European Monopoly, featuring all the countries of the European Union, to celebrate the launch of the euro. The site is bright and easy to navigate and includes an excellent "Daily Smile" page, offering a selection of fun articles and features aimed at children and parents. If you see yourself as a budding Johnny Vaughan you'll probably like Vital Statistics from the Big Breakfast, at www.gibsongames.co.uk . The site is plain and lacks colour or fun visuals but is clearly set out and describes the games well. However, if it's glamour and escapism you're after, it's worth checking out Cut&Run, a new board game, at www.CUTandRUN.com . The dark and smoky blue pages, complete with spinning dice, teach you the rules of the game, described as "more intellectually challenging than Cluedo" - which with luck will not deter those of us still scratching our heads over who did it in the conservatory with the lead piping.

fields.headline: Fresh violence threatens peace accord
fields.trailText: Three Israeli gunships opened fire today during fresh clashes between Israelis and Palestinians near the West Bank city of Nablus. The violence threatened to undermine the US-brokered accord, erupting two days after a self-imposed deadline to end three weeks of  violence in which 107 people, most of them Palestinians, have been killed.
fields.body:
Three Israeli gunships opened fire today during fresh clashes between Israelis and Palestinians near the West Bank city of Nablus. The violence threatened to undermine the US-brokered accord, erupting two days after a self-imposed deadline to end three weeks of violence in which 107 people, most of them Palestinians, have been killed.

Witnesses said three helicopters hovering overhead fired their machine guns three times during a firefight between Israeli soldiers and Jewish settlers and Palestinian policemen and gunmen.

Jewish settlers and Palestinians exchanged fire on Mount Ebal, one of the hills cradling the northern West Bank hub of Nablus.

One Palestinian was killed and three were wounded, according to hospital officials. The Israeli army said two settlers were shot but there was no immediate indication of the severity of their injuries.

The settlers said Palestinians opened fire on a section of their group who were seeking to establish a lookout to monitor a Nablus holy site evacuated by the Israelis two weeks ago.

Palestinians said the settlers opened fire, unprompted, on unarmed olive harvesters.

Elsewhere, two Palestinian policemen died in an apparent gas explosion at the Bethlehem headquarters of the elite Force 17 unit of the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat.

However, a police spokesman said the explosion "was from our stores and has nothing to do with the clashes". A jeep in the police courtyard had its roof collapsed and windows blown out, and police evacuated both the wounded and ammunition.

After the explosion, youths and gunmen headed toward Rachel's tomb, an Israeli-held enclave inside Bethlehem that has been the scene of clashes in the past.

In other signs of friction, Palestinian stone-throwers clashed with Israeli soldiers, who responded with tear gas, in the northern Gaza Strip around noon.

In Hebron in the West Bank, similar clashes erupted after Palestinians found graffiti insulting the prophet Muhammad on walls near the Jewish enclave. No injuries were reported.

Following a Middle East summit mediated by the US president, Bill Clinton, earlier this week, Israeli and Palestinian security teams yesterday set a 48-hour deadline for the next phase of the agreement. This involves a two-week recovery period aimed at getting negotiators back to the table after the recent wave of violence.

The deadline was originally set for this evening, but security negotiators re-set the deadline for noon tomorrow.

Part of the ceasefire plan calls for measurable steps from both sides. These include a pullback of Israeli tanks from the edges of Palestinian towns, easing a ban on travel that is compounding an already battered Palestinian economy, and the re-arrest of dozens of militants set free during the fighting.

Saeb Erekat, a senior Palestinian official, said: ""Once the Israelis pull out their soldiers and tanks, once the Israelis stop firing, once the siege is lifted, I think this will help a great deal."

Israeli authorities today lifted the internal closure on Palestinian areas, which allowed Palestinians to resume travel between towns inside the West Bank and Gaza.

The Israelis opened border crossings to Egypt and Jordan, and goods again started to flow between Gaza and Israel. The Palestinians were allowed to reopen their airport in Gaza after a 10-day closure.

However, Israel has yet to lift a closure between Israel and the Palestinian areas, barring tens of thousands of Palestinians from their jobs, and the Palestinian economy from its principal sustenance.

For their part, the Palestinians have begun to re-arrest some of the Islamic militants freed at the zenith of the recent violence. The Palestinian leadership also issued "strict orders" to observe the truce.

Also, the two sides have held secret meetings between their security chiefs, chaired by the American CIA, aimed at restraining the Palestinian militias that have led the attacks on the Palestinian side.

Four Israeli army outposts came under fire overnight in Gaza, but no soldiers were injured, the army said this morning.

More than 100 people have died since the fighting began, the worst surge of violence since the two sides began regular peace negotiations in 1993.

The Israeli security minister, Shlomo Ben-Ami, speaking before today's clashes erupted, said that sporadic fighting was still a cause of concern.

"I don't see things calming down," he said on Israel Army radio. "I personally see something more serious happening in the Palestinian Authority which raises a major question mark. Is Arafat in control?"

webTitle: Mihajlovic: Vieira called me a 'gypsy shit'

fields.headline: Mihajlovic: Vieira called me a 'gypsy shit'
fields.trailText: Sinisa Mihajlovic has admitted racially abusing Patrick Vieira during Tuesday night's Champions League game between Lazio and Arsenal - but claims he only did it after Vieira called him a "gypsy shit".
fields.body:
Sinisa Mihajlovic has admitted racially abusing Patrick Vieira during Tuesday night's Champions League game between Lazio and Arsenal - but claims he only did it after Vieira called him a "gypsy shit".

Yesterday, the French international had accused Mihajovic of calling him a "black bastard" and a "fucking black monkey". He added: "You don't want to hear that on the pitch from another professional player."

But at a press conference at Lazio's Formello training ground, Yugoslav international Mihajlovic insisted he only acted after Vieira started taunting him. "I insulted Vieira, but only as an answer to his insults," he claimed. "He called me a gypsy shit, so I answered back with black shit. And because I am proud of being a gypsy and I wasn't offended, I don't think he can be offended because I said he was black.

"I did call him a black bastard, but I didn't call him a monkey. He doesn't look like a monkey, but if he did I would probably have called him that," he added.

"Vieira provoked me from the first minute and not for the first time in games that we have played. This time I gave him some back. I don't care what colour his skin his, nobody does that to me and treats me that way."

"The mistake I made, and the only thing I regret, is to have reacted at the end of the match when he swore and me and I grabbed him by the neck. But we were hot and anyone who has played knows that in that moment the adrelanin is still pumping: I am who I am and I would have reacted the same way even on the street.

Mihajovic, who in the past supported late Serbian war-lord Arkan, then went onto chastise Viera for revealing what was said on the pitch.

"I've played football since I was 15 years old and in that time I have received a lot of kicks, spits and insults. In football these things happen. What makes me angry is that off the pitch, back home, Vieira hosts a press conference to reveal incidents that occurred during the match and must be kept on the field.

"I accept my responsibilities, but if there are going to be any bans, I should not be the only one to pay. If I am a racist, so is Vieira."

Meanwhile, Lazio president Sergio Cragnotti has apologised for the behaviour of some of his supporters. "I am deeply concerned and disappointed in the racist attitude of a small minority of fans," he admitted in a statement.

But his sentiments were undermined when vice-president Dino Zoff revealed that Lazio had no plans to punish Mihajlovic for his behaviour. "What happened between Mihajlovic and Vieira consisted only of players going about their usual business," Zoff insisted.

fields.headline: Agreement to save My.MP3.com
fields.standfirst: September 7: MP3.com fined $250m for copyright infringement
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: MP3.com has struck a deal with the National Music Publishers' Association that should save its controversial My.MP3.com service, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Internet music firm MP3.com has struck a deal with trade group the National Music Publishers' Association and its licensing subsidiary, the Harry Fox Agency, that will effectively save its controversial My.MP3.com service.

If approved by shareholders, the landmark three-year licensing arrangement will allow MP3.com to use more than 1m tracks on the My.MP3.com service, which allows users to create their own jukebox on the MP3 site.

MP3.com has said it will pay up to $30m (£19.6m) to 25,000 music publishers to see the deal through. Under the royalty terms, MP3.com will pay a quarter of a cent each time a song is accessed and a one-off fee every time a user stores a track.

If approved, the licensing agreement will settle the lawsuit filed in March by the National Music Publishers' Association on behalf of the Harry Fox Agency.

Both sides believe the agreement could set a standard for copyright payments on the internet. Robin Richards, president and chief negotiator for MP3.com, saidL "Today the American public won."

MP3.com, which has settled lawsuits brought by four of the five major music labels, has yet to settle with Universal, the world's largest music label.

fields.headline: PR Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: October 20.
fields.trailText: October 20: Brunswick is to recruit media and investor relations staff as part of an expansion into new markets.
fields.body:
Brunswick is to recruit more than a dozen senior and junior media relations and investor relations staff as part of an expansion into new markets including Germany.

WH Smith is reviewing the structure of its corporate affairs department and may abolish the role of corporate affairs director.

Reebok has hired Cake as its sole retained UK agency, ending its 10-year relationship with Cohn & Wolfe.

The Maitland Consultancy has been appointed by troubled car manufacturer MG Rover to improve its public image.

BT has appointed Bite Communications to handle the PR for its 3G mobile phone licence.

Edelman PR has launched a £5m joint venture with e-business provider Ebeon to roll out interactive business division Edelman Interactive Solutions across Europe.

Brodeur Worldwide UK managing director Stan Woods is leaving at the end of the year to start his own branding consultancy.

Joe Public Relations has launched a standalone digital division called Joe Public Future.

PR Week's leader says it is time for the BBC to rethink its PR: "The BBC is eventually going to have to admit that it can't have its cake and eat it."

fields.headline: Media Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: October 20
fields.trailText: October 20: NTL has abandoned its plans for pay-per-view soccer.
fields.body:
Media Week splashes on the story that NTL has abandoned its plans for pay-per-view soccer.

Other stories are that film magazine Flicks is thought to be closing after running into financial difficulty.

The Billett Consultancy has poached Tony Squires from Pedigree Masterfoods to be its new team leader. Squires will oversee client relations.

And the City of Westminster is to launch a new advertising medium in the form of its lampposts. 40,000 lampposts will carry ads.

The magazine also carries an interview with Andrew Hirsch, the new chief executive of John Brown Contract Publishing, who believes customer titles are a threat as well as an opportunity to traditional publishers.

fields.headline: Broadcast round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: October 20.
fields.trailText: October 20: ITV's decision to cut the number of slots on Trafalgar Road has caused a rift with United Productions.
fields.body:
ITV's decision to cut the number of slots on its upcoming daily soap, Trafalgar Road, is reported to have caused a rift between the network and producer United Productions. United will still make enough episodes to air five times a week but Broadcast claims that some of these may be in jeopardy. Meanwhile, Trafalgar Road producer Matthew Bird has jumped ship to work at the BBC's new drama department under Jane Tranter.

Delayed Office of Fair Trading figures show that the BBC only just "scraped through" its independent production quota, with 25.8% of the corporation's output commissioned from independents, down from 29.2% the previous year. Broadcast says the figures throw into doubt the corporation's claims that it will be able to fulfil next year's quota.

BBC entertainment is to be given 28 Saturday night slots for 2001, evidence, Broadcast claims, of director general Greg Dyke's promise to boost in-house production.

Regional news chiefs have approached Nigel Dacre, editor of ITN news on ITV, with a plea to move the 6.30pm news back to 6pm.

The Big Breakfast has been given a stay of execution and will remain on Channel 4 throughout 2001. Former Big Brother producer Richard Hopkins has been recruited as a senior executive producer on the show.

New BBC1 controllerLorraine Heggessey has axed Lucky Dog-produced drama A Many Splintered Thing, starring Alan Davies, claiming the series has "run its course".

Independent producer Lion TV is thought to be planning a sale of around 10% of the company.

And Top of the Pops is to move from its Elstree Studios' production base.

fields.headline: Heggessey defends BBC news move
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: The new controller of BBC1 revealed today that she had taken an "active role" in bringing forward the launch of a 10pm bulletin. By Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Lorraine Heggessey, the new controller of BBC1, revealed today that she had taken an "active role" in the decision to bring forward the launch of a 10pm news bulletin.

As the cracks started to appear in the new BBC1 schedule - overnight ratings were the worst since Monday, with the Ten O'Clock News scraping 4.3m against football and Coronation Street on ITV - Ms Heggessey once again defended the move.

She acknowledged that "fixed points" in the schedule posed a challenge, but said: "I'd rather have the fixed point at 10pm than 9pm."

Ms Heggessey, who does not officially take up her position until November 1, suggested that a fourth weekly episode of EastEnders was some time away. "Every channel needs a well-established soap as often as it can get it," she told Jenni Murray on Radio 4's Women's Hour. But she stressed there were many logistical problems that had to be overcome.

She admitted that, in the past, the BBC had taken its "eye off the ball" and neglected its principal channel. "The BBC was focusing elsewhere, on establishing digital channels and getting online up and running, and people forgot that the main channel should be the priority."

Ms Heggessey promised that under her direction, BBC1 would make fewer docu-soaps and more hard-hitting drama. Because of the lack of investment, the channel had become too "samey", she added.

She described how she turned down the controller's job three years ago when it was first suggested to her because she was not ready for it . "I felt I hadn't had such a range of experience." The job went to Peter Salmon.

And she told how she did not subscribe to the macho culture of hard drinking. "I don't want to get pissed every night with the lads," she said.

fields.headline: TBWA launches Sharwood's TV push
fields.standfirst: TBWA scoops £2m BA portal
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: TBWA/London is encouraging adventurous cooking with a new campaign for Sharwood's Indian and Chinese foods, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
TBWA/London is encouraging British punters to be more adventurous in their cooking with a new campaign for Sharwood's Indian and Chinese foods.

The £4m national TV campaign, which breaks on October 23, uses voiceovers from Eartha Kitt and Malcolm McClaren to urge people to do something different with their food.

The first ad proclaims that you have from nine to five to be sensible and that dinner is the time to have fun, while the second points out that while you can't control the weather, you can control what you eat.

Jonathan Gatward, head of marketing at Sharwood's, said: "It's great to be able to move the 'Stir Up Some Passion' campaign onto TV and inspire people to be more adventurous in the kitchen."

Media was bought and planned by BBJ Media.

fields.headline: Ludwig van Beethoven
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the irascible genius with passion in his soul - and poison in his hair
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the irascible genius with passion in his soul - and poison in his hair
fields.body:
1. American scientists have come up with a rational explanation for the irrational behaviour of Ludwig van Beethoven.

2. He was mean, he was moody, and according to a minute study of his hair, he had around 100 times the level of lead in his system than would be normal in a person today. You could say that he was a heavy metal musician. That could well account for his depression, his occasional violence, his constant scowl, and his general irascibility. It could even account for his death. But not his deafness, which afflicted him so grievously.

3. Lead poisoning is not unknown in musicians. Curiously enough, it used to affect specialist players of glass instruments.

4. It took the researchers at the Argonne National Laboratory four years to come up with the lead finding, which is odd. They have no idea how it got to be there, though it could have been ingested by the great man in his frequent visits to health spas - an early example of the universal truth that fitness can be very bad for you.

5. The research may not have added hugely to the sum of human knowledge, but it is a truly awesome example of the range and depth of American science. In addition to the brains of Argonne, the work involved the Health Research Institute at Naperville, and the McCrone Insitute in Chicago (founder Walter J. McCrone). All are clearly formidable centres of learning.

6. William J. Walsh of Naperville, who directed the Beethoven project, is a great authority on the effects of minerals on human behaviour. He is particularly strong on hair, on zinc, and on publicity.

7. The strands of hair which yielded up our new insight into Beethoven's rather pitiful life were bought at auction for just under £5000 in 1994, by Ira F. Brilliant, of the Ira C. Brilliant Center for Beethoven Studies at the San Jose State University. Brilliant name. Super collection. Disappointing merchandise.

8. Mr Brilliant is one of the army of Beethoven worshippers. Another is John Suchet who, when not reading the ITN news, delivers learned lectures on the composer.

9. Beethoven is credited with 138 major works. He may have been deaf and poisoned, but he turned out some of the most sublime music ever penned.

10. Instead of worrying about his hair, you should be listening to his symphonies right now. Go in at the deep end with the wonderful Ninth.
fields.bodyText: 1. American scientists have come up with a rational explanation for the irrational behaviour of Ludwig van Beethoven. 2. He was mean, he was moody, and according to a minute study of his hair, he had around 100 times the level of lead in his system than would be normal in a person today. You could say that he was a heavy metal musician. That could well account for his depression, his occasional violence, his constant scowl, and his general irascibility. It could even account for his death. But not his deafness, which afflicted him so grievously. 3. Lead poisoning is not unknown in musicians. Curiously enough, it used to affect specialist players of glass instruments. 4. It took the researchers at the Argonne National Laboratory four years to come up with the lead finding, which is odd. They have no idea how it got to be there, though it could have been ingested by the great man in his frequent visits to health spas - an early example of the universal truth that fitness can be very bad for you. 5. The research may not have added hugely to the sum of human knowledge, but it is a truly awesome example of the range and depth of American science. In addition to the brains of Argonne, the work involved the Health Research Institute at Naperville, and the McCrone Insitute in Chicago (founder Walter J. McCrone). All are clearly formidable centres of learning. 6. William J. Walsh of Naperville, who directed the Beethoven project, is a great authority on the effects of minerals on human behaviour. He is particularly strong on hair, on zinc, and on publicity. 7. The strands of hair which yielded up our new insight into Beethoven's rather pitiful life were bought at auction for just under £5000 in 1994, by Ira F. Brilliant, of the Ira C. Brilliant Center for Beethoven Studies at the San Jose State University. Brilliant name. Super collection. Disappointing merchandise. 8. Mr Brilliant is one of the army of Beethoven worshippers. Another is John Suchet who, when not reading the ITN news, delivers learned lectures on the composer. 9. Beethoven is credited with 138 major works. He may have been deaf and poisoned, but he turned out some of the most sublime music ever penned. 10. Instead of worrying about his hair, you should be listening to his symphonies right now. Go in at the deep end with the wonderful Ninth.

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: Time to really kick racism out of football
fields.body:
Time to really kick racism out of football

Not surprisingly, the shocking racist abuse directed at Patrick Vieira by Sinisa Mihajlovic during the Champions League game between Lazio and Arsenal dominates our postbag.

"Well done Patrick Vieira," says Justin Kavanagh. "At long, long last, someone has the courage to stand up to the inane racism that plagues the game. By naming Mihajlovic, Viera has taken a brave stance where too many before him have shied away from controversy and conflict.

"But before English football congratulates itself for the Frenchman's outspokenness, let's remember that nowhere does the cancer of racism fester more deeply than in the country where Viera plies his trade," Justin continues.

"One of my worst memories of supporting the Republic of Ireland, was in a bar in Dublin prior to the Landsdown Road riot, where several of Chelsea's finest beer bellies were loudly declaiming Paul Ince's captaincy of their national team on the grounds that 'no fucking monkey nigger should be captain of Ing-er-land'.

"I have often wondered how such morons would respond if black, Irish, French, or whatever race of footballer being abused, simply downed tools and walked off. Unprofessional? I don't think so. How many other European workers would be expected to carry on in the face of the kind of insults that Patrick Viera was subjected to?"

Meanwhile, Azahy is disappointed with the Guardian's coverage of the Mihajlovic affair. "How come you carry a long analysis of the shortcomings of managers when faced with erring players, yet you only make passing reference to Viera's 'claimed' racial abuse?" he asks.

"Aren't you a newspaper justly celebrated for its abhorrence of racism? Or is it a different thing to dare to actually identify an undercurrent of colour prejudice in another culture - a culture that is no stranger to systematic annihilation of people and ideas?

"Instead of lambasting the imaginary army of little Englanders, with their myopia and beer-bellies, I think you should recognise the intensity and ubiquity of the racial abuse evident among the supporters of Lazio and Galatasaray and comment on it."

Roy Collins: the new Richard Williams?

Many of you are unhappy about Roy Collins' article on myopic English managers.

"My word, the work experience boy from the sixth form has been let loose," reckons Ed Crick.

"Sure, Wenger turns a blind one from time to time but Eriksson didn't see that incident either. This is because they were at the match and not watching the highlights on ITV while listening to Pulp. Only with the benefit of a close up was it clear that Grimandi did give that racist thug a touch of his own medicine."

And Chris Purdon agrees. "What an absolute bag of crap some of your sports journalists write," he says. "Please, please, can we receive some non- partisan journalistic reporting instead of the totally subjective shite such as the article about Wenger's eyesight. Does this particular journalist perhaps sport a tattoo on his behind declaring his undying love for Sol Campbell and all things Spurs, or perhaps his bedroom is bedecked in posters of Luca and Ruud?"

World views

Football Unlimited's eclectic postbag has also been enriched from emails across the world today. First off is J Boakai G Russell, who is unhappy with how George Weah was treated by Manchester City.

"There is an African football proverb that states: 'expertise does not fight for jersey'," he says. "George Weah is God's gift to football, and the only player in the world to be named king apart from Pele. His record has shown that every team he has played for has won championship.

"If Manchester City don't want the championship they can keep the coach and not deliver. I can bet anything Weah's new team will win the championship because he is just a winner," he continues, forgetting to mention anything about Weah's time at Chelsea.

Meanwhile, Catagay Arslan is disappointed with the Guardian's Besiktas v Leeds match report. "As a supporter of Besiktas but also as a lover of England, I am ashamed of your match report," he writes. "Your neglect of the poor standard of refereeing is unbelievable. If such a guy had shown such a direction in any area in England I don't think you would have shown such a tolerance to him."

"I always trust Guardian. Whenever I find a copy of it, I buy it in Turkey. But from now on I will start to think about going somewhere else."

And on a lighter note...

"Why doesn't Harry Redknapp sign up Stan Collymore?" asks West Ham fan Richard Smith. And he's not joking either. "When he is playing well he is one of the best goal-scorers in England, and he will be going cheap," he continues, without a hint of sarcasm.

"Also, Redknapp is also is very good at handling troubled footballers. West Ham need somebody who can score goals regularly. Suker should be transfer listed as he is never fit to play for the club, while Kanoute - while being class - is not an out and out goalscorer, which is where Stan the man would fit in perfectly."

Peter Taylor and Harry Redknapp are you listening?

fields.headline: Miklos Jancso: The Round-Up
fields.standfirst: Derek Malcolm's 100 greatest movies. This week, number 88: Miklos Jancso's The Round-Up
fields.trailText: The film is so precisely choreographed that the patterns play on the mind until they become clear and obvious in their meanings. The camera style is beautiful but almost merciless. If the film can be criticised for its lack of emotion, it can't be for its absence of power or for its cold appreciation of the situation it illustrates
fields.body:
Those who have never seen a film by Miklos Jancso from the 1960s, when this Hungarian director was at his peak, are usually astonished by the experience. When The Round-Up, his third film, came to London in 1965, the broadsheet critics almost dropped their pens in surprise. Here was a deeply serious, decidedly uncamp and certainly not musically-minded middle European Busby Berkeley, who made formal patterns on the screen with humans and horses in order to illustrate the betrayals of his country's history. I joke, but not much. To watch The Round-Up or 1967's The Red and the White for the first time is to witness a kind of film ballet entering the realms of political drama.

In The Round-Up, Austrian soldiers representing the triumphant Hapsburg empire trap and interrogate the Hungarian partisans whose revolt against the empire's rule has petered out. The period is the mid-19th century and only the legendary Sandor Rosza's fighters stand in the way, succoured by the peasants. The drama is virtually divested of characters we can either sympathise with or hate. Instead, it deals largely in formal, abstract generalities. It is as if Jancso is merely watching, regretfully conscious that there are those who will be killed and those whose job it is to kill them. A man running on the horizon is calmly shot down. Another is taken away to be tortured. Short words of command seem to be the apotheosis of dialogue. The film achieves, in one critic's accurate view, "a total absorption of content into form".

All this takes place on a very particular landscape: the vast, summer-scorched Hungarian plains where whitewashed buildings, cloaked men and their horses appear to be the only occupants. It seems like a world apart, but one able to illustrate both a specific vision of Hungarian history and part of the story of mankind, where the powerful slowly but surely triumph over the weak.

The film is so precisely choreographed that the patterns play on the mind until they become clear and obvious in their meanings. The camera style is beautiful but almost merciless. If the film can be criticised for its lack of emotion, it can't be for its absence of power or for its cold appreciation of the situation it illustrates.

Later, with films such as The Confrontation and Red Psalm, Jancso's work begins to lose something through familiarity, and his obsession with half-naked girls and patterns becomes enervating. When he left Hungary for Italy in the 1970s, making erotic films such as Private Vices and Public Virtues (based on the Mayerling story), it seemed he had little more of value to say, or no way of saying it without repeating himself or exaggerating his weaknesses.

But the first few films were astonishing, whether dealing with Kossuth's rebels of the 1860s or the aftermath of the 1919 Hungarian revolution. They bitterly analysed the history of his persecuted country and commented, too, on the nature of violence in more general terms. No one has tried quite the same thing in the same way, and that is his most formidable legacy.
