webTitle: Cable & Wireless consolidate entire global PR account

fields.headline: Cable & Wireless moves global PR business to Brodeur Worldwide
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Cable & Wireless switches global PR account to Brodeur Worldwide, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Telecoms company Cable & Wireless has consolidated its entire global PR account into the Omnicom-owned Brodeur Worldwide following a review.

The decision follows the reorganisation of Cable & Wireless in May into a single global company, Cable & Wireless Global. Before the appointment of Brodeur, C&W used a number of different PR agencies around the world, including Company Care Communications, LBA, CloverLeaf Communications and Catalysis in the UK.

Brodeur Worldwide is part of Omnicom's Diversified Agency Services division. Its clients include IBM, Novell and Fidelity Investments.

webTitle: Media Edge lands energy efficiency drive

fields.headline: Media Edge lands energy efficiency drive
fields.trailText: 8am: The government has hired the Media Edge to handle media planning and buying for its new energy efficiency advertising campaign, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The government has hired the Media Edge to handle media planning and buying for its new energy efficiency advertising campaign.

The £3m campaign was created by Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R and launches on October 23 to coincide with Energy Efficiency Week.

Its focus will be national TV ads, although there will also be a week-long promotion on five GWR stations and internet ads.

Stuart Sullivan, a strategist at the Media Edge, said: "I believe the combined application of our own and Energy Efficiency's research will help us achieve a more focused, accurately targeted and well-balanced mix of media planning and buying for our client."

fields.headline: Tories 'lurch to right' over euro
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The Tories were last night accused of embarking on a fresh lurch to the right after a new survey claimed that nearly half of the party's candidates in target seats for the next general election took a harder stance on the euro than the party leadership.
fields.body:
The Tories were last night accused of embarking on a fresh lurch to the right after a new survey claimed that nearly half of the party's candidates in target seats for the next general election took a harder stance on the euro than the party leadership.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, hailed the survey as "clear evidence" that the Tories were intent on moving to the right after the election.

Mr Cook said: "As Michael Heseltine has warned, the 'Britain out brigade', is taking over the Tory party. If elected, the Tories would pose a very real threat to our membership of the EU."

His remarks came after the Eurosceptic European Journal published a survey which claimed that 46% of Tory candidates in target seats were opposed to the euro in principle and would defy the leadership if asked to support the single currency. William Hague, the party leader, wants to rule out British membership of the euro for the lifetime of the next parliament, leaving his options open for the election after next.

The findings were based on figures compiled by the Eurosceptic Candidlist website which aims to "out" pro-Europeans and to highlight the credentials of anti-Europeans.

However, the European Journal survey appeared to fall apart last night after it emerged that Mr Hague had been categorised as a "sceptic" on the Candidlist website. This would place him at odds with his own policy.

The survey was further undermined when it emerged that Danny Finkelstein, head of the Tory policy unit, who helped to formulate Mr Hague's euro policy, and George Osborne, another Hague aide, were also listed as a "sceptic".

Senior Tories last night welcomed the embarrassing blow to the Candidlist website, which they have found a nuisance. One candidate said: "Candidlist makes assertions about candidates without speaking to people. If they sent a questionnaire I would not reply because his criteria are questionable."

The disclosures undermined the entire survey by the European Journal which claimed that the vast majority of Tory candidates were strongly opposed to the euro. The magazine claimed that a mere 6.5% of candidates in marginal seats were pro-Europeans. Nearly half (47.5%) supported the leadership, with 46% labelled as "sceptics" who opposed the currency in principle.

The poor research by the European Journal will come as a blow to Eurosceptics attempting to put pressure on Mr Hague to harden his opposition to the single currency.

However, there is still strong evidence that pro-European Tories are struggling to win selections in safe or marginal seats.

webTitle: Boost for Brown as splits emerge in road tax lobby

fields.headline: Boost for Brown as splits emerge in road tax lobby
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Pressure on Gordon Brown to cut fuel duty for hauliers later this month will intensify today when the National Farmers' Union and the Freight Transport Association demand a 15p cut in diesel duty for the industry. They will also call for a small reduction in road tax for the general motorist.
fields.body:
Pressure on Gordon Brown to cut fuel duty for hauliers later this month will intensify today when the National Farmers' Union and the Freight Transport Association demand a 15p cut in diesel duty for the industry. They will also call for a small reduction in road tax for the general motorist.

However, the chancellor's room for manoeuvre in his pre-Budget report has been increased by growing divisions within the haulage lobby.

The FTA is furious that the CBI and Society of Motor Manufacturers have pulled out of plans to be part of the submission. The idea of an industry-wide demand covering the four organisations had originally been tabled by the CBI's director general, Digby Jones. But big oil companies in the CBI opposed the move, believing that it would put undue pressure on the government.

Lord MacDonald, the transport minister, will today meet the Fuel Forum, which brings together leaders of last month's petrol protest and the Road Haulage Association. The fuel protesters have threatened to try to paralyse the country again on November 13 unless their demands for a general cut in fuel duty are met.

Tensions are high. David Handley, chairman of the "people's fuel" lobby, was arrested during a protest in a meat plant in Wales on Sunday night.

Although Lord MacDonald will sound sympathetic at today's meeting, he has decided to rebut many of the claims of the haulage industry, pointing out that it is suffering 20% overcapacity, leading to tight profit margins. He will ask whether a solution would lie in imposing higher entry costs into the industry, and by clamping down on "cowboy" foreign operators.

But in an eight page letter to the industry, he denies the widespread impression that hauliers are suffering historically high levels of bankruptices. He points out that there were only 1,131 bankruptcies last year against 1,775 in 1993.

He does concede that fuel duty is lower on the continent, but says that is because mainland Europe pays higher income tax.

Lord MacDonald also denies that foreign competition is beginning to make serious inroads into the British-owned haulage industry. He writes: "Foreign vehicles continue to represent a very small proportion of overall freight traffic within the UK. Most foreign vehicles are engaged in international journeys, rather than performing cabotage (national transport carried out by foreign operators).

"The amount of cabotage undertaken in the UK by foreign hauliers represents just 0.06% of domestic transport." Germany, he says, suffers far more cabotage than Britain.

He acknowledges that before travelling in Britain foreign-based hauliers can load up with 1,500 litres of diesel at far cheaper rates in Europe. But he says it would be illegal under EU law for the UK to apply a lower duty-free fuel limit to foreign lorries entering the country.

In the letter, he warns the oil companies not to profiteer: "It is regrettable that oil companies appear to be charging higher wholesale prices to some customers so soon after the fuel blockades have been lifted, and the director general of fair trading has written to the oil companies about this."

He points out that there were only 1,131 bankruptcies last year against 1,775 in 1993. He does concede that fuel duty is lower on the continent, but says that is because mainland Europe pays higher income tax. Lord MacDonald also denies that foreign competition is beginning to make serious inroads into the British-owned haulage industry. He writes: "Foreign vehicles continue to represent a very small proportion of overall freight traffic within the UK. Most foreign vehicles are engaged in international journeys, rather than performing cabotage (national transport carried out by foreign operators). But he says it would be illegal under EU law for the UK to apply a lower duty-free fuel limit to foreign lorries entering the country. In the letter, he warns the oil companies not to profiteer: "It is regrettable that oil companies appear to be charging higher wholesale prices to some customers so soon after the fuel blockades have been lifted, and the director general of fair trading has written to the oil companies about this."

webTitle: Americans spend a scary amount on Halloween

fields.headline: Americans spend a scary amount on Halloween
fields.standfirst:
Gourd blimey! The amount of cash flung at fun and fripperies in the US seems to follow a feeling of sweet economic certainty, writes Jane Martinson in New York
The Halloween Association
fields.trailText: Gourd blimey! The amount of cash flung at fun and fripperies in the US seems to follow a feeling of sweet economic certainty in the US, writes Jane Martinson in New York.
fields.body:
Rising oil prices may be prompting fears of a fuel shortage on the north-east coast of America, but long, blonde wigs and pumpkins are really flying out of the shops.

Halloween is huge in America and this year is expected to be bigger than most. The statistics themselves are scary.

The average American adult is expected to spend $43 (£30) on celebrating October 31, making Halloween the second biggest holiday after Christmas in terms of dollars spent, according to the International Mass Retail Association, a trade body.

Most of the money (an estimated $1.9bn in total) will be spent on sweets. Seven out of 10 Americans said they would be handing out treats to ward off tricks in a survey carried out by American Demographics last year. So great is the demand for such ransom that one quarter of all confectionery bought in the US is purchased in the two months running up to November 10.

An estimated $1.5bn is also expected to be spent on costumes. The association does not break this figure down into regions, but New York City must contribute more than its fair share. The annual Greenwich Village parade attracts thousands of participants as well as onlookers wearing fancy dress. Last year featured men dressed as the queen from Star Wars or Dr Evil. Charlie's Angels are expected to be big this year, thus the run on wigs for all those Farrah lookalikes.

The rest of the country also likes to dress up for Halloween. According to the International Retail Marketing Association, between 40 and 60% of all adults between the age of 18 and 44 said they intended to dress up in 1998. Eight per cent of them said they intended to dress their pets.

The four-year-old Halloween Association, a sort of trade body for hobgoblins, has estimated that about $6bn will be spent on the festivities this year, up from $5bnn last year. On top of sweets and costumes are decorations, entertaining and greeting cards. Hallmark Cards says it sells about 23-26m Halloween cards each year. The company offers 250 different types of pumpkin-decorated cards, including 40 that are animated.

Drive out of Manhattan and pumpkins really are the only fruit. Shops, restaurants and homes have displays that would put an Oxford Street window to shame. One huge, detached house in Long Island has created a sort of high altar with gossamer butterflies and such a glut of gourds that the occupants could live off pumpkin soup until next year.

Mary Helen Sprecher, spokeswoman for the Halloween Association, said demand for motion-activated decorations, fake gravestones and heads that scream in the night had really taken off in the last few years. "Some of these decorations are worthy of professionals," she said.

Like most spectacles in prosperous, turn-of-the-century America, the chief cause of the increasingly exuberant nature of Halloween is the baby-boomer generation born after 1945. Adults who remember more abstemious affairs consisting of dressing up in their parents' old clothes and asking for sweets, now want to create a fairy grotto in their suburban gardens complete with special effects.

This fascination with Halloween, based as it is on ancient pagan rituals, comes as a surprise given America's puritanical history. Admittedly, most of the ostentatious displays of celebration are found on the west and northeast coasts of America. The southern and mid-western states - more conservative and religious and poorer - spend a lot less than the national average on fripperies such as pumpkin-shaped candles and electronic ghouls, according to the Halloween Association.

The celebration of harvest at around this time of year also seems such an exuberant thing in America compared with the tins of Heinz spaghetti hoops that sum up the British experience.

The sense of bounty partly follows the sense of economic certainty. Acts of vandalism and fears of candy tampering that became a real fear on the east coast during the early 70s have receded in recent years as local communities have organised more and more parties and parades.

Some people have started to watch the skidding share prices for signs that the party may be coming to an end. But until then, few Americans will be looking to pour cold water on the bonfires of Halloween.

webTitle: Prison chief admits raid yielded little contraband

fields.headline: Prison chief admits raid yielded little contraband
fields.standfirst: Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: The prison service's director-general admitted yesterday that a controversial night raid on a "model" liberal jail in May failed to find the contraband that had been expected.
fields.body:
The prison service's director-general admitted yesterday that a controversial night raid on a "model" liberal jail in May failed to find the contraband that had been expected.

In a spat between Martin Narey and MPs on the Commons home affairs committee, it was admitted that the 84 officers who searched Blantyre House resettlement prison, in Kent, had found little more than a small amount of cannabis, three ecstasy tablets, and some pornography.

Mr Narey had told MPs that "a frightening amount of contraband" and large sums of money had been seized. He said yesterday that the money amounted to £370, £120 of which belonged to the prison chaplain.

All 118 prisoners were drug tested and none had proved positive. The raid followed claims that the prison had fallen foul of a faction who believed its regime was too soft. The prison is one of only three resettlement jails in England and Wales where inmates are allowed out each day to work and has a reoffending rate of just 8%.

At one stage, Robin Corbett, the Labour MP chairing the committee, told Mr Narey that his explanation as to why he had moved Eoin McLennan-Murray, the prison governor, the day before the raid, was "totally unconvincing".

MPs on the committee accused the prison service of mounting an "SAS-style raid" during which they had smashed down doors.

But John Podmore, the operational commander, denied that that the officers were in riot gear. He said the only doors which had been broken down were those for which keys were not available.

Earlier, MPs heard Sir David Ramsbotham, chief inspector of prisons, say he believed the raid was more about finding evidence to use against the prison's departing governor than to find contraband. The MPs were told that there was "a tense relationship" between Tom Murtagh, the area manager, and Mr McLennan-Murray.

fields.headline: A taste for toxins
fields.standfirst: Some little creatures will eat just about anything. Which is handy for the genetic engineers who want to clean up polluted land, writes  Claire Cockcroft
fields.trailText: Some little creatures will eat just about anything. Which is handy for the genetic engineers who want to clean up polluted land, writes Claire Cockcroft
fields.body:
Genetically engineered bugs and plants with an appetite for toxic waste are part of today's arsenal for purging the planet of man-made pollution - a process called bioremediation.

Barren wastelands, once home to industrial processing plants, are a blot on the landscape. However, these "brownfield" sites could be cleaned in a cost-effective, environmentally-friendly way for commercial re-development.

Left to its own devices, nature eventually disposes of organic matter, but it takes time.

Bioremediation takes advantage of the natural ability of living things to remove hazards that threaten human and animal health. Genes are borrowed and engineered into plants or microbes to make them super-efficient at degrading pollution, "fast-forwarding" a natural evolutionary process that would normally take years. Once a pollutant appears, the local microbial community tries to tackle this potential source of energy.

To find contamination-consumers, scientists collect soil from polluted plots, isolate bacteria which have have adapted to the environment and feed them with contaminants common to the site.

"Selective enrichments" ensure that only those able to metabolise pollution are isolated. Genes encoding the relevant metabolic enzymes can be cloned and engineered into more suitable bacteria for optimal digestion. For a career in waste-digestion, a microbe must rapidly and completely digest organic waste without producing offensive odours or noxious gas, reproduce in hostile conditions and be non-pathogenic.

Chlorinated solvents are troublesome contaminants and a headache for environmental protection agencies. These dense chemicals sink through the soil into groundwater supplies, spreading plumes of pollution over wide areas.

Trichloroethane (TCE) and perchloroethane (PCE), which has four chlorine groups attached to it, are notorious environmental offenders. These highly toxic and potentially carcinogenic compounds are used in many industrial processes, including dry cleaning, and are widespread in the environment.

Researchers at Cornell University discovered an anaerobic bacterium, known as Strain 195, that neutralises nasty chlorinated compounds into a harmless molecule called ethene. Hydrogen gas, produced by fermented organic matter, provides the electrons needed to break the carbon-chlorine bonds.

Sadly, Strain 195 does not thrive in soil but cloning de-chlorinating genes facilitates their transfer to bacteria better accustomed to toxic territories.

Chlorinated pesticides, like DDT, also lurk in the environment. Their by-products were previously thought indestructible but scientists at AstraZeneca in Canada have discovered a recipe of unusual ingredients for removing these persistent pollutants: old newspaper, straw and wood chips, chicken and cow manure and local soil bacteria that gorge themselves on organic waste, digesting it into carbon dioxide and water.

C ontaminated soil is mixed with large amounts of the waste making an enormous compost heap which is tilled and aerated every few weeks. The microscopic chemists convert pesticides and their by-products into less toxic end-products using bacterial enzymes called dehalogenases that chop off the chlorine groups.

Soil levels of DDT fell by 95% during a year-long test at an old pesticide factory in Tampa, Florida.

The rise of nuclear power has generated thousands of radioactive waste sites. Soil and groundwater are contaminated with toxic solvents, radionuclides such as caesium, plutonium, strontium and uranium, and heavy metals including chromium, lead and mercury. Cleansing these sites in the US by conventional methods is dangerous, labour-intensive and estimated to cost $250bn over 70 years.

Although bacteria can deal with diverse pollutants, radiation damages their DNA. But Deinococcus radiodurans, first found in meat tins during radiation sterilisation experiments in the 1950s, can withstanding radiation thousands of times stronger than the lethal dose for humans. To diversify Deinococcus's diet, scientists have engineered it with genes borrowed from Pseudomonas putida, a bacterium which uses organic solvents as a carbon source. With an improved genetic vocabulary, Deinococcus degrades toluene under radiation levels characteristic of contaminated sites. This radiation-resistant bug could be engineered to guzzle other organic pollutants or immobilise heavy metals.

Plants with a penchant for radioactive metals have been found around Chernobyl. These "hyperaccumulators" store metals in more harmless complexes in vacuoles - special subcellular compartments. Uranium-absorbing sunflowers are being field-tested at a Department of Energy facility in Ohio.

Solvent spills could also been tackled by plants. Tests in Oregon showed that poplars could remove 97% of TCE applied during watering, either storing it in a safer form or metabolising it. Plants can be engineered with bacterial genes for converting chemicals into safer compounds, providing a renewable, solar-driven means of cleaning contaminated sites. The environment agency estimates there are around 150,000 brownfield sites in the UK comprising over 300,000 hectares of affected land.

Recent government targets demand that 60% of all new houses should be built on these sites, leaving "greenfield sites" free from urban sprawl. Bioremediation is an evironmentally-attractive and economical alternative to energy-intensive incineration methods or chemical-based soil washing processes which destroy soil structure and concomitantly release other chemicals into the environment. It is a sustainable, and more permanent path towards a cleaner, greener environment.

 Dr Claire Cockcroft is a molecular biologist at the Institute of Biochemistry, Cambridge.

fields.headline: Iraq-Bin Laden boat bomb link
fields.standfirst:
USS Cole: 17 dead mourned as experts piece together attack

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Investigators in Yemen yesterday uncovered evidence suggesting the bomb attack on the warship USS Cole had been a meticulously organised conspiracy, which a leading US terrorism expert said may have been the first joint operation between Osama bin Laden and Saddam Hussein.
fields.body:
Investigators in Yemen yesterday uncovered evidence suggesting the bomb attack on the warship USS Cole had been a meticulously organised conspiracy, which a leading US terrorism expert said may have been the first joint operation between Osama bin Laden and Saddam Hussein.

Under an overcast sky at the Norfolk naval base in Virginia, President Clinton led thousands of US servicemen in mourning the 17 victims of last week's blast, as the state department warned that more attacks against US citizens could be on the way in the Middle East or Turkey.

In Aden, Yemeni police and FBI agents were examining a flat apparently rented by the bomb makers four days before the attack. Bomb-making materials were found in the flat, which was rented by two non-Yemeni Arabs, at least one of whom had a Gulf accent, local residents said. They kept a fibre glass boat parked nearby.

It was not clear whether the missing suspects were the two men who manoeuvred their small boat alongside the USS Cole and blew themselves up, or whether they were technicians spirited out of the country after the attack.

Paying tribute to the Cole victims, Mr Clinton said: "To those who attacked them we say: You will not find a safe harbour. We will find you and justice will prevail. America will not stop standing guard for peace, for freedom or stability in the Middle East or around the world."

Vincent Cannistraro, the CIA's former head of counter-terrorist operations and a respected expert on Middle Eastern terrorism, said the timing, location and method of the attack pointed to Bin Laden's terrorist network, al-Qaeda. He said it was the only group in the area which has issued a fatwa (a religiously inspired death sentence) against US and British citizens.

Bin Laden, a Saudi national based in Afghanistan, has Yemeni family roots and close links with some of the local tribal warlords. A few weeks before the attack, he distributed a video in which he issued familiar calls for a holy war against the "forces of evil". He was wearing Yemeni tribal costume and a Yemeni dagger.

"He's puckish like that. On one hand he does not want to give out his address, but on the other hand, he likes to let his followers know he is leading the fight," Mr Cannistraro said.

He argued that the sophistication of the bomb - an estimated 272kg of high explosive shaped and placed within a metal container to channel the blast and penetrate the armoured hull of the USS Cole - suggested the involvement of a state.

"The Iraqis have wanted to be able to carry out terrorism for some time now," Mr Cannistraro said. "Their military people have had liaison with al-Qaeda in Afghanistan, and could well have supplied the training."

He said the theory was still speculative but was consistent with the series of recent contacts between Baghdad and the Bin Laden organisation.

Harvey Kushner, a terrorism expert at Long Island University, said there was reason to believe Bin Laden had been investigating ways of launching attacks by sea. "He's been looking around for small, personal submarines. One of his relatives in the United States had an order in for one of these personal submarines, and it was stopped," Mr Kushner said.

Other terrorism experts agreed the boat bomb was a significant technical advance on earlier terrorist attacks, such as the bombing of the US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania two years ago.

The bodies of six of the US sailors killed in the blast were still being extracted from the wreckage left by the blast, which punched a 12-metre hole in the ship.

Investigators in Aden were studying video surveillance tapes of the port from the hours leading up to the attack.

webTitle: Middle East: a letter to President Clinton

fields.headline: Dear Mr President...
fields.standfirst: It is January 2001 and the US presidential inquiry into  violence in the Middle East  has finally issued its report. Middle East editor Brian Whitaker imagines what it might say
fields.trailText: It is January 2001 and the US presidential inquiry into violence in the Middle East has finally issued its report. Middle East editor Brian Whitaker imagines what it might say.
fields.body:
January 1 2001

Mr President,

You appointed us to carry out this inquiry under the terms of a summit meeting held at Sharm el-Sheikh last October. As you explained during our private briefing in the Oval Office, the summit meeting had two main purposes.

One was, as you put it, "to keep a lid" on the violence until November 7, in order to minimise collateral damage to Mr Gore's presidential campaign. The other was to pre-empt and frustrate the Arab summit (which was due to be held this weekend) and so ensure, as you put it, that the United States "would remain in the driving seat" of the peace process.

In order to secure these goals, you reluctantly accepted Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat's request for an inquiry into the disturbances but you felt, as you explained at our briefing, that it would be unhelpful if our inquiry were to apportion blame for specific acts of violence.

We have therefore refrained from that, concentrating our investigations instead on the underlying causes of the violence, and we find that you, Mr President, through your mishandling of the peace process, are the person mainly responsible.

Last March you blundered into a meeting with the late President Assad of Syria, arrogantly believing you could talk him into a peace deal with Israel.

President Assad met you because he had been led to expect an offer over Galilee, which was not, in fact, forthcoming. That meeting was ill-prepared, and it failed.

As a result, the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, withdrew Israeli forces from southern Lebanon, hoping to weaken Syria's future bargaining position. In our view, this has also contributed to subsequent violence, and Mr Barak must carry some responsibility.

By withdrawing unilaterally, outside the framework of a comprehensive settlement with Syria and Lebanon, Mr Barak gave the Hizbullah guerrillas an opportunity to claim victory. This raised a question in many Arab minds as to whether Hizbullah's methods might not be more effective than the peace process as a means towards achieving Palestinian goals.

Secondly, the withdrawal marked Israel's full compliance with UN resolutions on Lebanon. This led many Arabs to ask why, if the Israelis were able to comply with those resolutions, they could not comply with other resolutions about Palestine. So far, Mr Barak has not provided a satisfactory answer.

The Israeli withdrawal thus produced a hardening of attitudes among Arabs and provided a rationale for alternative "violent" approaches in the event that the peace process became stalled.

We turn now to the Camp David summit, which you called last July. The timing of this was little short of disastrous. Mr Barak arrived with his coalition government battered from inside and outside, and barely clinging on to office.

He was in no position to make real concessions. Mr Arafat, too, knew that concessions on the Palestinian side would leave him fatally wounded. Despite these appearances, many people imagined that after months of informal talks you must have had a secret plan which would reconcile the parties at Camp David. But you had none.

Perhaps you imagined that your personal charms, which worked so well on Monica Lewinsky, would also work on Messrs Arafat and Barak. But they didn't. Your achievement at Camp David was to stir up the worst fears on both sides about their respective leaders, leaving both Mr Barak and Mr Arafat at the mercy of their own rejectionists.

After Camp David it was only a matter of time until something triggered violence. Since then, in an effort to solve a problem of your own making, you have been pressuring the "moderate" Arab states (Egypt and Jordan in particular) into lending their weight to revive the peace process.

You may suppose, Mr President, that since these countries are not real democracies, their leaders can safely ignore public opinion. That is not so.

Ordinary Arabs are furious about the recent turn of events - as witnessed by the riots and demonstrations. The more you bully their leaders into supporting the discredited peace process, the more you risk widening the conflict by destabilising those Arab governments on which you depend.

We recognise that your efforts have been driven by a personal ambition to achieve a settlement in the Middle East during your presidency - what has become known as your "legacy project".

But this, we believe, is the cause of your undoing. Your real legacy is to leave the Middle East more unstable now than it was when you came into office.

Finally, Mr President, we commend to you our report and, along with everyone in the Middle East, take this opportunity to congratulate you on your forthcoming retirement.

webTitle: Murdoch says Vivendi has put float in doubt

fields.headline: Murdoch says Vivendi has put float in doubt
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Rupert Murdoch, chairman of the News Corporation, has blamed arch-rival Vivendi for delaying the proposed stock market listing of the media group's satellite assets.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch, chairman of the News Corporation, has blamed arch-rival Vivendi for delaying the proposed stock market listing of the media group's satellite assets.

In a meeting with investors in Adelaide, Mr Murdoch said that the uncertainty over Vivendi's 22.7% stake in BSkyB, the UK satellite operation, had put back the proposed listing of Sky Global Networks by weeks.

Shares in News Corp, which is based in Australia, fell almost 8% to A$19.95 yesterday amid increased fears that the group would not be able to accomplish its proposed listing because of the turbulent market conditions.

Mr Murdoch also fielded questions about the allocation to him of 24m options in the company's shares, worth some $35m.

Shareholders pointed out that, as the owner of some 30% of the group's voting shares, the Murdoch family needed little encouragement to invest further.

Stock options are typically awarded to retain key executives and analysts pointed out that no other media company is likely to try to poach Mr Murdoch or his sons. Lachlan Murdoch, his eldest son, also received stock options worth $9m as a result of the new in centive plan. A company spokesman said that the family had not before received share options.

News Corp also pointed to some uncertainty in its earnings outlook for 2000-01, with its United States television stations at risk in a weakening market after a strong start to the year. Rupert Murdoch also declined to make any firm predictions about the group's volatile film business after blaming "a couple of stinking films" for much of last year's net profit fall to $794m from $917m.

The often tempestuous relationship between Mr Murdoch and Jean-Marie Messier, the head of Vivendi Universal, appears to have reached a new low this week following Mr Messier's decision to jettison his stake in BSkyB to win regulatory approval for his merger with Seagram of Canada.

According to Australian news reports, Mr Murdoch said this decision had "been a factor in slowing" the proposed flotation.

He added that "my friend Mr Messier" was likely to swap the UK holding for one in Sky Global.

However, in New York this week Mr Messier said that any holding in Sky Global would be an "interim solution".

After suggesting last week that he was open to the possibility of holding shares in Sky, Mr Messier said: "At the end of the day, part of the undertaking was to exit any direct or indirect relationship with Sky."

The EU had given him "total flexibility" to sell the BSkyB stake within two years.

When asked about his relationship with Mr Murdoch, Mr Messier said his rival understood that he had a "duty to maximise the value" of his stake in BSkyB. Vivendi would not benefit from a "disorganised" sale that would depress the price of Sky Global.

In an interview with French newspaper Le Figaro this week, Mr Messier described Mr Murdoch as "a partner who is not easy".

Mr Murdoch tried to ease concerns that he would scrap the flotation. He said that, although the initial public offering was at least a month away, News Corporation was busy drawing up documents for the deal.

Mr Murdoch is keen to sign up a US satellite business such as Hughes, the satellite broadcaster owned by General Motors, or Echostar as a partner in the new company.

webTitle: Laughter and tears for Donald Dewar

fields.headline: Laughter and tears for Donald Dewar
fields.standfirst:
Prince, politicians and people pay tribute to MP's tireless efforts for a fairer society

Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: The prime minister, of course, was there.The Prince of Wales, the Irish Taoiseach, the British and Scottish cabinets filled the pews. Alongside them, however, sat schoolchildren, pensioners and the canteen ladies who made his daily bacon rolls.
fields.body:
The prime minister, of course, was there.The Prince of Wales, the Irish Taoiseach, the British and Scottish cabinets filled the pews. Alongside them, however, sat schoolchildren, pensioners and the canteen ladies who made his daily bacon rolls. The funeral of Donald Campbell Dewar was that sort of affair.

Within the 800-year-old walls of Glasgow Cathedral, more than 1,300 people gathered yesterday in respect and celebration of the life of Scotland's first first minister. Outside thousands lined the streets for the man who brought nationhood again to Scotland. It was, perhaps, the closest the country has come to a state funeral in modern times.

But Donald Dewar was also a private man who suffered a lonely childhood, spent solitary Christmasses with his books and surrounded himself with only a few close friends. For that man, the marking of his passing would have been an embarrassing, though gratifying, affair. "I wonder what Donald would have made of all this," said his friend and spokesman David Whitton.

Philosophy

His funeral said much about his life. There was no special area set aside for the politicians and dignitaries: they sat among the ordinary people Mr Dewar spent his career trying to help. He did so, said Mr Whitton, because of the "tadpole philosophy". Reading an extract from Equality by the historian RH Tawney, Mr Whitton said the passage appeared to concern tadpoles, but was about everything Mr Dewar believed in.

"If we look at our society, the tadpole philosophy is a very real threat," Mr Whitton said Mr Dewar had once told him. "I can see it, indeed, in parts of my own constituency, where people of real capacity don't make it, simply because hope and expectation is snuffed out."

A belief in helping the weak was the thread that bound Mr Dewar's funeral service. Tony Blair read from Isaiah of how the humblest and most needy must be helped. Gordon Brown, the chancellor, spoke of how this was Mr Dewar's creed.

"When people say what was special about Donald was his decency, they tell less than half the story. What was special was how constantly and tirelessly he pursued the logic of his decency and worked for a just and more equal society," said Mr Brown. "Everyone knew someone Donald had helped."

And it was the desire to help not the attainment of high office that drove Mr Dewar: nothing meant more to him than the work he could do and the people he represented. "MP for Garscadden and laterally MSP for Anniesland were the only two titles that meant anything to him," said Mr Brown.

There was more, though, to celebrate than a life of political service. Mr Dewar was friend as well as politician. "I have the daunting privilege of speaking on behalf of Donald's private army - his friends," said the broadcaster Ruth Wishart. She spoke warmly of the irascible, infuriating, rude but most of all humorous and loyal companion.

In a string of anecdotes that brought laughter to the cathedral, Ms Wishart explained how Mr Dewar's holiday wardrobe was nothing more than a pair of worn-out plimsoles; the sum of his outerwear was a 1960s overcoat. It was a look his friends despaired of - and knew they would never change. But then he appeared at a lunch in a "YSL" tie.

Mournful

Ms Wishart thought he had finally been made over and inquired if Yves Saint Laurent designer chic had crept into his wardrobe. Not at all, he retorted - "he had been presented with it by Yarrow Shipbuilders Ltd".

The laughter died away as the clear unaccompanied voice of the Labour MSP for Falkirk East, Cathy Peattie, filled the cathedral with the strains of Burns' mournful ballad, Aye Waulkin O. Tears were shed.

Outside, a large crowd gathered to listen to the service, and there were touches that Mr Dewar might have loved. An elderly lady helped to a better vantage point by the crowds, programmes shared and comfort offered when, for some, it all became too much. Small courtesies in honour of a man who prized decency above all else and was himself prized for it.

"He was a great man for Scotland," said Marie McDougall of Roystonhill, Glasgow, who had come to the cathedral to pay her respects after meeting Mr Dewar at a community housing project last year. "He was a decent, ordinary person. No airs and graces. He made me feel like what I said was important to him and I wanted to be here because of that."

But for all Mr Dewar's approachability, the congregation inside the cathedral showed that his life had been far from ordinary. Prince Charles represented the Queen; all but two members of the cabinet were there - including Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor, with his wife Alison, Mr Dewar's ex-wife - and a generation of political heavyweights sat alongside. Mr Dewar's son Ian, 33, and daughter Marion, 35, led the family mourners.

The Rev Douglas Alexander, a friend of Mr Dewar since university days, led the service for his "real and extended family". As a single red rose lay on top of Mr Dewar's coffin, Mr Alexander offered a eulogy: "Where the truth is, God is. Where decency is, God is. In Donald we had honesty, decency and compassion."

After the service, Mr Dewar's family walked behind his coffin down the cathedral aisle; outside hundreds of people gathered along the route to the cemetery where he was buried privately. As the cortege reached George Square in the heart of Glasgow, the crowd watched silently until someone broke into applause. Clapping swelled and spread across the square.

As the crowds dispersed, a fiddler inside the cathedral played one of Burns' most famous airs. The first bars of For a That And a That filled the building; its lyrics were left unsung. They didn't need to be.

The rank is but the guinea's stamp,

The man's the gowd for a that.

fields.headline: Fear across the barriers
fields.standfirst:
Jewish view: Trapped in a worthless flat

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Yosef Mizrahi cannot tear himself away from the window of his daughter's flat. He trains his binoculars on the Palestinian village of Beit Jalla, which spills out from a hilltop across the way, moving upwards from the olive groves in the valley to the roofs of the nearest houses.
fields.body:
Yosef Mizrahi cannot tear himself away from the window of his daughter's flat. He trains his binoculars on the Palestinian village of Beit Jalla, which spills out from a hilltop across the way, moving upwards from the olive groves in the valley to the roofs of the nearest houses.

There is no sign of movement. But Mr Mizrahi remains restless. In the last 24 hours his daughter's flat at 329 Anafa Street in this Jewish settlement on the southern edges of Jerusalem has been turned into a frontline.

On Tuesday night, when the Palestinian snipers on the opposite rooftops, a distance of perhaps 800 metres, opened fire, a bullet hit the thick outer wall of the flat, chipping off a block of golden stone close to the spot where Mr Mizrahi's daughter's wedding picture hangs in the bedroom.

Yesterday, two tanks trundled back and forth at the foot of the building, where a bulldozer was ploughing a perimeter road. Soldiers were setting up a barricade of massive concrete blocks and Israel's new team of spin doctors was leading journalists on a conducted tour of the newest war zone in nearly three weeks of violence between Israel and the Palestinians.

Mr Mizrahi, and his son-in-law, Roni Barazani, are singularly unimpressed by the spectacle unfolding beneath their first-floor window. "This is just crap. What a waste of money," says Mr Barazani. "It won't help at all. The bullets are coming from above."

He cautions his guests, sitting on the black leatherette sofa in a front room crammed with toys: "You know we are on army orders not to sit there. This is a frontline."

When the firing started on Tuesday night, pockmarking a row of low-rise flats along the street, a border policeman was critically injured, taking a bullet in the chest. Two of Mr Barazani's neighbours were slightly injured.

He, his wife, Ayelet, and two small daughters decamped to Mr Mizrahi's, who also lives in Gilo but far back from the ridge. Last night, the family was planning to drag mattresses into the small back bedroom shared by their daughters, one-year-old Yuval and Ofek, three.

Several of their neighbours appear to have moved out until signs of a lasting calm. Police have set up a cordon at the entrance to the street in a half-hearted attempt to reduce traffic. Most curiosity seekers simply stroll down the end of the road and clamber down a flight of stairs to the flats.

Of the bloodshed of the past weeks, both men claim a certain expertise. Mr Barazani is in the building trade and employs dozens of Palestinian labourers. When his family moved into their flat less than three years ago, a crew of Palestinian workers arrived to do the painting and plastering.

"They were all people from Beit Jalla. They sat and ate with us and we gave them money. There was no problem," says Mr Mizrahi.

Born in Iraqi Kurdistan and a fluent Arabic speaker, Mr Mizrahi used to wander down to Beit Jalla twice a week to shop and to visit the holy sites of Bethlehem. He is particularly fond of Manger Square.

"With the Christians, we don't have a problem. It's a Muslim problem," Mr Mizrahi says. He stretches an arm towards Beit Jalla. "Look how rich they are. What big houses they have, and every house there is for just one family."

But this small flat is a millstone round the family's neck. Although they believe the tanks and barricades offer no real protection, Mr Barazani says he cannot even think of moving. "Property prices have dropped 40 % overnight," he says. "What am I supposed to do, put it up for sale with a tank thrown in for free? Who would buy it?"

He says his workers tell him they have no time for the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat. He argues they have benefited handsomely from Israel's national health scheme and other social benefits, and have no desire to give them up.

"We are not the people who started this," Mr Barazani says. "They say they are just throwing stones and not firing with bullets. But stones can kill just as easily as a bullet."

Still, both men believe war is inevitable, and that the latest ceasefire can do nothing to stop it. What is needed, they argue, is for Israel to stop tiptoeing around, and to hit the Palestinians back hard.

"If we want to, our soldiers could kill 1,000 of their people every day. We do not have a problem killing people, we have the power to do it. But instead, what is happening is that we have our soldiers risking their lives to avoid killing Arabs," Mr Mizrahi says.

When the firing started on Tuesday night, pockmarking a row of low-rise flats along the street, a border policeman was critically injured, taking a bullet in the chest. Two of Mr Barazani's neighbours were slightly injured. He, his wife, Ayelet, and two small daughters decamped to Mr Mizrahi's, who also lives in Gilo but far back from the ridge. Last night, the family was planning to drag mattresses into the small back bedroom shared by their daughters, one-year-old Yuval and Ofek, three. Several of their neighbours appear to have moved out until signs of a lasting calm. Police have set up a cordon at the entrance to the street in a half-hearted attempt to reduce traffic. Most curiosity seekers simply stroll down the end of the road and clamber down a flight of stairs to the flats. Of the bloodshed of the past weeks, both men claim a certain expertise. Mr Barazani is in the building trade and employs dozens of Palestinian labourers. When his family moved into their flat less than three years ago, a crew of Palestinian workers arrived to do the painting and plastering. "They were all people from Beit Jalla. They sat and ate with us and we gave them money. There was no problem," says Mr Mizrahi. Born in Iraqi Kurdistan and a fluent Arabic speaker, Mr Mizrahi used to wander down to Beit Jalla twice a week to shop and to visit the holy sites of Bethlehem. He is particularly fond of Manger Square. "With the Christians, we don't have a problem. It's a Muslim problem," Mr Mizrahi says. He stretches an arm towards Beit Jalla. "Look how rich they are. What big houses they have, and every house there is for just one family." But this small flat is a millstone round the family's neck. Although they believe the tanks and barricades offer no real protection, Mr Barazani says he cannot even think of moving. "Property prices have dropped 40 % overnight," he says. "What am I supposed to do, put it up for sale with a tank thrown in for free? Who would buy it?" He says his workers tell him they have no time for the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat. He argues they have benefited handsomely from Israel's national health scheme and other social benefits, and have no desire to give them up. "We are not the people who started this," Mr Barazani says. "They say they are just throwing stones and not firing with bullets. But stones can kill just as easily as a bullet." Still, both men believe war is inevitable, and that the latest ceasefire can do nothing to stop it. What is needed, they argue, is for Israel to stop tiptoeing around, and to hit the Palestinians back hard. "If we want to, our soldiers could kill 1,000 of their people every day. We do not have a problem killing people, we have the power to do it. But instead, what is happening is that we have our soldiers risking their lives to avoid killing Arabs," Mr Mizrahi says.

webTitle: Tradition of grim determination nets lynch mob

fields.headline: Tradition of grim determination nets lynch mob
fields.standfirst:
Israeli agents: Palestinians hunted in style of Munich 1972

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel's dramatic capture of Palestinians suspected of involvement in last week's lynching of two soldiers in the West Bank fits into a long tradition of hunting down enemies with "blood on their hands" - however long it takes.
fields.body:
Israel's dramatic capture of Palestinians suspected of involvement in last week's lynching of two soldiers in the West Bank fits into a long tradition of hunting down enemies with "blood on their hands" - however long it takes.

Details remained sketchy last night, but the operation was reportedly the work of the Shin Bet security service, whose agents led the army to hiding places in the Ramallah area.

Still stunned by the brutality of the killings - broadcast repeatedly on television since last Thursday - many saw a link to the far longer search for the Palestinians who murdered 11 Israeli athletes at the Munich Olympics in 1972.

In that case, the Mossad secret service spent years hunting down the members of the "Black September" team - who did much to draw attention to the Palestinian cause.

One by one through the 70s and 80s the Munich killers and planners were targeted in Europe and the Middle East, although one innocent man, a Moroccan waiter working in Norway, was mistakenly assassinated.

Israel denied links with the Mossad hit squads for years, but eventually admitted it had been responsible and had planned the revenge campaign at the highest levels.

During that so-called "war of the spooks", a young Israeli special forces officer named Ehud Barak led one of the deadliest of a series of carefully planned attacks on key PLO targets.

In 1973, Mr Barak, commander of the elite Sayeret Matkal unit, led a raid on Beirut, codenamed Springtime of Youth, in which three guerrilla leaders - and the wife of one of them - were gunned down in their homes.

By contrast, the Palestinians captured after the Ramallah lynching, which took place inside the city's police station, are likely to stand trial. But it was clear from the start that the Israelis would ensure they did not escape retribution.

Binyamin Ben-Eliezer, the deputy prime minister, issued a chilling warning hours after an Israeli helicopter gunship fired a rocket into the window through which the bodies of the two soldiers were thrown.

"We will get them, one by one," he declared. "We will do whatever it takes and find them when they are least expecting us. These are not human beings but wild animals."

The Israelis were middle-aged reservists who blundered into the Palestinian-controlled town on their way to report to their transport unit in a nearby Jewish settlement.

The killing was a grave embarrassment for the Palestinian Authority as it gave Israel a grisly propaganda advantage that detracted from the media impact of far greater Palestinian losses - including many children - in repeated clashes with troops.

Yasser Arafat was reported to have ordered that participants in the lynching be arrested. Speculation was rife last night that Palestinian security services had helped the Shin Bet track down the culprits, or at the very least turned a blind eye to an operation apparently conducted in Palestinian-controlled territory.

Meanwhile, a correspondent for Italian state television, Rai, was ordered back to Rome after being rebuked for apologising to the Palestinian Authority for having handed over film of the lynching to the Israelis. Other footage of the killings, in which Palestinian policemen were unable to hold back the baying mob, was confiscated.

The correspondent, Riccardo Cristiano, said he had been trying to clarify Rai's impartiality.

fields.headline: Israelis snatch lynch mob suspects
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli commandos captured several men from the mob which lynched two of its soldiers, injecting a potentially combustible charge into the first tentative steps taken yesterday to curtail the violence in the Middle East and rebuild shattered confidence.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Jerusalem and  Suzanne Goldenberg in Beit Jalla
fields.body:
Israeli commandos captured several men from the mob which lynched two of its soldiers, injecting a potentially combustible charge into the first tentative steps taken yesterday to curtail the violence in the Middle East and rebuild shattered confidence.

On a day of high tension and sporadic violence, Palestinian and Israeli sources reported that as many as eight men involved in last week's brutal slaying of two Israeli reservists at a police station in central Ramallah had been seized.

The area where the men were murdered is under the full control of Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority, where Israeli forces are barred from operating alone. If it turns out the commandos had help from Palestinian police, that would make Mr Arafat appear to have sold out.

Palestinian distrust could also rise following an appeal from the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, to the rightwing opposition Likud party leader, Ariel Sharon, and other key players to join an emergency government. Many Palestinians would take that as a sign that Mr Barak has given up on the peace process.

Yesterday he restated his belief that he could not make peace with Mr Arafat. "To my sadness, I am not convinced that we have a partner for peace," he said.

Less than a day after the US-brokered Sharm el-Sheikh summit gave the Oslo peace process the slenderest of second chances, military and security officials tried to defuse tensions.

But new clashes were reported as Israel's Gen Yom Tov Samia and the Palestinian general Abdel-Razak al-Majaida met at the northern entrance to the Gaza Strip. Last night a powerful roadside bomb exploded as a civilian bus was passing an Israeli settlement. Earlier a Palestinian boy, 12, was seriously injured in one of many incidents.

Israel welcomed a statement from Mr Arafat's Palestinian Authority that it had "issued strict orders to all Palestinians to follow through" on the implementation of what was agreed at Tuesday's summit.

The appeal was not issued in person byMr Arafat, who has faced angry protests about his presence at Sharm el-Sheikh. The call to halt the violence was aimed at Mr Arafat's Fatah faction, whose Tanzim gunmen have taken a lead in shooting attacks on Israeli positions, often from inside large crowds. More than 100 people, almost all Palestinians, have been killed in 21 days of fighting.

In return, Israel announced the lifting of an internal closure on Palestinian areas, which prevented residents from travelling, and allowed the reopening of Gaza airport and border crossings to Egypt and Jordan.

However, a general closure that prevents Palestinians from entering Israel remained in effect.

Palestinian, Israeli and US security officials were meeting last night to decide when to start a 48-hour countdown after which a full ceasefire is due to come into effect.

Meanwhile, Israel Radio said yesterday that one of the lynch suspects being held was the man who stood at the window of the police station with his bloodied hands raised in triumph. Nahman Shai, the Israeli government spokesman, refused to confirm the report.

webTitle: The mayor's wife who was 'too busy' to meet Queen

fields.headline: The mayor's wife who was 'too busy' to meet Queen
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The Queen, as a veteran of countless royal tours, is used to politicians on the make. She has been pawed by premiers and appraised by pontiffs and manipulated by ministers. But yesterday in Rome may have been the first time she has been stood up by a mayor's wife.
fields.body:
The Queen, as a veteran of countless royal tours, is used to politicians on the make. She has been pawed by premiers and appraised by pontiffs and manipulated by ministers. But yesterday in Rome may have been the first time she has been stood up by a mayor's wife.

Her Majesty, resplendent in lilac, was supposed to be greeted by the mayor of Rome, Francesco Rutelli, and his wife Barbara Palombelli, a journalist, on her arrival at the Capidoglio, the city's Michelangelo-designed town hall yesterday morning, where she was supposed to be viewing ruins of the nearby Forum.

But it did not take long to appreciate that the woman by the mayor's side was not actually his wife. She was no impostor but Louisa Laurelli, blameless chairwoman of the city council.

Later the Queen, who has managed to avoid garlic on her trip, was served roast young goat with chestnuts and seasonal vegetables for lunch.

Goat, described as more delicate than lamb, is usually served at Easter in Italy with roast potatoes. But now chestnuts are in season and they were teamed up with the tender goat for the royal table.

Before the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh set out on their four-day state visit, Buckingham Palace sent a list of royal culinary likes and dislikes.

Evidently, goat was not listed as a dislike. But garlic as well as difficult-to-eat spaghetti and potentially messy tomato sauce were.

Ms Palombelli in her newspaper column in the centre-left La Repubblica dispenses agony aunt wisdom.

Her website yesterday announced defiantly that she was too busy to meet the Queen and anyway never turned up for her husband's official events. She clearly overlooked the time she deigned to greet President Clinton.

It has to be said that the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh appeared sublimely unconcerned by the absence of the mayor's wife.

Mr Rutelli may yet become Italy's prime minister, as he appears certain to become the centre left alliance's candidate to go head to head with rightwing media magnate Silvio Berlusconi in next year's general election.

His wife's behaviour would not have met with approval from the small band of Italian monarchists who greeted the Queen on her walkabout outside the Capidoglio.

Dressed in long cloaks airing the royal arms of the House of Savoy, the family deposed in 1946, they form an eccentric rump. The last monarchist party disbanded in Italy in 1972.

Luca Schiamo, 25, explained how much he loved the British queen. "She is so much better than a president," he said, but his colleagues confessed that the monarchist group - combined membership 3,500 - has an uphill struggle.

Today the Queen will be on another politician-alert, lunching with Mr Berlusconi in Milan.

webTitle: A broken rail - new safety alert at 100 sites on the network

fields.headline: A broken rail - new safety alert at 100 sites on the network
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the Hatfield train crash
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Speed restrictions were imposed on more than 1,000 miles of Britain's railway network yesterday as it emerged that a commonly found distortion in track could be responsible for Tuesday's crash near Hatfield which killed four passengers.
fields.byline: Andrew Clark, Keith Perry and Sarah Hall
fields.body:
Speed restrictions were imposed on more than 1,000 miles of Britain's railway network yesterday as it emerged that a commonly found distortion in track could be responsible for Tuesday's crash near Hatfield which killed four passengers.

The emergency measures, announced by Railtrack last night, will cut speeds by up to a third at about 100 different sites and will lead to delays throughout the network.

The move came hours after the company's chief executive, Gerald Corbett, offered to resign, saying he was "distraught" by the tragedy. His future remained uncertain as Railtrack's 13-strong board met to decide whether to accept his offer.

Accident investigators found that a broken rail had caused the London-to-Leeds service to come off the track at 115mph, even though the track was just five years old.

Railtrack executives believe the break could have been caused by a condition called "graduated top" - a frequent form of uneveness on the surface of the track, caused by erosion. The company has imposed speed limits on all areas where this problem exists.

Railtrack later revealed that it had decided to re-rail the Hatfield area this year. The work was due to be completed in November. The section of line was treated by grinding on September 4 and 5 as part of planned preventative maintenance to stop rail breaks and improve ride quality. The stretch of line was last visually inspected a week before the accident on October 10, and it was due to have another in spection on the day of the crash. Yesterday Railtrack admitted that the condition of the track was "not good."

Michael Holden, director of Railtrack Southern, said: "We have had engineers inspecting the crash site and on the basis of what they have found we are saying the track appears to have been one of the factors. The engineers are saying they have seen enough of the track to say it has been an issue."

Executives at the company realised as early as Tuesday evening that faulty track was the probable cause of the crash. Mr Corbett offered to stand down after agonising over his future overnight. But by last night, there was growing support for him. Survivors of last year's Paddington rail crash joined passengers' groups and the government in urging Railtrack not to make him a scapegoat.

In a statement to the Stock Exchange, Mr Corbett said: "I, personally, am distraught that another tragedy has occurred on our railways. The families of the bereaved are foremost in my mind.

"As a matter of principle, as chief executive of Railtrack, I have, of course, tendered my resignation to the board."

Within hours, Lord MacDonald, the transport minister, expressed concern: "I certainly would not want to see anything that put at risk the authority and executive lines of command inside Railtrack."

The 49-year-old chief executive also received backing from Pam Warren, who was badly burned in the Paddington rail crash a year ago. She said it would be impractical for him to resign at a "horrendous time like this".

Mrs Warren said: "We would urge Railtrack not to accept Mr Corbett's resignation. We need Railtrack to work with us, to urgently address the problem of rail safety."

There was praise for Mr Corbett from the Association of Train Operating Companies, the Rail Passengers' Council and from Christopher Garnett, chief executive of GNER, the train company involved in the accident.

Mr Garnett said: "I genuinely don't know what that is going to do to improve rail safety for passengers. Gerald Corbett was leading Railtrack well."

The shadow transport secretary, Archie Norman, a former director of Railtrack, said: "If he goes, it will be a great loss to the railway industry."

Mr Corbett's wife, Virginia, said her husband was devastated by the crash. Speaking outside the couple's farmhouse at Redbourne, Herts, she said: "He was appalled by what happened and feels very sorry for the affected families."

Mr Corbett has been chief executive of Railtrack for three years. He resisted pressure to resign after the Paddington disaster, which was caused by a train going through a red light, on the grounds that tracks and signals were in full working order. However, he made it clear at the time that he would have quit if Railtrack had been at fault.

fields.headline: Families caught in the crossfire
fields.standfirst:
Arab view: Paradise turns into a prison

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: With her younger daughter perched on her hip and the elder tugging at the knees of her jeans, Manal Kamel points her free arm towards the opposite hill and the tank whose machine gun is pointing at her home.
fields.body:
With her younger daughter perched on her hip and the elder tugging at the knees of her jeans, Manal Kamel points her free arm towards the opposite hill and the tank whose machine gun is pointing at her home.

"Just the sight of that tank is enough to panic us," she says. But the tank is there to stay. On Tuesday afternoon, about an hour after Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, agreed to end the violence, snipers perched on a neighbouring house opened up on the Jewish suburb of Gilo, a sprawl of low-rise apartment blocks 800 metres away. Israeli soldiers returned fire with machine guns. Yesterday, they enforced their positions around Gilo.

Ms Kamel's home stands directly in their path. "The bullets were falling like rain here. It was the most terrible thing. The children were taking their afternoon nap. It was very frightening."

When the firing stopped, she took her children and fled to her mother's at the other end of Beit Jalla, a prosperous, mainly Christian village on the western fringes of Bethlehem.

She felt no safer. "Last night, I could not sleep because I kept thinking about my daughter. There is a big window in her room and the firing could start at any time."

The Kamels came home yesterday morning, despite a warning from Israel's army for people living on Beit Jalla's firing line to evacuate their homes, or risk getting shot. But where else would Ms Kamel and her children go?

Although the village is under Palestinian self-rule, the main road into Beit Jalla is blocked by an Israeli concrete guard post, and there is a strip of metal spikes on the road. The Israeli authorities have imposed closures on the West Bank and Gaza, barring Palestinians travelling to Israel proper.

Ms Kamel is afraid that if she leaves her home, she may not be able to return for days. She and her husband, a candlemaker who supplies the churches of Beit Jalla and Bethlehem, have invested everything in this home.

The family moved into the house nearly two years ago, a handsome two-storey building divided into four flats, one for each brother in an extended family. All enjoy spectacular views of a silvery-green olive grove, and the flats of Gilo.

Nobody in the family has ever been to Gilo, built on illegally occupied Palestinian land which was later annexed to Jerusalem. There is a bridge spanning the valley, but it was built for cars speeding to other Jewish settlements to the south. Until the first of four recent gun battles between Beit Jalla and Gilo, it was as if their Jewish neighbours did not exist.

Last night, the family was planning to bed down on mattresses on the floor of the back room.

When the firing started on Tuesday, all seven children in the extended household were bundled downstairs to the basement in stages, the family huddling for intervals against the wall of the central stairwell. Ms Kamel's elder daugh ter, Juwana, an inquisitive girl in a tartan frock was old enough to understand what was happening, and she was terrified. "She is four now and very sensitive. What can I explain to a little girl?" she says.

Shadia Bazazo, Ms Kamel's sister-in-law, has four older boys and her terrors are different. Across the valley from Bethlehem, they can hear the wake for Mohammed Jawarish, 14, who was shot dead by Israeli soldiers earlier in the week. "We will keep struggling until we achieve victory," the mourners chant. "We will take the same path as the martyrs."

webTitle: Jury finds woman guilty of blackmailing football star

fields.headline: Jury finds woman guilty of blackmailing football star
fields.trailText: An obsessed and lonely former beauty queen faces a long prison sentence for a plot to blackmail a former international footballer that persisted until a crown court jury found her guilty yesterday.
fields.body:
An obsessed and lonely former beauty queen faces a long prison sentence for a plot to blackmail a former international footballer that persisted until a crown court jury found her guilty yesterday.

Carolyn Pick's initial hopes of sex and money became a deluded hunt for fame as she handed out pictures of herself during the trial and stared across the court at her victim, whose family life and reputation she had threatened to ruin in a series of chilling tapes.

Foiled by rigorous legal restrictions from dragging his name into the headlines, the 36-year-old sat expressionless as the verdict was read after the jury had only been out for only 35 minutes. Judge David Hodson remanded her in custody, after warnings that she might still stalk the ex-footballer if given bail.

Pick was taken from the dock with a warning that the sentence could be up to 14 years for a crime described during the seven-day hearing in Newcastle upon Tyne as sinister, menacing and relentless. Prosecuting counsel Robert Woodcock said that the six-year plot had harassed and frightened "a very successful public figure, whose position and popularity make him vulnerable to exploitation".

The victim gave evidence at the trial, looking embarrassed as he described how cut-out photographs of naked men with his head glued on top had formed part of Pick's bombardment of letters, packages and calls.

He described how friends and colleagues had been sent the material, while the would-be blackmailer taped a promise that she would prove his denials were lies.

He told the jury: "Some were suggestive and pleading. Others were very abusive, vitriolic and threatening. I was more than disturbed by it. You don't really know what you are dealing with."

He was visibly angered when asked about claims that he had masturbated while on the phone to Pick when she first made contact.

The court heard the man had put the phone down on Pick when she tricked him into ringing by leaving a message at his workplace claiming to be a colleague. The blackmailer, who is jobless and lives in a block of flats in Washington, Tyne and Wear, started talking about her suspenders and underwear, which her victim briefly took to be a friend playing a joke.

The call was just long enough, the jury heard, for Pick to claim repeatedly that it amounted to phone sex and to make claims that she had been abused and only wanted an apology.

Giving evidence, she broke down in tears as she said: "I was bluffing. I want him to know I am very sorry. I just felt absolutely devastated and empty inside. I waited every night for him to call me, but he dumped me. He treated me like a chatline prostitute."

The court was told Pick had made no specific demands for money or goods, but referred to her fondness for big houses, expensive cars, fine wine and beautiful restaurants, suggesting that her victim could use them to "correct matters". She was eventually cautioned by police when her calls took on a threatening tone.

Pick, a former secretary, had a drab background that contrasted with the ex-footballer's apparent high life. Her work as a secretary was interrupted by one brief moment of glamour, when she was a finalist in the 1986 Miss England North East beauty competition.

One of three sisters, she lost her father to cancer two years ago and has a mother who suffers from severe dementia.

"This is an unusual case of blackmail because what the defendant knew about the victim is little more than you or I know about him," said Mr Woodcock.

Judge Hodson, who adjourned sentencing until November 17 while psychiatric reports are prepared, criticised media coverage of the trial. He asked prosecution barristers to put together a file of cuttings for the attorney general to assess whether there had been any breach of contempt of court orders protecting the victim's identity.

The ex-footballer was not in court for the verdict and had no comment afterwards.

webTitle: Widow denied £400,000 payout because of mistress

fields.headline: Widow denied £400,000 payout because of mistress
fields.trailText: An insurance company is refusing to pay out a £400,000 claim to the widow of a motorcycle accident victim on the grounds that he had a mistress and his marriage would not have lasted.
fields.body:
An insurance company is refusing to pay out a £400,000 claim to the widow of a motorcycle accident victim on the grounds that he had a mistress and his marriage would not have lasted.

Sadie Dalziel was unaware of the other woman's existence until her husband, Jason, a soldier, was killed, the high court was told today. His lover, who was riding pillion, survived.

Martin Staples, president of the Forum of Insurance Lawyers, representing lawyers who act for insurers, said he had not seen such a case in 38 years of practice. But he added: "If you can show that the husband would definitely have gone, then the wife would be limited to what she would have got on divorce."

Mrs Dalziel, 30, told a judge at the high court in London that she had "worshipped the ground" her husband walked on.

Elizabeth Simpson, who survived when the 1,000cc motorbike crashed in Hull in 1996, also had no idea he was married and considered herself his fiancee, the court was told.

Lance Corporal Dalziel, who was 25 and was to start a tour of duty in Kosovo, also left a baby daughter, Caris, now five.

Mrs Dalziel, of Burham, Kent, wants damages from the other driver involved, Gary Donald, from Doncaster. His insurers have admitted 80% liability but say the widow should have only modest damages because her marriage was "unlikely to have survived".

The widow told deputy high court judge, Robert Moxon-Browne QC, that she never suspected her husband, whom she married in 1995, was having an affair. She insisted that she would have stayed with him even if she had found out about the other woman.

Howard Elgot, for Mr Donald's insurers, told the judge that Miss Simpson, of Shiptonthorpe, near York, had been told by the soldier that he would move to Yorkshire to be near her when he returned from Kosovo in late 1996.

Mr Elgot said Mr Dalziel began his relationship with Miss Simpson in January 1995 and proposed to her in November the same year, eight months after marrying his wife.

He said the soldier had disciplinary problems in the army and his career had also been unlikely to survive.

The hearing continues today.

webTitle: One of the victims still not identified

fields.headline: One of the victims still not identified
fields.standfirst:
Police say examination of the site could take a week
Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: Police were last night still trying to identify one of the four men killed in the rail crash.
fields.body:
Police were last night still trying to identify one of the four men killed in the rail crash.

Relatives of the other three had been informed that their loved ones died in the disaster, but officers were struggling to establish who the fourth man was.

Postmortems were carried out on two of the victims yesterday afternoon and police were hoping that inquests on all four, whose bodies were being held at the Queen Elizabeth II Hospital in Welwyn Garden City, could be opened tomorrow.

All but three of those who needed hospital treatment were released and able to complete their journeys which began yesterday afternoon or returned home.

Seven - six of them women - had been kept in overnight. Those who remained in hospital were a 41-year-old man from south-east London, a 30-year-old woman from Wakefield, and a 66-year-old woman from Harrogate. Among the injuries to the seven were a punctured lung, a broken leg and fractured vertebrae.

Meanwhile, the police investigation centred on a 600 metre stretch of track strewn with debris and mangled metal.

At 3pm yesterday, the carriages which had fallen on to their sides were lifted high enough so that officers could make sure that no one else had been trapped underneath.

Otherwise police were concentrating on a fingertip search of the area. The stretch of track was divided into sections and teams on hands and knees picked their way through the wreckage.

Whenever they found an object which they believed could be of interest or which they could not identify they called over awaiting technical experts to check what the object was. The whole operation was filmed and could be used in evidence as part of any criminal prosecution.

By 5pm the police had checked one fifth of the area and confirmed that they had not found any evidence so far that vandalism might have caused the crash.

Among police officers at the scene were scenes of crime expert and members of the Metropolitan police's body recovery team. Sixty or 70 people were present at any one time.

Inspector Alec Carson, of British Transport Police, said the search could take several days, possibly even a week. If the weather worsened - yesterday it remained mostly dry - it could take even longer. Those who saw the train wreck at close hand said it was a bizarre sight. One of the rails looked like a rope which had been flicked up over the other track.

Police officers found themselves picking through suitcases, handbags and briefcases which had been thrown across the track. The buffet car was a mess of broken glass and jagged metal. The roof looked, in one observer's words, like "a piece of material flapping about."

Tin cans and bags were scattered inside.

The blackberry bushes along the side of the track were pockmarked with bits of metal and rubbish.

The gantry which supported the electric cables had collapsed on to the track. The atmosphere was described as "eerily quiet, sombre".

The scene clearly disturbed even senior officers and railwaymen.

Chris Garnett, chief executive of GNER, said it had been horrific to see the ripped up track, the coaches on their sides and the huge wheels scattered across the rails.

But assistant chief constable Paul Nicholas, of British Transport Police, said that his 35 years service had taught him that rail travel remained the safest form of transport.

He said: "There is no doubt the railways are still the safest way to travel. Millions of people travel safely every day."
