fields.headline: BT to offer 'free' off-peak calls
fields.standfirst:
Troubled company plans US-style monthly payment package to cover local weekend and evening use

Net news
fields.trailText: The dream of every talkative teenager - and the answer to their parents' nightmare - could soon become reality thanks to US-style "free" local evening and weekend phone calls to be offered by BT.
fields.body:
The dream of every talkative teenager - and the answer to their parents' nightmare - could soon become reality thanks to US-style "free" local evening and weekend phone calls to be offered by BT.

A confidential BT briefing document obtained by the Guardian discloses that the company is to launch a radical off-peak free calls package on December 1, after a nationwide advertising campaign starting next month.

The package, called BT Talk Together, will offer an unlimited number of local evening and weekend calls for residential subscribers for £14.99 a month, including line rental and VAT - £5 more than the current standard monthly line rental.

But there is still a catch in the small print for the parents of chatty children - 1p a minute will be charged after the first hour of any single "free" call.

The offer will be part of a wider shake-up by the telecommunications giant, which has been under pressure from increased competition from mobile phones and cable operators.

BT said yesterday it would not comment on the new package in advance of an official announcement. "We have no specific plans that we are able to talk about right now," said David Orr, a spokesman for the company.

The company will also offer a similar package for unlimited off-peak internet access. The combined voice and internet package will cost £17.99 a month.

At the same time the company also plans to hike its standard residential line rental by more than £2 a quarter. BT defends the increase by saying it needs to make "a better return on its line rental product".

Oftel, the telecommunications watchdog, is said to have been told of the plans by BT. "Oftel have been informed of the price changes and there are now no objections to the changes," the briefing document states.

BT says the timing and scope of the unlimited calls package is the result of demand from its residential customers.

The off-peak call scheme comes after heavy criticism of BT by its rivals that the corporation has "dragged its feet" over allowing its competitors access to local exchanges and hampered internet service providers from offering unmetered access for individuals along the lines of similar services in the US.

The company has also seen its share price plummet in recent months on the back of investors' worries about the size of BT's corporate debt - which is more than £20bn.

City analysts expect BT's new offer to spark a price war among the leading operators. And it comes as BT has been under severe pressure from institutional investors to breathe life back into its faltering share price - which has fallen from a peak of £15.13 at the beginning of this year to less than £7 each this month.

In its most recent company results, BT reported a 27% dive in pre-tax profits for the first three months of this year, down from £772m to £561m. Earlier this month, BT bowed to shareholder pressure for a change in its management by parting company with its senior finance director.

In April, BT announced it had restructured the company into four main divisions, and is expected to sell off some to raise extra cash to help meet its debt mountain.

But yesterday BT received some good news. The company won a £250m refund on its local business rates bills in England and Wales. The rebate covers valuations based on BT's network assets, including phone boxes and telephone poles.

webTitle: Tories warm to Benn plan for Speaker

fields.headline: Tories warm to Benn plan for Speaker
fields.standfirst:
Special report: who will be the new Speaker?
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Tony Benn's plan to reform the way of choosing the Speaker of the Commons yesterday won the backing of the Conservative front runner, Sir George Young.
fields.body:
Tony Benn's plan to reform the way of choosing the Speaker of the Commons yesterday won the backing of the Conservative front runner, Sir George Young.

But important members of Labour's establishment discreetly threw their weight behind the "Buggin's turn" principle of having a Tory as successor to Betty Boothroyd, formerly a Labour MP.

Despite the government's determined effort to stay out of a contest among backbench MPs, the leader of the Commons, Margaret Beckett, let it be known she favoured a Tory - provided the Opposition could field "a heavyweight candidate" who was also a reformer. Sir George fits that bill, being a poll tax rebel sacked by Lady Thatcher who became John Major's transport secretary.

But the Labour frontrunner, Michael Martin, the Glaswegian former shop steward, now one of Betty Boothroyd's deputies, has amassed considerable support, and remains the bookies' favourite.

Mrs Beckett's aides were careful yesterday to say that she was not endorsing Sir George or undermining Mr Martin, both self-declared reformers. But the net effect of her advice was to do just that, five days ahead of Monday's Commons vote to succeed Miss Boothroyd.

Other senior Labour fixers were also delicately urging backbench colleagues to consider that Labour might be vulnerable to renewed charges of "control freakery" if it insisted on two Labour speakers in a row - a breach with a 30-year tradition.

Sir George yesterday wrote to Mr Benn endorsing his plan for replacing the rolling vote between two candidates at a time, with a straight ballot between all contenders and a run-off between the top two.

But Mr Benn's meeting to press his case on Sir Edward Heath, Father of the Commons who will chair Monday's election, was postponed.

Sir George yesterday wrote to Mr Benn endorsing his plan for replacing the rolling vote between two candidates at a time, with a straight ballot between all contenders and a run-off between the top two. But Mr Benn's meeting to press his case on Sir Edward Heath, Father of the Commons who will chair Monday's election, was postponed.

webTitle: New laws toe EU line on bias in workplace

fields.headline: New laws toe EU line on bias in workplace
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European Parliament
fields.trailText: The government is to introduce sweeping new laws cracking down on workplace discrimination on the grounds of religion, sexual orientation, age and disability.
fields.byline: Vikram Dodd  and  Andrew Osborn  in Brussels
fields.body:
The government is to introduce sweeping new laws cracking down on workplace discrimination on the grounds of religion, sexual orientation, age and disability.

It will be the first legislation in Britain outlawing discrimination on the grounds of religion and sexual orientation, and follows a landmark European Union directive rubber stamped by the European Council of ministers yesterday.

The government must put in place a system of "proportionate and persuasive" legal sanctions to discourage discrimination which is likely to include financial compensation and mandatory reinstatement.

The new anti-discrimination package will apply across all EU countries and was agreed after the government secured a series of opt outs.

The outlawing of discrimination on the grounds of religion or sexual orientation must be in place by 2003, with provisions covering discrimination on age and disability following three years later.

The home secretary Jack Straw had resisted calls from religious leaders for religious discrimination to be outlawed, but had commissioned more research into the issue. Muslims in particular felt that the scale of Islamaphobia they faced warranted legislation.

Francis Maude MP, the shadow foreign secretary, attacked the government's decision to sign up to the directive: "We believe it is right to strive for the elimination of discrimination in general, but we warned about the problems of this directive months ago."

Claude Moraes MEP, Labour's European parliament spokesman for employment and social affairs, said: "The government had taken the view that it's not desirable to extend the law to cover religious discrimination. Now the EU has done it.

Angela Mason, director of the gay rights group Stonewall, said: "It's very good news. At the moment in this country there is no legislation protecting gay men or lesbians in the workplace."

Afraid that the new legislation would spark a costly wave of litigation from workers, the government refused to endorse the directive until it had secured a number of key opt-outs.

"This is exactly the sort of directive that could give rise to a plethora of challenges and legal uncertainty for years to come," warned one UK official before the talks ended in Luxembourg on Tuesday night.

The government was particularly worried that the armed forces would be forced to recruit people who simply were not "combat ready" and won an exemption that will allow the army to continue to turn down and sack people who are too old or disabled to serve.

Religious schools will be able to continue to recruit staff of the same faith without risking challenge, according to employment minister Tessa Jowell. The business community also has doubts about the directive's section on age discrimination and condemned it as a "fuzzy law" which will trigger more employment tribunal applications.

John Cridland, deputy director-general of the Confederation of British Industry said: "Will a company be able to enforce a contractual agreement to retire? Can a firm offer higher pay to older staff?"

But with a growing number of people taking early retirement and claiming state pensions many European governments are keen to encourage employers not to automatically get rid of older workers.

The European Commission, the architect of the directive, says this legislation shows the EU is not just about economics. "This sends a strong signal that the EU is also a community of values," said Anna Diamantopoulou, commissioner for employment and social affairs.

webTitle: Chaos as aftermath hits roads and rail timetables

fields.headline: Chaos as aftermath hits roads and rail timetables
fields.standfirst:
Commuters face late and crowded trains

Special report: the Hatfield train crash
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Rail and road users yesterday faced difficult journeys as the stretch of track where the accident happened stayed closed.
fields.body:
Rail and road users yesterday faced difficult journeys as the stretch of track where the accident happened stayed closed.

Train companies reported little reduction in the number of passengers using their reduced services and consequently trains were crowded.

Major and minor roads around the site of the crash were congested due to part of the area being sealed off, and because a number of people drove rather than chance the trains.

GNER, which operates from Kings Cross to the north-east of England and Scotland, managed to run about 90% of its 120 plus services. Delays of up to an hour, north and south-bound, were caused as trains were diverted off the east coast main line through Hertford.

The speed restriction imposed on more than 12 stretches of line by Railtrack contributed to the delays.

However, a spokesman for GNER said there had been "no appreciable" difference in the number of people travelling.

With the weekend and the impending half-term, there is likely to be a surge in the number of people trying to use the railway and greater pressure on its services.

WAGN Railways, which runs shorter distances services from Kings Cross, managed to keep about two thirds of its trains going. For the foreseeable future it will be operating on an emergency timetable. It had not noticed a drop in passenger numbers and many commuter trains arriving in London yesterday morning and returning to the suburbs last night were very crowded.

It ran a number of bus services where stations such as Hatfield were closed down but a spokesman said that most people had been able to reach their destinations.

For WAGN, the half-term will come as some relief as the number of commuters using the services will be greatly reduced.

The roads around Hatfield and the A1M which runs a mile or so from the line were very busy.

Traffic tailed back for several miles on the A1 at Stevenage about 10 miles north of Hatfield for much of the day and commuter traffic nearer London jammed the motorway and many of the feeder roads. There were also knock-on effects on northern sections of the M25 and the M11 from East Anglia.

The rail companies and the AA were advising people to postpone journeys unless they were absolutely necessary.

fields.headline: Days of the living dead
fields.standfirst:
It happened to Barbara Castle, John Biffen - and Geoffrey Robinson. Hywel Williams on the politician's worst nightmare: getting the sack

Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: It happened to Barbara Castle, John Biffen - and Geoffrey Robinson. Hywel Williams on the politician's worst nightmare: getting the sack
fields.body:
The political death is a peculiarly British art form. There is a ritual to be followed and an etiquette to be observed as the pompous and the proud walk the plank to political perdition.

Once they tripped the primrose path of dalliance with favourites and enjoyed alliance with cliques who offered the means of ministerial grace and the hope of public glory. But the hour of dubious splendour in the governmental Rover is now about to pass. And the chauffeur who became "our family friend" stands ready for the final drive to dusty oblivion.

No longer will the red box at night be their chief delight. The bright day of these pocket Othellos is soon over as they learn that their occupation is gone and they are for the dark. The ritual which saves the face is part of our informal constitution by now. But it is preceded by an equally traditional destruction of reputation. The final goodbye may be short, but the farewell is long as the No 10 press office gets to work.

John Biffen read about his semi-detached status, Frank Field learnt of the impracticality of his reforms and John Patten could be fully seized of his unsuitability months before the axe fell.

In the Private Office there's awkwardness and whispering. Has the minister read the latest bit of diary gossip? Do we tell him about it? Do we care? The answer is no. All deaths are solitary affairs and political ones are no exception. In a mean Downing Street, the stiff upper lip, conjoined to the quivering lower one, must appear alone - to find a prime minister available for a few minutes.

The style will vary. "But why?" wailed one victim to Attlee. "Just not up to it, I'm afraid," he was told. Jim Callaghan told Barbara Castle that she was too old: "I must reduce the average age of cabinet and I want to ask for your portfolio." John Patten was ushered in and out by a Downing street back door to avoid the cameras.

Recollections will vary too as dignity is salvaged. Hugh Dalton was forced to resign as chancellor after a budget leak: "I was moved," he wrote in his memoirs, "that the prime minister was much more moved than I was at this moment. He said he hated - hated - he repeated the word several times - hated to lose me."

"Always was a loud-mouthed fellow" was Attlee's private reflection.

But the maintenance of form acquires a Japanese intensity at these moments. Most of the rest of us will reflect that even the grave yawns for these characters. But for those immersed in Westminster's isolation tank of unreality the patina of etiquette has to be polished to the end.

There's the formal exchange of letters, of faux -effusive thanks and implausibly grateful assurances that they "will continue to support the government from the back-benches".

Arias may have turned to requiems, but rest assured that they will hold a candle for the cause - even as they leave to spend more time with lobby journalists. "It is not so much being sacked that one objects to in politics, but the manner in which it is done," writes the latest memorialiser, Geoffrey Robinson.

He is only half wrong. Of course they all "object", and Robinson's resentment at Blair's first botched attempt at sacking him bubbles over. One instinctively knows when something is wrong with post-ministerial prose and the distancing "one" gives the game away.

But Robinson's resentment at the manner - the use of the cabinet secretary as a mere intermediary is entirely genuine.

The etiquette of the political court dictates that it is the prime minister who must do the sacking. The form is there to console the grief (and limit the damage potential) of the sacked.

A messenger is only for underlings or for the really embarrassing. The lord chancellor had to do the dirty deed in 1931 when the Liberal leader in the Lords, the 7th Earl Beauchamp, had to go. But then Beauchamp's countess had threatened to name his valet as the co-respondent in the looming divorce case.

Political office is to the politician what football is to the football manager - much more important than a mere question of life and death. Getting a life is strictly for other people. After all, after this death there is no other.

fields.headline: Lead poisoning killed Beethoven
fields.trailText: Beethoven was a victim of lead poisoning, according to an analysis of samples of his hair carried out by researchers in Chicago.
fields.body:
Beethoven was a victim of lead poisoning, according to an analysis of samples of his hair carried out by researchers in Chicago.

The verdict, after four years of research, could provide a clue as to why the composer sometimes behaved in strange and eccentric ways and may also be an explanation for his deafness.

The findings, made by scientists attached to the Health Research Institute in Argonne, Chicago, clear up speculation surrounding the possible source of his illness.

Analysis of his hair clippings showed that he had around 100 times the level of lead that would be normal in a person today.

It is unclear how he came to be so badly poisoned, although one theory is that he could have ingested the lead through mineral waters taken at the many spas he visited.

"It was a surprise, but it stood out like a sore thumb in the analysis," said William Walsh, the director of the research project.

The analysis was carried out on hairs that were supposedly taken from Beethoven after his death at the age of 56, in 1827. The hairs were purchased for $7,300 (£4,980) in 1994, at Sotheby's, by Ira Brilliant of the Centre for Beethoven Studies at San Jose State University.

The 582 strands were said to be a mixture of grey and brown.

Hairs were taken from Beethoven's body by many people prior to his burial.

"He was shorn. He was practically bald when he was buried," said Mr Brilliant, founder of the centre, who bought the hair with Alfredo Guevara, a surgeon from Nogales, Arizona.

The findings also clear up speculation as to whether Beethoven suffered from syphilis. There was no trace of mercury, then the common method of treating the disease. Nor were there any traces of the painkillers used at the time.

Beethoven had constantly complained of illness during his life. But whether the lead poisoning caused his deafness is not certain.

"That's really the million-dollar question," William Meredith, the director of the centre, said.

He said he hoped testing could be carried out on other locks of hair taken before the composer's death.

The conclusions were based on chemical analysis by the McCrone Research Institute in Chicago and images taken at the Argonne national laboratory using an electron accelerator.

Whether the lead poisoning contributed to - or detracted from - his genius is something that hair analysis is still unable to answer.

webTitle: Inspection of site was due on day of crash

fields.headline: Inspection of site was due on day of crash
fields.standfirst:
Admission that condition of line was not good, as broken rail becomes key clue in discovering why express derailed

Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: The section of railway track where a high speed train derailed killing four people was due to be inspected on the day of the disaster, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The section of railway track where a high speed train derailed killing four people was due to be inspected on the day of the disaster, it emerged yesterday.

It was also revealed that the health and safety executive was checking other sections of track away from the Hatfield area, for fear that other faults may exist on sections of the high speed electrified East Coast route to the north from London.

Railtrack, the privatised company which maintains the track, confirmed it was "investigating the possibility of a broken rail being a factor in the tragedy" after one was discovered at the crash scene - although at this stage it was not yet known if the rail broke before the accident or during it.

The company, which admitted yesterday that the condition of the track at Hatfield was "not good", has fought a continuous battle to reduce the number of broken rails on the network.

But after bringing down the annual number, Railtrack had to report a sharp rise in incidents in 1998-99. It was already under fire from both the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, and the railway inspectorate for its inability to drastically reduce the number of broken rails.

In the aftermath of Tuesday's crash, Railtrack imposed a speed restriction on bends for high-speed lines throughout the country. Drivers will have to knock a third off their permitted speed in such areas, inevitably leading to delays for trains and their passengers.

The RMT, the biggest rail union, said it had learned that one of Railtrack's contractors, Balfour Beatty, had reported to Railtrack on an increase in "corner gauge cracking" believed to have been caused by new locomotives. Corner gauge cracking refers to the wearing along the top corner edge of a rail.

The union added that there was no indication of the actions taken by Railtrack arising from this information.

Its assistant general secretary, Vernon Hince, said: "We have constantly drawn attention to the conflict of interest between profit and safety in the privatised railway industry.

"This tragic incident re-emphasises the need for the government to instigate a complete examination of responsibility for rail safety."

Track inspections were less frequent, said the union, and it was "not surprising" that broken rails increased by 42% between 1994-95 and 1998-99.

Both Railtrack and GNER, the train operating company for the East Coast line, agreed the crash would lead to renewed anxiety among passengers.

Railtrack's director for London and the north-east region, Nicholas Pollard, said he was aware that Railtrack could come under heavy fire if the crash were found to be caused by a fault with a rail.

Preliminary investigations had found a smashed rail, he said, but it was not yet clear if the rail had broken before the accident or was a result of the crash.

"A rail is smashed up there. What we have got to understand is why that has happened and how it has happened," he said.

"We have no indication yet of whether it happened before or after."

Speed limits had been imposed on sections of curved track across the UK; different areas of track have different limits, but Railtrack has reduced all the limits by a third - at Hatfield the limit was 115mph, he added.

Railtrack said that the Hatfield area rails were inspected every week. October 10 had been the last time a "track patrol" made a visual inspection; the section had been due to be inspected on Tuesday, but this had not happened before the time of the crash.

Stanley Hart, a principal inspector of railways for the health and safety executive, said vandalism had not been ruled out but seemed "unlikely". He said the executive was checking records of when the rails were last inspected and also checking other rails from the same batch as those at Hatfield.

There were seven inspectors checking the scene of the accident and two inspectors elsewhere, though Mr Hart would not say where.

Yesterday's derailment came on track that is continuously welded - which should greatly reduce the chances of a rail cracking, though defects can appear even in welded areas.

Railtrack said in its most recent annual report that though the improvement in the number of broken rails last year was not enough, track quality was now better than at any time since the mid-1990s.

It has also said that the growth of traffic on the network, particularly heavy freight, has had a major impact on track deterioration. It has been targeting renewals on locations where they would have the most effect.

Railtrack has also spoken of introducing the UIC60 rail, the standard rail used in Europe, which is stronger than that used in the UK and requires less maintenance.

It plans to replace an extra 350 miles of rail over the next five years. A total of 68,000 tonnes of new rail has been ordered for this year - the highest amount since 1988.

Commenting on the possible reasons for the broken rail, David Johnson, a civil engineer with Laser Rail and Technology Services, said last night: "If it is shown to be a rail break, one could question why the leading car had managed to stay on.

"It may suggest that possibly a rail break occurred under the train, as opposed to ahead of it, in which case an inspection may not have revealed anything."

Track damage

These are the most recent figures for broken rails and track buckles. The figures for 1999/00 are provisional.

1995/96 776 breaks 133 buckles

1996/97 739 breaks 47 buckles

1997/98 800 breaks 34 buckles

1998/99 988 breaks 21 buckles

1999/00 949 breaks 64 buckles

Railtrack said in its most recent annual report that though the improvement in the number of broken rails last year was not enough, track quality was now better than at any time since the mid-1990s. It has also said that the growth of traffic on the network, particularly heavy freight, has had a major impact on track deterioration. It has been targeting renewals on locations where they would have the most effect. Railtrack has also spoken of introducing the UIC60 rail, the standard rail used in Europe, which is stronger than that used in the UK and requires less maintenance. It plans to replace an extra 350 miles of rail over the next five years. A total of 68,000 tonnes of new rail has been ordered for this year - the highest amount since 1988. Commenting on the possible reasons for the broken rail, David Johnson, a civil engineer with Laser Rail and Technology Services, said last night: "If it is shown to be a rail break, one could question why the leading car had managed to stay on. "It may suggest that possibly a rail break occurred under the train, as opposed to ahead of it, in which case an inspection may not have revealed anything." Track damage These are the most recent figures for broken rails and track buckles. The figures for 1999/00 are provisional. 1995/96 776 breaks 133 buckles 1996/97 739 breaks 47 buckles 1997/98 800 breaks 34 buckles 1998/99 988 breaks 21 buckles 1999/00 949 breaks 64 buckles

webTitle: Award-winning dome finally given icon status

fields.headline: Award-winning dome finally given icon status
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: At last, somebody loves the Millennium Dome. Last night it won the construction industry's major project award, the trade's Oscar, after failing to even make the shortlists for the upcoming Stirling Prize, or the recent Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors' prizes.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
At last, somebody loves the Millennium Dome. Last night it won the construction industry's major project award, the trade's Oscar, after failing to even make the shortlists for the upcoming Stirling Prize, or the recent Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors' prizes.

It was balm for the bruised hides of the chief executive, PY Gerbeau, his staff, and the architect Lord Rogers, to hear the great white elephant praised as "one of the great icons of the decade". The citation adds: "The dome had to be designed and built to an immutable deadline. Its completion on time and under budget was a stunning achievement."

The judges added: "While this may have been obscured by controversy about content and operation, the architecture, engineering and construction of the dome deserve to be recognised as a triumph."

The "controversy" included the fiasco over ticketing for the opening party, the sacking of the original chief executive, Jennie Page, visitor numbers under half the most optimistic original forecasts, repeated massive injections of extra money from lottery funds, the collapse of its sale to Nomura, police inquiries into fraud in the allocation of construction contracts, and the collapse of the boat firm which had expected to ferry visitors to the Greenwich peninsula.

"It's fantastic," a spokeswoman for the dome said yesterday. "We are never smug about it, but it's hard to be knocked for not winning prizes we may not even have been nominated for, so we are chuffed about this."

Mr Gerbeau announced figures of 28,000 and 24,000 for last Saturday and Sunday, and is predicting large crowds for next week's half term.

The construction industry judges, 12 architects, engineers and contractors chaired by Sir Andrew Turnbull, also made a special award to the Jubilee Line extension - which ran massively over budget, and was so late that the vital link to the dome barely made the New Year's Eve deadline.

Unlike the dome, the handsome new stations have been much admired and have won many prizes. Lord Foster's Canary Wharf station is a contender for the Stirling Prize, the UK's top architecture award.

The judges said the prize went to London Underground for raising the design stakes for future public transport. "While the colossal engineering achievement is less apparent, the quality and variety of the station architecture has won universal acclaim."

Other awards, presented by the construction minister, Nick Raynsford, went to Shell's Skiff gas platform in the North sea, which cost half the price of conventional rigs and won the civil engineering prize, and to the Torrs millennium walkway in Derbyshire, the jubilee campus at Nottingham University, the refurbishment of Glasgow Central station, and the Oresund Link, a bridge and tunnel linking Sweden and Denmark, on which many British engineers and contractors worked.

webTitle: An honourable man in the firing line

fields.headline: An honourable man in the firing line
fields.standfirst:
Gerald Corbett is paying the price for being the voice of the rail industry

Special report: the Hatfield train crash
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Gerald Corbett's job as chief executive of Railtrack - regularly referred to as the most hated corporation in Britain - was never going to be easy. But even the self-assured and confident Mr Corbett, a financial specialist whose career has spanned top jobs in several big companies, could not have imagined the scale of the problems he would face.
fields.body:
Gerald Corbett's job as chief executive of Railtrack - regularly referred to as the most hated corporation in Britain - was never going to be easy. But even the self-assured and confident Mr Corbett, a financial specialist whose career has spanned top jobs in several big companies, could not have imagined the scale of the problems he would face.

Aside from needing to turn a company still imbued with the culture of a rundown nationalised industry into an efficient enterprise delivering top-class customer service and impressive shareholder returns, there were countless other issues to deal with.

There were major incidents such as Tuesday's crash and last year's Paddington disaster, the daily delays and discomfort suffered by commuters, the political pressure piled on by a government determined to improve the rail system, the demands of the new rail regulator and the problems caused by rain, snow, sunshine and wet leaves.

He once described his £400,000-a-year job as "like sitting in a river with a flood coming towards you".

Thinking

A graduate of the "firm but fair" school of management, Mr Corbett is described by colleagues as "an honourable man" who "kicked a lot of ass and got people really thinking about safety and investment".

He was undoubtedly deeply affected by the death of passengers in the recent crashes. This month he passed up an opportunity to defend Railtrack's reputation on a Radio 5 Live phone-in, deciding instead to spend the time with the families of Paddington victims on the anniversary of that crash.

In yesterday's resignation statement he said: "The families of the bereaved are foremost in my mind."

Mr Corbett admitted that Railtrack was Britain's most hated company and cited as evidence the bricks thrown through signal boxes and the spitting and swearing at staff wearing the company's orange jackets. Such incidents shook him to the core, and he took them personally.

But public relations were not always his strong point. In the aftermath of Paddington he pulled out of an interrogation on BBC2's Newsnight after an aide reportedly claimed he was tired, and he walked out on another interview when a reporter asked him if he thought he was likely to face corporate manslaughter charges.

A keen skier, tennis and bridge player, the Oxford and Harvard educated Mr Corbett describes his style as combative and direct. In his three years at Railtrack he has earned a reputation for telling it like it is and taking the blame wherever he believes it is due.

Last July, apologising for long delays - stretching all the way to Glasgow - caused by work on the approach to Euston station in London, he said: "I'm afraid it has been truly dreadful, and it has been largely down to us and our contractors. We are trying to do a hell of a lot of work, and the way we have been doing it has not been good enough. I am very sorry about that."

Railtrack insiders said he was convinced that the government wanted his resignation after the Paddington crash last October, which claimed 31 lives after a Thames Trains driver passed a signal at red.

'Buck stops here'

Tony Blair and John Prescott, transport secretary, were reported to have wanted him to quit, believing that the buck stopped at the door to the chief executive's suite. He refused, but admitted shortly afterwards that he would have tendered his resignation if Railtrack's signalling equipment had been faulty. "If that light had been at green I would have gone. But it was red. There is an important principle at stake here." Only later did it emerge that drivers had made a series of complaints about the faulty signal.

Mr Corbett can be seen as the victim of his own decision, post-Paddington, to assume leadership for the entire industry and become its voice - a modern Sir Peter Parker, renowned British Rail chairman, in a privatised, fragmented business environment - and the fear is that Mr Prescott will now seek more scapegoats, with more heads to roll.

Mr Corbett, 49, took the job at Railtrack after a career in more conventional companies, where the top executives are never likely to become publicly reviled figures.

Married with four children, he started out with seven years as a management consultant. He then spent five years with the electrical retailer Dixons before becoming finance director of the building materials group Redland.

In 1993 he was appointed finance director of the Grand Metropolitan pubs and leisure group, only to lose his job when the company merged with Guinness to form Diageo.

He walked away with a £600,000 pay-off and within months had landed the top job at Railtrack. He was a rail user, as well as the boss, taking a train daily from his St Albans home to Railtrack's head office at Euston station.

Mr Corbett was seen by Railtrack insiders as the leader who told demoralised, traumatised staff that they should not be ashamed but should rise to the challenge of making the railways safer and better. He brought in a new safety director and set up area safety groups.

He was also the first to raise the issue of franchises for train operators, saying that they were too short to make investments count, and to demand government funding because of the economic benefits an improved railway system would bring. Both points have since been taken on board, with longer franchises now being awarded and Mr Prescott's 10-year transport plan.

Mr Corbett's business associates describe him as a superb boardroom operator. One said: "He's incredibly stimulating, extremely bright, a very good lateral thinker who expresses himself very well."

Dubbed "the fat cat controller", he was on a one-year contract and last year received a pay package of £398,000, including £21,000 in perks. However, he turned down a £100,000 performance bonus, as he believed it was inappropriate to accept the payment after the Paddington disaster.

If Mr Corbett does indeed go, it will be viewed as a disaster among train operators. "He bullied and pushed for more investment, encouraged everybody to start thinking in a different way and made as many enemies as friends," a senior source said. "With a strong chairman and board he would have been less in the firing line - they have a lot to answer for."

As for his replacement, one rail insider said: "Ministers won't accept an insider so it will have to be an outsider, maybe from abroad."

webTitle: Elite forces fear the coming of the egalitarian beret

fields.headline: Elite forces fear the coming of the egalitarian beret
fields.trailText: A politically correct US army wheeze to boost morale in the ranks by making berets standard issue has backfired after elite special forces units complained yesterday they were being robbed of a badge of pride.
fields.body:
A politically correct US army wheeze to boost morale in the ranks by making berets standard issue has backfired after elite special forces units complained yesterday they were being robbed of a badge of pride.

Unlike the British army, in which berets are common, US troops either wear peaked caps or "envelope" caps which fold into a flat rectangle. The exceptions are specialised units such as the Rangers, who wear black berets; the Green Berets special forces; and airborne units, which, like their British counterparts, wear maroon berets.

However, the army chief of staff, General Eric Shineski, decided that such discriminatory practices must be brought to an end. He apparently came to this conclusion last week after attending a Green Berets ceremony.

"As I stood looking at those [soldiers], I was reminded of the special significance that the beret has come to symbolise for the United States army," the general announced. "It is time for the entire army to accept the challenge of excellence that has so long been a hallmark of our special operations and airborne units.

"When we wear the black beret it will say that we, the soldiers of the world's best army, are committed to making ourselves even better," he added, describing it as a "symbol of unity".

Black berets are to be issued to the troops next June. But already an angry backlash is gathering steam among special unit veterans' groups, especially the Rangers, whose distinctive black beret risks losing its cachet.

Emmett Hiltibrand, a retired Ranger and Vietnam veteran said: "It's going to look silly. The beret is a symbol of excellence. It is not to be worn by everybody; every Tom, Dick and Harry."

Karl Monger, of the US Army Ranger Association, said he had been inundated with email complaints by veterans.

"The greater issue is that there is a morale problem in the military," Mr Monger said. "It's not something you do by changing hats."

Gen Shineski's announcement comes at a time of low morale, an exodus of junior officers and severe problems in recruiting replacements. The new headgear is supposed to symbolise the half-million-strong army's transition to a lighter, more agile force that can respond more rapidly to distant trouble spots.

Colonel Vince Ogilvie, a Pentagon spokesman, defended the announcement, pointing out that he wore a beret when he served with the 82nd Airborne. He said: "From my point of view, it's a great idea. It really looks great with the uniform."

Fellow officers have put across other, more practical considerations against donning a beret. Unlike the baseball-style cap, the beret has no peak to provide a shield from the rain and sun.

Ralph Peters, a retired lieutenant-colonel, said that British soldiers that he knew do not like the beret. He said the hat was, in any case, a throwback to the 60s.

"It's like being told you can wear bell-bottomed trousers," he added.

webTitle: Shots fired at funeral of Real IRA man

fields.headline: Shots fired at funeral of Real IRA man
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: It was like old times in west Belfast yesterday, as republicans fired a volley of shots over the coffin covered with an Irish tricolour. Except that this time the funeral was for a Real IRA man, and his killers were fellow republicans in the mainstream Provisional IRA.
fields.body:
It was like old times in west Belfast yesterday, as republicans fired a volley of shots over the coffin covered with an Irish tricolour. Except that this time the funeral was for a Real IRA man, and his killers were fellow republicans in the mainstream Provisional IRA.

Only 300 came to send off Joe O'Connor, 26, from his mother's house in Ballymurphy, west Belfast - a fraction of the usual turn-out at such events. He had just left her home on Friday when he was shot five times in the head.

Those there for his cortege included former leading lights in the IRA: Maria Price, convicted of bombing the Old Bailey in 1973; and ex-Belfast commander Brendan Hughes, a one-time associate of Gerry Adams. Also there was Francie Mackey, the Omagh councillor and chairman of the 32-county Sovereignty Movement, allied to the Real IRA.

The republican split came over the Good Friday agreement, with the Real IRA, responsible for the Omagh bomb which killed 29 in August 1998, implacably opposed.

Fresh graffiti around the estate derided the "Ra" in the crudest of terms, while Ms Price made scathing comments during the graveside oration, describing the mainstream group as the armed militia of the British state. At least one leading dissident was threatened on Tuesday by Provisional volunteers.

There are fears that the murder, which may have been a row over the proceeds of smuggled cigarettes, will lead to more and more violence. O'Connor was also said to have goaded several Provisional figures. The Provisional IRA leadership yesterday denied it was responsible for the murder. But the identities of the two hooded gunmen believed to be responsible are well-known, and both belong to that organisation. The theory is that the killing was not a sanctioned operation.

The IRA said: "The malicious accusations suggesting IRA involvement are designed to heighten tensions and promote the agenda of those opposed to the current IRA strategy." It said the Real IRA's threat to retaliate was exacerbating the situation.

webTitle: Hedge fund vultures find rich pickings among poor

fields.headline: Hedge fund vultures find rich pickings among poor
fields.standfirst:
Pofessional creditors make millions by suing debt-laden nations

Special report: debt relief
fields.trailText: Their nickname is the vultures - hedge funds which swoop on struggling economies in the developing world, buying up their debts at a discount then suing the governments for the full face value.
fields.body:
Their nickname is the vultures - hedge funds which swoop on struggling economies in the developing world, buying up their debts at a discount then suing the governments for the full face value.

One New York based fund, Elliott Associates, has made more than $130m (£93m) out of the practice over the past year, according to Jubilee 2000, the lobby group campaigning for the cancellation of unpayable third-world debt.

After winning a landmark judgment against the Peruvian government in the New York courts in October last year, Elliott finally forced Peru to pay it $65m this month, by threatening to seize money which the Lima government had transferred to Wall Street banks to pay other bondholders. The company had bought up the Peruvian debt for $20m.

"It may be business to them but these people are trading in misery," says Liana Cisneros, Latin American coordinator for Jubilee 2000. "To the children of Peru it is schoolbooks, medicines and clean water." Half of Peru's population live in extreme poverty, and debt payments to western creditors consume almost a third of the government's budget, outstripping spending on either health or education.

The case has raised alarm bells in capitals throughout Latin America. The vultures travel in flocks, and are already lining up their next victim.

Ecuador, which has almost completed a deal with its creditors in the aftermath of its debt default a year ago, has already been stung. As long as the creditors were threatening legal action, a negotiated settlement was impossible, and Quito was forced to pay off the vultures, before it could sort out the rest of its debts.

The funds, of course, do not see themselves as parasites, but rather as champions of creditors at a time when, they argue, sovereign debtors are being allowed to walk away too lightly from their legal obligations.

When a defaulting country renegotiates its outstanding debts, creditors typically lose out badly, accepting much less than the face value of the loans. In the case of Ecuador, creditors accepted just 40 cents for every dollar they were owed.

Squeezing the debtor

Except, that is, the vultures who got in first and got a much better deal. But while the funds are raking in the money, concern is growing that the actions of a few rogue creditors are threatening attempts to get bankrupt economies back on the road to financial health.

The US treasury has warned that the funds risk creating "economic chaos" in foreign lands.

Other creditors are not happy either. They say the vultures are pushing their way to the head of the queue, squeezing the maximum out of debtor nations, and leaving less for other investors. Under New York law, a creditor with a tiny proportion of a country's outstanding debt can block a settlement which would be in the interest of the majority of creditors.

The solution, according to international finance experts, is for borrowing countries to include a clause in bond contracts requiring bond holders to agree a settlement by majority vote, rather than allowing one creditor to grab as much as possible through the courts. Such arrangements, known as collective action clauses (CACs ), are already standard in bonds issued in London, but the New York financial community is resistant .

The Wall Street big hitters argue that CACs will increase the cost of borrowing for poor countries because the markets suspect that any country including one is worried about defaulting. Like a pre-nuptial agreement which rather suggests that marriage partners do not trust one another, they say CACs increase perceptions that a country is not creditworthy.

Richard Portes, the head of the London Centre for Economic Policy Research, says comparing borrowing costs for emerging countries in London with New York shows that the claim that CACs increase borrowing costs is untrue. "Except for countries which are at the bad end of the credit ratings and shouldn't be borrowing commercially anyway, CACs result in an improvement in terms," he says.

"It's the same reason that we have bankruptcy laws; you want to have a rules-based procedure to sort things out." Otherwise, he says, countries can end up tied in legal knots by some creditors, as Peru was, to the detriment of others. Making CACs mandatory in bond contracts would avoid the problem.

"The lawlessness of the international financial system gives all creditors enormous power over sovereign debtors," says Ann Pettifor, director of Jubilee 2000.

"We urgently need an independent international insolvency process which takes into account the true cost of repaying debt, and holds creditors as well debts, responsible for the debt crisis."

webTitle: EMI takes secure stride on download path

fields.headline: EMI takes secure stride on download path
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: EMI yesterday moved a step closer to selling music over the web by signing a deal with internet music expert Tornado Group.
fields.body:
EMI yesterday moved a step closer to selling music over the web by signing a deal with internet music expert Tornado Group.

The agreement is for Tornado, a small company formed at the end of last year, to provide EMI with a secure way to sell its digital music files to retailers.

EMI has been one of the pace setters in the race to offer music downloads for sale, countering the threat posed by free downloads.

"Every content owner understands this is where the industry is moving," Ian Watson, Tornado's managing director, said. Tornado's technology would allow digital files to be stored in a secure environment for delivery to retailers.

Jay Samit, EMI's senior vice president, new media, said: "Tornado has the right technical architecture to fit EMI's planned business model for downloads, helping to ensure that the customer receives top-quality music through a reliable and legal service."

EMI in July began North American trials of commercial downloading of music. The company claims it was the largest single release of digital music on the web.

The digital download trial for Europe is expected to be rolled out at the beginning of next year. The cost to retailers and consumers, and the music to be sold have not yet been decided. An EMI spokesman pointed out, however, that the American trial offered a wide mix of music, including artists such as the Spice Girls and Robbie Williams.

EMI has about 1,500 artists and releases more than 1,000 albums a year.

fields.headline: Euro plumbs new depths
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited More guidance at: http://eek.guardianunlimited.co.uk/money/story/0,6812,143048,00.html
fields.trailText: The euro fell to new lows against the dollar yesterday, despite a chorus of support from European policy makers.
fields.body:
The euro fell to new lows against the dollar yesterday, despite a chorus of support from European policy makers.

As turbulence swept though Wall Street, the single currency rallied, but as equity investors regained their nerves, the dollar rebounded, pushing the euro down to 83.30 cents. This was more than a cent below its previous worst, set last month before the Group of Seven industrialised nations entered the market to stabilise it.

It is trading four cents below its levels after the G7 intervention as traders' fears of a repeat of the $50bn support operation fade away.

Yesterday's fall adds to pressure on the president of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg, who will face tough questions at a press conference in Paris today. He is blamed for prompting this week's rout with comments on Monday appearing to rule out immediate intervention.

French finance minister Laurent Fabius said a strong euro was in Europe's interests, backing comments made earlier by the head of the Bank of France, Jean-Claude Trichet, who would be next in line for the presidency of the ECB if Mr Duisenberg were to step down as a result of the row about his comments.

Analysts think it unlikely that Mr Duisenberg will go as a result of this week's barrage of criticism. "The markets' reaction to Duisenberg's departure would be quite possibly positive," said Ryan Shea at Bank One in London. "But in the longer term would it really solve the ECB's problems? It's unlikely. It would also create maybe a sense of crisis."

The euro has given up 28% of its value against the dollar since its January 1999 introduction as investors flock to the buoyant US economy, and has also hit fresh five-month lows against the pound below 58p.

"In the greater scheme of things the US is still a good place to park funds, as the European stock markets are getting hit just as hard as the US stock market," said Lisa Finstrom, currency analyst at Salomon Smith Barney.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Leeson's boss faces queries
fields.body:
Leeson's boss faces queries

Simon Jones, a former boss of rogue trader Nick Leeson, will be questioned over his behaviour in the scandal which brought down Barings Bank.

A tribunal will hear complaints about his role in the management of Barings Futures (Singapore), following an investigation by the accountants' joint disciplinary committee.

These include concerns over the accuracy of statements he made in connection with a 1993 audit and in the directors' statement published in financial documents in the same year.

The tribunal, which is not expected to start until early next year, will also look into liaisons with the Singapore international monetary exchange.

EC investigates £50m aid plan

The European commission said yesterday it would investigate a British government plan to provide £50m over three years to set up and promote regional venture capital funds in England.

"Although the commission is in favour of promoting the supply of venture capital to small and medium-sized enterprises, it believes that care is needed when state aid is proposed to fulfil this objective," the commission said. "In the current case, the state aid proposed does not fall within the existing rules for state aid which can be found compatible with the [EU] treaty."

With unfortunate timing, the opening of the commission's inquiry coincided with the publication of a commission policy document calling for actions to stimulate the development of risk capital in Europe.

The Conservative party was scathing, however, calling on trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers to apologise to small businesses for "wasting their time and money preparing for grants he is not allowed to pay them".

Bank puts price on good name

Making companies publish information on their green and social performance would allow consumers and investors to compare like with like, said Mervyn Pedelty, chief executive of the Co-operative Bank, which is noted for its ethical investment stance.

His call came as the bank published a poll conducted by Mori in which one in six people said they frequently bought or boycotted products because of a manufacturer's reputation. More than half had bought a product and recommended a supplier in the past year because of its responsible reputation.

Ethical consumerism was worth more than £8bn a year to the economy, the bank said.

CGNU defies sales trend

CGNU, Britain's largest insurance group, reported a 21% increase in UK sales in the past nine months. The performance contrasted sharply with its rival Prudential, which announced weaker UK third-quarter sales on Tuesday.

CGNU, created by the merger of CGU and Norwich Union in February, said sales in the UK were up 22% to £5.5bn. Sector analysts said CGNU's figures looked reasonable given the general market slowdown.

webTitle: Parthus chip sends share price smartly upward

fields.headline: Parthus chip sends share price smartly upward
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Irish microchip designer Parthus yesterday shrugged off the gloom surrounding technology shares by introducing a product it claims would place it at the heart of the predicted boom in demand for internet-enabled "smart" mobile phones.
fields.body:
Irish microchip designer Parthus yesterday shrugged off the gloom surrounding technology shares by introducing a product it claims would place it at the heart of the predicted boom in demand for internet-enabled "smart" mobile phones.

Parthus shares bucked the wider sell-off to close up 27.5p at 296.5p after announcing that it had developed a chip called InfoStream in conjunction with palmtop computer maker Psion and chip designer ARM Holdings. Motorola is the first manufacturer to take a licence the product.

InfoStream would be the world's most advanced mobile internet computing platform built on a single chip, the companies said. Parthus chief operating officer Kevin Fielding said the chip would make mobile phones "smart" by turning them into personal organisers without consuming large amounts of battery power.

"There are only about 25m personal digital assistants in use worldwide today but there are expected to be about a billion mobile phones in use in three years' time, so we're attacking a very big market," he said.

"InfoStream offers great functionality and performance, and consumes very little power. If the chip were powered by a traditional AA battery it would run on standby for about five years."

Independent research group Cahners In-Stat predicts there will be 740m mobile internet devices in use by 2004, allowing users continuously to surf the web, send emails, and access address books and diaries.

Several technologies are competing to become the standard platform for these new phones. Infostream has been designed to power Symbian, a Psion backed consortium, but will also run on Pocket-PC, Palm and Linux.

Licence and royalty revenue projections have not been disclosed but income will be shared by the three partners in the InfoStream project, with Parthus taking the bulk.

The Parthus share price rise was also supported by the release of better than expected figures for the three months to September 30. Revenues rose from $4.9m to $8.6m year on year but losses widened from £653,000 to £2.2m.

fields.headline: C&W adds Baynton to stable
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Cable & Wireless took another step in its business-to-business internet strategy yesterday by buying web infrastructure company Baynton Thompson Networks.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless took another step in its business-to-business internet strategy yesterday by buying web infrastructure company Baynton Thompson Networks.

Baynton sells products and services that help businesses to get online quickly and to do e-business securely. Its clients are mainly blue-chip companies.

Cable & Wireless said the deal will enhance its ability to meet demand for internet protocol services.

Peter Green, president, UK, at Cable & Wireless Global, said: "This acquisition and our increased network structure investment represent further stages in the implementation of Cable & Wireless's strategy of focus on IP services to business customers.

"We aim to furnish our business customers with all their IP solutions, including internet access, web-hosting, e-commerce and network integration services."

Cable & Wireless has acquired 13 internet service providers over the past 18 months.

Ken Baynton, managing director of Baynton Thompson Networks, said that the deal with Cable & Wireless would open up a world of opportunity for his company.

Cable & Wireless refused to disclose the exact figure for the acquisition, but said it was in the millions.

The company's share price yesterday dropped 37p to close the session at 823p.

webTitle: School faces action over diabetic ban

fields.headline: School faces action over diabetic ban
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A grammar school which banned a pupil from foreign school trips because he is diabetic is facing an unprecedented legal challenge over its decision, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
A grammar school which banned a pupil from foreign school trips because he is diabetic is facing an unprecedented legal challenge over its decision, it emerged last night.

Tom White, 15, was told he could not travel to France on the watersports holiday with fellow pupils from Clitheroe Royal grammar school in Lancashire even though he had been allocated a place and paid a deposit.

The decision came after he had his first severe hypoglycaemic attack - caused by a drop in blood-sugar levels - on a skiing trip last February.

The school told his parents, Malcolm, 48, and Rosemary, 42, a lecturer of music, that Tom was also unable to take part in a German exchange visit, although he is studying for a GCSE in the language.

The Disability Rights Commission is pursuing legal action against the school in the first case of its kind under the goods and services section of the Disability Discrimination Act 1995.

DRC chairman Bert Massie said: "It is blatantly unfair to ban Tom because he has had one severe hypo. There is no justification for this. A disabled pupil should have access to the same opportunities as everyone else.

"It highlights the urgency to put the education system squarely within the bounds of anti-discrimination law."

Mr White said his son, who developed diabetes when he was nine, was devastated by the ban.

"It is totally unfair to stop him from going on trips with his friends and other pupils just because he has diabetes."

"Tom has never had a day off sick because of the diabetes. He is fit and even played for the school football team.

"There are normally warning signs before a hypo, but because he was in bed at the time he did not recognise the symptoms of drowsiness. He has not blacked out since."

The boy's doctors also confirmed he had good control over his condition, which affects 1.4m people in Britain. He takes two injections of insulin a day, which enables him to lead a normal life.

His father said he had first thought the problem with the school was ignorance of the illness: "We thought that as soon as they heard from an expert, that would be the end of the matter, but they wouldn't talk to the expert. It's an arrogance and conceit which is beyond anything that I have ever come across. They are totally defiant that they will not lose."

Stuart Holt, headmaster of the 1,120-pupil school and sixth form, said he believed it would be unfair on Tom to comment at this point as the case was very sensitive.

But in a letter to Mr and Mrs White he expressed support to teachers who were unwilling or felt unable to take the additional responsibility of looking after the boy.

The letter said: "The teachers who organised the trip were fully acquainted with his condition and knew the steps to take. They took those steps with great skill, great determination and great difficulty. They had difficulty in opening his mouth since his jaw had locked when he passed out.

"In view of this incident I am unwilling for Thomas to join any extra-curricular visits where the organising teacher is unwilling or unable to take this responsibility."

fields.headline: Bacteria revived after 250m years
fields.trailText: Bacteria trapped inside crystals of rock salt for 250m years have been brought back to life, US scientists say today.
fields.body:
Bacteria trapped inside crystals of rock salt for 250m years have been brought back to life, US scientists say today.

Russell Vreeland, of West Chester University in Pennsylvania, reports in Nature that he and colleagues examined a lump of rock salt from the Permian era, 250m years ago, from the Carlsbad region of New Mexico, 569 metres below the surface.

They extracted droplets of brine trapped inside. In the brine, they found bacterial spores. They dropped the spores into a culture dish - and watched the bacteria come back to life.

DNA analysis showed that the apparently long-dead microbes were closely related to two kinds of bacteria known today: one of them is called Bacillus marismortui, or Dead Sea bacteria. Microbiologists have often been astonished by the capacity of some bacteria to survive. Some streptococci from a technician's sneeze survived on an instrument sent to the moon: when the instrument was taken to earth by an Apollo team years later, the bugs began to multiply again.

fields.headline: BT fails to call Genie out of bottle
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: British Telecom faced an embarrassing setback to its mobile internet strategy when it said it did not know when its Genie portal would be fully operational, after more than a week of problems.
fields.body:
British Telecom faced an embarrassing setback to its mobile internet strategy when it said it did not know when its Genie portal would be fully operational, after more than a week of problems.

Britain's leading multi-platform portal has been completely or partly out of action since October 11, when an upgrade scheduled to take 12 hours ran into problems.

The failure could jeopardise BT Cellnet's lead over rival mobile operators, which view portals running on both desktop computers and cell phones as potential money spinners.

fields.headline: Here's to you, Mr Robinson
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Robinson, the wealthy former minister, is now criticised by some for saying too much in his memoirs, by others for saying too little. Even those who have good reason to be relieved taunt him for failing to produce a smoking gun or fire a silver bullet.
fields.body:
Geoffrey Robinson, the wealthy former minister, is now criticised by some for saying too much in his memoirs, by others for saying too little. Even those who have good reason to be relieved taunt him for failing to produce a smoking gun or fire a silver bullet.

In fact, Robinson, correctly dubbed an unconventional minister by Tony Blair, has the ability to unleash the political equivalent of an artillery barrage but never intended to pull the trigger.

I can claim a little responsibility (or if you prefer, part of the blame) for the book, after suggesting to Robinson in the spring of last year that he should write an autobiography and I, then political editor of the Mirror, would help him. Unbeknown to me, Robinson, forced to resign four months earlier over that £373,000 loan, had thought of doing a book while still in government, so within a fortnight we were off.

From the outset Robinson declared he would concentrate on policy and Labour's achievements, though he accepted that his financial relations with Peter Mandelson, Joska Bourgeois and Robert Maxwell - a prominent trio during his controversial spell in office - had to feature. And then there was the question of the millionaire's wider business dealings and funding of the offices of Blair and Gordon Brown which needed to be tackled.

I helped draw up a synopsis and publication was scheduled for the late autumn of 1999. Sitting at his desk in the eighth-floor corner apartment in London's Grosvenor Park Hotel, he would write down his recollections on sheets of A4 paper before asking Colin, his driver, to have them typed up by a former secretary, Margaret Sims, in an office on Coleshill industrial estate just outside Coventry.

Back down to London would come typed copies and a computer disc so, after interviewing him at length about the chapter, I could revise. The words would be batted between us until he was happy with what was to be the final version.

Two things became clear early on, both of them frustrating for a journalist. The first was Robinson's desire to concentrate on policy, the second his stubbornness over the timetable and reluctance to hit the deadline. He was distracted by a DTI inquiry into his business dealings and was under enormous pressure from Gordon Brown not to go into print. Brown, a close friend, repeatedly urged Robinson to abandon a project that would inevitably reignite the party's feuds.

Around the end of July last year, with less than half the pages completed, I wrote my last word (declining any fee) ahead of moving to the Guardian and writing my own book with Nick Cohen, the Observer columnist. Robinson vowed he would finish; I wrongly disbelieved him. Later I learned that Anji Hunter, an aide at No 10, had - despite denials - been dispatched by Downing Street to stop him. Robinson's stubbornness saw him ploughing on to his own timetable and the book Downing Street mocked and dreaded in equal measure was finally completed last summer.

Peter Mandelson suggested this week that Robinson had been manipulated, while one report even claimed that Gordon Brown's former spin doctor, Charlie Whelan, ghost-wrote the memoirs. Both claims are untrue. The Unconventional Minister is very much Robinson's book, which is precisely why he, at root a party loyalist, does not go for the jugular. Whelan wrote not a single word and the sections I was involved with more than a year ago have been extensively reworked.

Out is much entertaining "colour" Robinson always detested - such as the Dover sole, fresh fruit salad and Puligny Montrachet 1986 wheeled up by room service for that fateful Mandelson dinner à deux on May 23 1996. Gone are the slightly more uncomfortable details for Mandelson of house hunting in happier times and how an offer starting at about £100,000 spiralled to £373,000. Missing are the handwritten letters about buying the property, that the Northern Ireland secretary must surely regret sending.

The tone, however, does come across as more hostile to Mandelson, if the Daily Mail's serialisation reflects the actual text, which in turn may reflect Robinson's growing perception as the borrower attempted to shift responsibility on the lender.

Fevered speculation ahead of publication reached preposterous proportions with unfounded Sunday newspaper tales that it could contain compromising photographs of Mandelson. More interesting was speculation over how much Robinson donated to the party and whether he poured cash into Blair's "blind fund" to finance his office.

Robinson can appear disorganised in public, but his private records, including voluminous correspondence and details of financial transactions, are thought to be more ordered. From the start he maintained that no figures would appear, despite reports to the contrary, therefore allowing the speculation to run out of control and William Hague to shout sleaze.

Robinson funded Brown's office in opposition and commissioned expensive research on the windfall tax. He also financed Blair's office (the sum is thought to be below the £250,000 plucked out of the air and now cited as fact) via the Labour party rather than Blair's blind trust. The denials of trustees were accurate, but amid the confusion of recent days at least one character may best be advised to pause before denying support for Blair's office was ever solicited.

Robinson has always been a controversial politician and his memoirs make him more so despite a loyalty to Brown, respect for Blair and his position as a Labour MP requiring him to pull his punches, even if some of those who feature still feel badly bruised. Peter Mandelson is the prime victim, as Robinson declares he has nothing but goodwill for him, while Brown, who failed to halt the book, would not be human if he failed to take some pleasure from its publication.

Is Robinson bitter? He insists not, though No 10 is unconvinced. Is Mandelson, as he believes, the victim of a fiendish Brownite plot to destroy him? Certainly Robinson is no friend, but he could have been more of an enemy.

The Unconventional Minister, as with all memoirs, is partial and we must await more books, hopefully including one from Mandelson, before we have the full picture. As cabinet secretary Sir Richard Wilson put it, during a Whitehall mission to sack Robinson: "Rough old game, politics."

fields.headline: Bishop attacks floral tributes
fields.trailText: The Bishop of Lincoln has warned that the growing modern custom of people leaving tributes at the sites of accidents or to mark the death of public figures risks creating a superficial response to death.
fields.body:
The Bishop of Lincoln has warned that the growing modern custom of people leaving tributes at the sites of accidents or to mark the death of public figures risks creating a superficial response to death.

The Right Rev Robert Hardy questioned the long-term value of flowers, poetry and soft toys, laid most notably after the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, three years ago.

He was criticised, however, by the former agony aunt Claire Rayner for being condescending and insulting.

Bishop Hardy, 54, a veteran survivor of controversy during his 15 years at Lincoln, suggested that such mourners needed help to understand death as well as continuing life for the bereaved. He asked parishioners in the November edition of the Lincoln Bulletin diocesan newsletter: "How can we help them move on from there, from a simple gesture, however sincerely or deeply expressed? How can we begin to open for them the way to deeper and more permanent belief?" The bishop warned that the instant comfort of leaving a teddy bear risked a superficial response to death which was "confused and hardly sustained by Christian belief".

Ms Rayner attacked the comments as condescending and outdated in a society no longer dominated by religious belief. She said: "He is being deeply, grossly unjust. He thinks his method of dealing with bereavement by having services of remembrance is the 'right' way. But in an increasingly secular society he really must stop thinking that his road is the only road."

She also criticised the tone of references to bunches of flowers and teddies as "insulting and having a go at other people's personal taste". She said: "I am not going to criticise the personal taste of other people, and I don't think that he should.

"He wouldn't say this kind of thing if the custom belonged to a foreign culture and was observed by people in this country who are members of ethnic minority groups."

The bishop said the developing trend was a matter of concern because of the way that new ways of mourning were spreading, often with support from churches.

"Whilst services of remembrance are still, thankfully, strongly supported, other forms of memorial are developing in our communities and countryside," he said. "Bunches of flowers, teddy bears, wreaths and crosses appear on grass verges marking a road accident. Churches organise services of remembrance for those who have been bereaved in the year and people light candles or pin cards as tokens of affection and remembrance.

"Understandably, people want to do something. But for a Christian, death must in the end be not only an act of surrender but a form of trust and an expression of self-offering."

The bishop has regularly challenged his flock to debate in the Lincoln Bulletin, in spite of the long-running affair of the Lincoln Cathedral canons, whose dispute with the city's former dean, the Rev Brandon Jackson, split the local church for much of the 1990s. The dean's appointment as a reformer led the then prime minister, Margaret Thatcher, to predict correctly that there would be "blood on the carpet" in her native diocese.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Man cleared of sex assault|Diana producer for Panorama| Lawrences win Europe award|Seed bank will save plants
fields.body:
Man cleared of sex assault

A man was cleared of indecent assault after a Chester crown court jury backed claims that the victim was suffering from false memory syndrome. Edward Williams, 72, was accused of assaulting the woman between 1977 and 1985.

Diana producer for Panorama

Mike Robinson, who produced the Panorama interview with Diana, Princess of Wales, will return to the current affairs series as its editor. He is a documentary producer at the BBC.

Lawrences win Europe award

The parents of the murdered black teenager Stephen Lawrence, Doreen and Neville, have been named Europeans of the Year at the European parliament in Brussels for their struggle against racism. They were presented with the Solidar Silver Rose.

Seed bank will save plants

An 80m seed bank opened yesterday at Wakehurst Place, in West Sussex, in an attempt to save endangered plants. The vault will preserve seeds at -20C (-4F), to save them from extinction.
