fields.headline: Don't blame Gerald
fields.standfirst:
Hatfield rail disaster: Rushing to apportion blame won't help the crash victims

Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: the Hatfield train crash
fields.trailText: The 12.10 from London to Leeds passed the train on which I was travelling 10 minutes before it crashed. I think I recollect it, a flickering distraction from the papers I was reading on my way into King's Cross. I still haven't quite grasped the idea that while I was packing my bag and thinking about my lunch, the other train was being ripped apart.
fields.body:
The 12.10 from London to Leeds passed the train on which I was travelling 10 minutes before it crashed. I think I recollect it, a flickering distraction from the papers I was reading on my way into King's Cross. I still haven't quite grasped the idea that while I was packing my bag and thinking about my lunch, the other train was being ripped apart.

It's hardly surprising that we should wish to find the person responsible for this outrage and vent our fury upon him. It's no less surprising that the man who runs the company charged with maintaining the track should be identified as the culprit. But to blame Gerald Corbett would be to exonerate the real offenders. He has presented himself as a sacrifice, to atone for the multiple failures of our railways. We should reject it.

If the crash was caused by a broken rail, then there can be little doubt that Railtrack is partly responsible. Two months ago the regulator informed the company that its failure to reduce the number of breakages appreciably was a breach of its licence. The health and safety executive had warned that "the risk of derailment from a broken rail is likely to remain significant for some time to come."

But whatever the immediate reasons for the crash might have been, the underlying causes predate Mr Corbett's appointment by decades. The Beeching cuts brought to an end not only a widely accessible railway system, but also a management ethic which, for a few years at least, placed public wellbeing ahead of competing private interests. The haste with which the railway lands were sold and the decision to dynamite some of the bridges - ensuring that the cuts could not be reversed - suggest that a reduction in public spending was not the government's only consideration.

Years later, the Tories' motives for running down the railways also appeared to be mixed. When Mrs Thatcher announced that "nothing can stop the great car economy", she meant it. Just as the traffic light intervals on the old Winchester road were increased in order to make the case for a bypass through Twyford Down more compelling, just as the ferries to the Isle of Skye were allowed to fall apart in order to generate public pressure for a privately financed bridge, so Britain's railways were left to deteriorate to make their eventual privatisation seem more attractive.

As the network fell apart, so our faith in public provision waned, and our participation in the great car economy - socially fragmented, non-unionised and lucratively unsustainable as it was - increased. By the time privatisation was mooted, our suspicion of the government's proposals was matched only by our loathing of British Rail.

Fragmentation of the privatised network by the Conservatives, with its accompanying diffusion of responsibility for safety, makes sense only as a strategy for impeding renationalisation. By insisting that regulation should be as light as possible, by withdrawing subsidies from the railways and pouring them into roads, they exposed British people to the dangers both of a dysfunctional rail network and of the far more hazardous cars in which we were forced to travel.

Privatising the railways both diffused and confused responsibility. Gerald Corbett's fiduciary duty forced him to place the interests of his shareholders ahead of those of his passengers. While directors of companies can be imprisoned for failing to discharge their responsibility to keep the share price as high as possible, the Home Office's new corporate manslaughter proposals would submit them to no more drastic penalty than disqualification for killing their customers. Money, in company law, is better protected than human life.

The current government seems to understand why our railways are failing, so why are its proposed solutions so timid? Soon after taking office, John Prescott rejected the idea of renationalisation, on the grounds that it would cost some £4bn. Yet now he proposes to pour £60bn into the privatised railways, while reclaiming only a limited amount of regulatory control. It is hard to see why the new public investment should not be reclassified as equity, endowing the government with a controlling financial stake in the network. It is still harder to see why it wants to do to air traffic control and the London Underground what the Tories did to the railways.

By loading the problems of our railways on to the shoulders of one man, we relieve the government of its responsibility to reclaim real public control over the way they are run. The people on the train that passed mine deserve solutions, not scapegoats.

fields.headline: NTL obstructed from ambitious goal
fields.standfirst: League bosses fumble the ball
fields.trailText: The meeting of Premier League chairmen in central London today promises to be an entertaining affair. The bosses of England's top 20 clubs are gathering to debate how the £1.4bn revenues they secured from the renewal of broadcasting contracts in the summer should be distributed. A split already exists, with the small clubs demanding more from the big sides. But now the kitty is more than £328m short.
fields.body:
The meeting of Premier League chairmen in central London today promises to be an entertaining affair. The bosses of England's top 20 clubs are gathering to debate how the £1.4bn revenues they secured from the renewal of broadcasting contracts in the summer should be distributed. A split already exists, with the small clubs demanding more from the big sides. But now the kitty is more than £328m short.

Yesterday NTL, the cable company-cum-broadcaster, pulled out of a three-year deal to buy the rights to 40 Premiership games on a pay-per-view basis. When the deal was struck in June no one could understand how NTL, already carrying debts of around £9bn, could make it pay. A simplistic calculation suggested NTL needed to recoup £2.7m a game. At £4 per punter per match, that meant a regular crowd of 675,000 - a heroic expectation if, for example, Coventry were playing Southampton.

Remember, too, these were only going to be the second or third best games available in any weekend. BSkyB, holder of primary rights, usually has first call. With NTL's share price up 6% yesterday, the market clearly thinks it was right to get out.

Yet analysts who know NTL believe it could have picked up around 1m affluent football nuts happy to add a £100 NTL season ticket to their Sky Sports subscriptions. They could have picked up a further 500,000 who regard SkySports as too expensive. After tax these fans might have added an extra £120m to NTL's revenue.

But NTL's trick was based on not selling the football package at all. Instead, it is thought to have been planning to bundle footie access with its overall cable and telephone service - a highly attractive "free offer" that might have attracted as many as 1m customers.

Using an industry standard "value per customer" figure of £2,000, the extra 1m customers which NTL might have could have been worth an extra 25% on its (Nasdaq) market capitalisation, making the original £328m deal look cheap.

Instead, it seems, the league started wittering on about how it did not want its precious game touted as a freebie, bundled in with things such as off-peak telephony charges and interactive shopping channels.

Faced with league intransigence, NTL walked away. Whether it will have to pay a break clause is unclear. The Premier League might now try to set up its own channel or NTL could return with a shorter-term offer. BSkyB, delighted with yesterday's events, is unlikely to be far from the action.

Shared misery

How do you read a market where there is a bloodbath in all things technology-related and yet the technology-laden Nasdaq composite index in the US ends up on the day?

The short answer for longer-term equity investors is that you do not bother. You close your eyes and repeat the mantra that, ever since proper records began, the return on equities has vastly outstripped alternatives such as cash or gilts. Real crashes or bear markets are rare. There were two last century, in 1929 and 1974.

That said, markets are under stress. Volatility feels as if it is becoming increasingly extreme. Any froth lingering from the internet investment bubble has been well and truly blown away. The spreads between government stock and corporate bonds are exploding in a fashion not seen since the darker moments of the Asian crisis.The cost of capital for companies is going up.

Unilever is already feeling the pain. It is smack bang in the middle of selling $7bn worth of paper to help pay for Bestfoods in the US, and the coupon (or rate of interest payable) is rising fast.

One top American fund manager, William Gross of Pimco, was quoted yesterday as saying that the fixed-income market looked as uncertain as he had seen in 30 years. He is putting his clients' cash into mortgage-backed securities and keeping a tin hat to hand.

It is likely we will see the physical symptoms of all this stress over the coming weeks. It will not feel like an or derly retreat after a period of irrational exuberance. It will hurt.

Fall guy jumps

In the aftermath of the Paddington rail disaster, Gerald Corbett's boardroom colleagues at Railtrack left him to swing in the breeze, put up each night to apologise, offer sympathy to relatives of the dead and promise there would be no skimping in making the railways safe.

Yesterday, after the third serious crash in three years, Mr Corbett made it clear he was not willing to go through the media mincer again. Last night Railtrack's board was in emergency session, presumably trying to think of a way to avoid accepting his resignation.

This is a tricky one for Sir Philip Beck, Railtrack's supposed chairman. Without Mr Corbett he might have to put his own head above the parapet.

webTitle: St Michael's tonsure given a rebranding

fields.headline: St Michael's tonsure given a rebranding
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer will for the first time sell a range of goods under a brand name other than M&S or St Michael.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer will for the first time sell a range of goods under a brand name other than M&S or St Michael.

The ailing retailer, which is fighting to win back shoppers who have become increasingly keen on brand labels, has signed up "internationally renowned hairdresser" Martyn Maxey to develop "an exclusive new designer range of haircare products and accessories bearing the stylist's name".

The labelling - which will be "MM Martyn Maxey" - is a radical departure for M&S. The retailer has often used designers in the past, but would not agreed to put their names on the goods they have developed with the store.

It uses Julien Macdonald, Betty Jackson and Katherine Hamnett to design its prestige Autograph collection, but their names do not feature on the clothes or in the special Autograph stores-within-stores.

Similarly television make-up expert John Gustafson does not have his signature label on a range of cosmetics he has developed with M&S.

The new branded haircare range is the first sign that Marks & Spencer is willing to follow the lead of Debenhams, which exploits the names of a team of named designers to drive sales. On Tuesday Debenhams said it expected sales of its Designers at Debehams labels to double in the coming year.

According to the publicity material for the new hair products "the introduction of the Martyn Maxey range is the latest weapon in M&S's campaign to revitalise its image".

M&S beauty business director Jacqueline Paterson said her strategy was to "offer inspirational products" and it was "important to underpin this strategy with expertise by bringing in leading experts on specific ranges".

A spokesman for M&S admitted that Mr Maxey was not a celebrity TV crimper but said: "He is very well known in the industry."

Mr Maxey, 40, has three London salons - one in Mayfair and one each inside the Harbour Club and the Riverside Club - two of the capital's smartest health clubs.

His list of famous clients, she said, included Anneka Rice, Anna Ford, racing driver David Coulthard, and Elle Macpherson, the Australian supermodel.

fields.headline: Sainsbury cuts 900 staff
fields.trailText: Sainsbury is cutting its entire in-house IT and systems departments and transferring the 900 computer staff - and the work they do - to external consultants Andersen Consulting.
fields.body:
Sainsbury is cutting its entire in-house IT and systems departments and transferring the 900 computer staff - and the work they do - to external consultants Andersen Consulting.

The decision to outsource all Sainsbury's information technology functions was confirmed by chief executive Sir Peter Davis as he updated the City on his progress in turning around the supermarket group.

Sir Peter said he could not promise the staff affected that their jobs would be safe at Andersen, and the supermarket's senior managers are still in discussions with the staff council. But he added: "We have had sensible discussions with the colleagues concerned. And some will definitely have better opportunities with Andersen".

Buying IT capacity from outside the organisation is one of three strands of Sir Peter's recovery strategy. He also told analysts that improvements to the group's depot infrastructure were underway, and that investment in stores would soon start to pay dividends.

Three new depots are to be built to improve distribution and Sir Peter promised that the entire store estate of 440 outlets would be upgraded in the coming three years.

Every store was being as sessed, he said, and a handful will be closed down, but no more details will be available until the end of November, when the group announces its half-year results.

Sainsbury is now moving fast to catch up the ground it has lost in recent years to Tesco. A range of 350 premium food items labelled Taste the Difference is about to be launched to rival Tesco's Finest range.

At the same time, Sir Peter is beefing up the store's e-commerce home delivery service.

While Tesco established a store-based system which now covers the bulk of the country, Sainsbury was left standing with grand plans for huge dedicated e-commerce depots. Yesterday Sir Peter said he would have 33 stores nationwide and two dedicated centres offering "a hybrid service" by next April. They will be able to service 60% of the country.

Asked how long it would take to catch up with Tesco's internet shopping service, Sir Peter said: "I don't want to get into that."

He said that the transformation programme the group had embarked upon would deliver cost efficiencies of £600m a year and that profits and sales were meeting targets. There was no news on the future of Homebase, which is expected to be sold.

The shares climbed 25.75p to 379p.

webTitle: Red tape still needs cutting says Haskins

fields.headline: Red tape still needs cutting says Haskins
fields.trailText: The government was yesterday criticised by its own watchdog for the excessive levels of regulation still being introduced.
fields.body:
The government was yesterday criticised by its own watchdog for the excessive levels of regulation still being introduced.

Officials frequently assume regulation is the only way to achieve policy objectives and are too eager to follow European Union directives to the letter, according to the better regulation task force.

Its report will embarrass the government which is keen to trumpet its anti-red tape measures. What is worse for the administration is that ministers are under fire from a prominent businessman and Labour peer Lord Haskins.

Ministers were found guilty of over-reacting to media stories leading to "unnecessary, ineffective regulation" such as labelling genetically modified foods in restaurants.

Lord Haskins, chairman of the task force and also chairman of Northern Foods, praised the government for introducing the panel for regulatory accountability and the small business service, but believes "more remains to be done" in coming months.

"This government is doing rather better than the last one and is approaching it [cutting red tape] in an orderly, structured way," he said. "Tony Blair takes a lot of interest in the issue ... but there's a culture in Whitehall we need to get rid of - it's the nature of bureaucrats generally that if you've got a problem, create a regulation."

Regulation should be flexible and targeted rather than universal. "There is a need to minimise financial red tape," said Lord Haskins, who believes good self regulation can improve standards and performance of trade bodies.

Research has shown Britain has the lowest level of product market regulation of all countries in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, but these regulations are strangling the smaller firms.

fields.headline: Lehman's placing hits trouble
fields.trailText: Shares in Baltimore Technologies came under severe pressure yesterday as the internet security specialist attempted to place a huge lump of stock with City institutions.
fields.body:
Shares in Baltimore Technologies came under severe pressure yesterday as the internet security specialist attempted to place a huge lump of stock with City institutions.

At the close Baltimore shares were off 66p, or 12.94%, at 444p as rumours spread through the market that Lehman Brothers, one of the company's two brokers been unable to find enough buyers for the stock.

A spokesman for Baltimore would only say that the placing had "proceeded in line with expectations" and could not elaborate further.

According to one tale doing the rounds late in the session Lehman had managed to find a home for just 20m of some 38m shares it had been trying to place despite offering the stock at an alleged 440p. While Lehman insiders denied the charge, rivals said the bank could be sitting on £90m of unshiftable stock.

"It's madness to try and place that much stock on a day like this," one dealer said referring to the performance of the technology heavy Nasdaq index, which had dipped more than 200 points shortly after opening yesterday.

The placing was related to Baltimore's acquisition of email security company Content Technologies, which was approved by shareholder yesterday.

When the deal was announced in September, Baltimore said it would pay for Content with 91m Baltimore shares. The Dublin-based firm said that between 17m and 24m of those shares would be sold by Content shareholders in a subsequent placing once the deal had been approved.

The placing, it said, would be timed to coincide with another by Baltimore to raise up to $100m (£69m) for working capital and general corporate purposes.

But Baltimore, which has seen it share price halve since trading around 980p at the start of September, was not the only tech stock to fall sharply yesterday. IT services group Logica tumbled 220p to £16.30p, while internet group Freeserve shed 20.75p to 160p, and ARM Holdings lost 35p to 700p all hit by the performance of their US rivals. The hi-tech benchmark Techmark index fell 146.6 points to 3,215.34.

There was more pain for Anglo-Dutch IT services group CMG as the earnings downgrades continued to roll in. Yesterday was the turn of Deutsche Bank to slash profit forecasts 9.7% this year and 7.3% in 2001. Like Lehman Brothers on Tuesday, Deutsche blamed a higher than expected interest cost but also its "more conservative expectations" for the core systems integration business.

With the CMG trading on 71 times 2000 earnings, this was all too much for some investors who simply cut their holdings. The shares ended 77p lower at £10.43.

These falls came as the blue chips endured a session of wild price swings that at one point saw the FTSE 100 decline more than 180 points before recovering to close 55 points lower at 6,148.2.

Those looking for an explanation had to look no further than New York where disappointing figures from IBM and some inflation unfriendly economic data had sparked an early sell-off. At one point Dow Jones industrial average was off 400 points, before recovering its poise.

Investors, however, remained unconvinced and headed for safer stocks such as food retailers and utilities.

Sainsbury rose 25.75p to 379p also helped by a positive trading statement, in which the supermarket group estimated it would achieve massive cost savings by the time its three-year cost cutting drive is completed. There was also encouraging news on margins.

Tesco, up 7p to 268p, was also in demand, underpinned by a positive note from Schroder Salomon Smith Barney. Despite the 45% rise of Tesco shares in the past year, Schroder believes they have further to go and has set a 310p target price.

fields.headline: Vaccine doubts hit Cantab
fields.standfirst: Shares fall by two thirds as drug trials failure calls firm's technology into question
fields.trailText: One of Britain's oldest biotechnology companies, Cantab Pharmaceuticals, saw its market value collapse by two thirds yesterday after the failure of a vaccine for genital warts triggered questions about the viability of its technology.
fields.body:
One of Britain's oldest biotechnology companies, Cantab Pharmaceuticals, saw its market value collapse by two thirds yesterday after the failure of a vaccine for genital warts triggered questions about the viability of its technology.

The vaccine, called TH-GW, was supposed to prevent recurrence of genital warts when given to patients who had suffered a severe outbreak. However, it proved no more effective than a placebo in a clinical trial involving more than 200 people. Cantab announced it was axeing the product after its development partner, SmithKline Beecham, pulled out.

Cantab's chief executive, Jurek Sikorski, admitted the outcome was "disappointing" but launched a scathing attack on the market's reaction, after watching the company's shares slump 156p to 76.5p.

Mr Sikorski said: "This was one of our two lead programmes and it did account for a not insignificant proportion of the value of the company - but that nowhere near justifies the brutal response of the market today."

He pointed out that Cantab still had six vaccines in clinical trials, giving it a broader portfolio than many of its rivals. "I am totally bemused, and stunned, by this reaction," he said.

Cantab's products are based on three different technology platforms, and Mr Sikorski said only one other vaccine - for cervical lesions known as dysplasia - was comparable. He said: "There is a possibility that they are sufficiently similar that the result may be the same for the dysplasia vaccine, but then again it may not be the same." He insisted that all the group's other vaccines were "quite different", including products for genital herpes, cervical cancer and nicotine addiction.

Analysts were split on the implications for Cantab. Howard Miller of Teather & Greenwood said: "We don't know why this has happened yet - it doesn't affect the validity of Cantab's other products."

Nick Woolf, biotech analyst at ABN Amro, who had been expecting TH-GW to reach the market in 2003 and achieve peak sales of $400m (£278m) within a few years, said profitability had been pushed back at least one year to 2005. He cut his rating on the stock to "hold" from "undervalued".

But another analyst said: "There are two other products using the same type of technology - it casts doubt on both of them. You could even be very pessimistic and say this casts doubt on the whole area of immunotherapy."

Founded in 1989, Cantab was one of the country's pioneers in biotechnology. However, the company has had a tough year - merger talks with rival Peptide Therapeutics failed during the summer, and Glaxo Wellcome pulled out of a partnership deal for a herpes vaccine, due to its imminent merger with SmithKline. The company's 145 staff were summoned to a meeting to hear of the setback yesterday morning. Mr Sikorski said: "The mood is one of reality - people know this is part of the nature of biotech."

Valued at just £34m, Cantab is now considered a takeover target - North American vaccine firms such as Medimmune and StressGen were mentioned as possible bidders.

webTitle: Blacks boss warns middle market retailers

fields.headline: Blacks boss warns middle market retailers
fields.trailText: Blacks Leisure's acting chief executive, Tom Knight, issued a grim Christmas warning yesterday for any retailers trapped in the middle market of the retail sector.
fields.body:
Blacks Leisure's acting chief executive, Tom Knight, issued a grim Christmas warning yesterday for any retailers trapped in the middle market of the retail sector.

While most stores say that trading conditions on the high street remain tough, the Blacks boss said: "The outlook for Christmas is promising if you are in the discount business or the aspirational market. But for anyone stuck in the middle, then woe betide."

Blacks was unveiling headline profits up 43% to £7.2m, but the figures were inflated by the sale ofthe company's 40% stake in the Fila sports brand. Stripping out the effect of that sale, comparable profits were ahead 8% at £5m.

Turnover was up 78%, mainly because of the acquisition of The Outdoor Group, which brought more than 200 Millets and Free Spirit fascias. It now has a total of 463 outlets.

Blacks said its sport and fashion division, dominated by 168 First Sport outlets, was performing well with like-for-like sales ahead 8.5%.

The shares were unchanged at 231.5p.

fields.headline: At this price? Chorion
fields.trailText: Former First Leisure boss John Conlan has carved out an unusual business in Chorion, which owns trendy London nightspots such as Tiger Tiger and Bar Madrid, in addition to the intellectual property rights to Noddy.
fields.body:
Former First Leisure boss John Conlan has carved out an unusual business in Chorion, which owns trendy London nightspots such as Tiger Tiger and Bar Madrid, in addition to the intellectual property rights to Noddy.

Mr Conlan created Chorion from the ashes of Trocadero - the property company based on the hi-tech attraction off Piccadilly Circus, which ran into trouble several years ago. On the bars side, his strategy is to go for the more affluent over-25 professional crowd. As he put it: "Not your Sharon and Tracey mob."

The company yesterday announced plans to roll out Tiger Tiger, an all-day bar, restaurant and nightclub operation in Haymarket which has made £1m of profits in six months. A further five outlets are to open by the end of next year, at a cost of about £3m a time.

Tiger Tiger will be restricted to large sites of more than 20,000 sq ft, and Mr Conlan believes there is scope for perhaps 15 in big cities around the country.

Several other bar concepts could be ready for roll-out soon - On Anon and Oxygen, among others, have attracted a big following in the West End.

On the other side of the business, Chorion owns the rights to Enid Blyton's literary canon, and the company has a 64% stake in Agatha Christie's creations.

These are immensely lucrative - a Hollywood film of her Poirot is a possibility, and the BBC is trying out a series based on the characters Tommy and Tuppence who appear in several of her thrillers.

Stockbroker Teather & Greenwood points out that other intellectual property companies such as HIT Entertainment are valued at more than 100 times future earnings, against Chorion's rating of just 26.5.

A demerger of the two sides of the business is likely next year and both elements appear to have decent potential. The shares are due a substantial rerating. Buy.

fields.headline: Investors shop around
fields.trailText: Schroder Salomon Smith Barney has called time on the advance of Next, the star of the British retailing scene.
fields.body:
Schroder Salomon Smith Barney has called time on the advance of Next, the star of the British retailing scene.

In contrast to the rest of the sector, Next shares have been a strong performer this year rising from 430p in March to 676p last night. Investors have fallen in love with the company because of its ability to keep churning out healthy increases in sales.

But Schroder believes things have gone far enough and is advising its clients to take profits and look for better value elsewhere in the sector.

The broker points out that the valuation gap which made Next so attractive early this year has disappeared. Next, it notes, now has a similar stock market rating to Marks & Spencer and Kingfisher.

Schroder suggests that investors look at Debenhams, for which it has set a 230p target price. Last night their shares closed at 207p, up12.75p.

webTitle: Arts: What determines how long we spend looking at a painting

fields.headline: How do you view?
fields.standfirst: What determines how long we spend looking at a painting? Is it just whether or not we like it?  Jonathan Jones  reports
fields.trailText: What determines how long we spend looking at a painting? Is it just whether or not we like it? Jonathan Jones reports
fields.body:
The difference between a good and bad work of art is how long it detains us. When you walk into an art gallery there is no start or finish, no interval. You walk around, look at what takes your fancy, move on, stop, go away, come back. It's a cruel, casual blood sport. Piles of rubbish forming the silhouette of faces, or a photograph of the artist naked in a beach hut are nice ideas but essentially one-liners - you move on quickly. The simplest, most final way to dismiss a work of art is to say it does not reward serious attention.

When you stand before great art, it seems impossible to look for too long. Caravaggio's Supper at Emmaus (1601) in the National Gallery has this effect on us. Caravaggio's painting is the document of a single moment, like a photograph, when two of Christ's disciples recognise their risen Lord. They register this realisation not in prayer, not by going down on their knees, but with the kind of stupid, stunned gestures that people might make seeing a goal on TV - pure physical shock. One disciple is pushing back his chair as if about to jump up and run outside. The other spreads his hands, dumbfounded. Only the waiter or host standing behind Christ looks dully, not realising what this moment is about. It is a split second of frozen action, but it contains infinities. In recognising the resurrected Christ, the disciples see that death is not an end, that human time has no meaning. The clock has stopped.

Painting can make you feel all this, drag you out of time, yet it does it through material means, through technique.

Telling Time, an exhibition that has just opened at the National Gallery, examines the ways in which painters since the Middle Ages have tried to mark the passing of time. It includes what is believed to be the first blurred image of a rotating wheel in art, in Nicolas Maes's Woman Spinning (c.1642). The exhibition also incorporates a fantastic machine, devised by scientists from the applied visual research unit at the Institute of Behavioural Sciences at Derby University, that tracks the movements of your eyes as you look at a painting. The National Gallery is conducting a sinister experiment on its visitors. You sit down and study an image of a painting in the collection on a screen. As you do so, your eye movements are monitored, and the information collated with other results to find out how far a painting determines the way we look at it.

The results so far are not stunning. When people look at Albert Cuyp's The Maas at Dordrecht in a Storm (1645-50), a painting of sail boats being thrown about on a tempestuous sea off the Dutch shore, they look first and longest at the boats. When they contemplate Paul Delaroche's sentimental 19th-century history painting The Execution of Lady Jane Grey (1833), their eyes tend to be drawn to the central white-clad figure of the kneeling woman about to have her head cut off.

The most interesting thing that the research has confirmed so far is that it is impossible to take in the whole of a painting at once. There is no such thing as a totalising gaze - the look that comprehends everything - because the nature of visual perception is momentary, partial and fragmentary. Our visual field is very small and precise. Look at someone's face and you are aware of their surroundings and dress only as blurred secondary information. When we contemplate a painting we are not looking equally at all parts at the same time (unless we move so far back that it becomes one small image). The National Gallery's eye-tracking machine demonstrates that we look at one small area of the canvas, then another, in short glances. Yet ultimately, we connect the dots to make sense of the painting, feel its total presence, in our mind.

Telling Time is unsure if it wants to be scholarly or populist, but it is this most gimmicky aspect that raises the most interesting questions. How does the succession of glances that the eye-tracking machine records lead to the overwhelming effect of a painting like Caravaggio's Supper at Emmaus? When you look at a painting, your brain breaks it up into high spots and low spots, faces, fruit, chairs, shadows. Like a film camera wielded by a Soviet montage director, you take in the world (the real world as well as that of painting) in a series of glances. William Hogarth's paintings Before and After (1730-1) in Telling Time invite and celebrate this type of looking. Hogarth's two paintings of a young couple just before and just after sex are designed to be seen side by side, so your eyes move from one to the other, comparing sections of each picture, contrasting the woman's modest shying away from her lover's proposal Before with her flushed look After; the man's foppishly neat hair Before with his tousled locks After. Hogarth's materialist, low art revels in the fragmented looking documented by the eye-tracking machine. Art that enjoys and acknowledges the glancing way we see things is anti-spiritual, time-bound art.

This brings us back to Caravaggio's Supper at Emmaus. Does this painting feel like something you could look at for ever simply because of the richness of glances that it provokes? A work of art that you can take in at a glance is, by definition, inadequate. It is in a glance that the two disciples have recognised the man who walked beside them, yet for us there are so many points of visual fascination: the open palm of a hand, another hand raised in blessing, the bowl of fruit dangerously poised on the edge of the table, the bread. It is a low, ordinary scene - a scene in an inn in 17th-century Italy where Caravaggio might have drunk with men like these. But the longer you study the painting, the more you become aware that each gesture, far from being random, is intimately connected to everything else in a symbolic tableau. The hand of Christ elicits the outstretched hands of the disciple in a way that instantaneously connects the Last Supper, the Crucifixion and the Resurrection. The longer you look, the more you read the painting as a whole rather than merely registering separate visual details.

In the end, Caravaggio's painting is not about light hitting the eye in a series of moments. It is about the mind: it is intended to be read, interpreted. This is the difference between art we just walk past and art we could look at for ever. The eye-tracking machine demonstrates what happens when your eye moves across the surface of a painting. And what the banality of this information reveals is that in the end our relationship with art is not merely visual. After looking at The Supper at Emmaus, you surrender exhausted, go to the museum shop, buy a postcard, plan to come back and look again. You feel that you have failed - and perhaps that is the definition of a great work of art. It outfaces you.

 Telling Time is at the National Gallery, London WC2 (020-7747 2885), till January 14.

fields.headline: Changing of the guard
fields.standfirst: Last week, The Guardsman opened in the West End. Next week it will close. Here, its star Michael Pennington reveals what went wrong
fields.trailText: Last week, The Guardsman opened in the West End. Next week it will close. Here, its star Michael Pennington reveals what went wrong
fields.body:
John Gielgud once said that you work harder at your failures than your successes, and since any play is a great experiment, it's important to look back and see what went wrong. His much-loved voice rings in my ears this week.

The work itself is a private business, and nobody else is much interested in that. But the story behind The Guardsman's closure is already seeping out into the public domain and looks likely, unlike the show, to run and run. So: no witch-hunt, but some facts.

The producer of the play is Paddy Wilson. His temporary landlords at the Albery are the Ambassadors Theatre Group. The critical reception for the show has been poor, but not that poor - the Times was good, the Guardian too to some extent, and there have been good television reviews. The word-of-mouth is good, and advance bookings have built healthily since the first performance on October 4. Under normal circumstances, the show could have looked forward to an honourable two or three month run.

As it turns out, it never really had a chance. Before The Guardsman opened, plans appear to have been already advanced to bring The Mystery of Charles Dickens into the Albery early in November. During its last week on tour, The Guardsman company and staff were requested by Paddy Wilson to take a salary cut, which in the case of some of the principals amounted to 80% of their negotiated fees, although the advance was not bad for a new and unfamiliar play. The proposal was that the cast would return to their original salaries in week three of the London run, and be reimbursed what they had deferred for the first two weeks by the end of week six. The reality was that the sixth week was unlikely to be available to us; the third barely. Paddy Wilson assures me that he didn't know this.

The company eventually agreed to the deferment. In this event, all it has really achieved is to reduce Paddy Wilson's costs on the show's demise.

Without a rush on the box office, there seem to have been no refunds available to "nurse" the production through its critical first two weeks. Paddy Wilson attributes the problem to the loss of an investor halfway through the pre-London tour (a loss that Lady Bracknell might have described as "careless"); I am not convinced that the show's investment base was secure from the start. To me, there were signs of under-resource and false economies even then; and Equity, who require a deposit equivalent to two weeks' actors' salaries at the beginning of such a project, didn't get it until just before the West End opening.

The relationship between a producer and a theatre owner is a complicated one; Ambassadors Theatre Group had hesitations about the show's "legs" in any case. Suppose they had doubts about receiving their due rents from the producer as well, and you can well see that they might begin to make other arrangements for the Albery and to see the Guardsman as a brief "filler".

Still, a show which clearly had limited but still honourable expectations in the West End has sunk almost without trace. As I write, some of those associated with the production are still owed money, quite apart from the pay deferment. All are embarrassed to be the last to hear what much of London seemed to know. Producers are a hardy and courageous lot in a high-risk business, and theatre-owners need to keep their lights on, but it can be difficult to judge how unlucky a producer has to be before he is to blame. For a hard-working cast and staff, it can be difficult, too, to detect the fault-lines beneath, let alone know what to do about them. For both parties, as Giuelgud said, failure can be fascinating. RIP.

fields.headline: No: 1744
fields.standfirst: Robson Green
fields.trailText: Robson Green
fields.body:
Age:
38.

Appearance:
Weather-beaten action man (retd) with unconvincing facial scarring.

Role:
Weather-beaten action man (in service) with convincing facial scarring.

Hang on, didn't he used to sing with that other bloke out of Soldier, Soldier? Jerome, wasn't it?
Too long ago, too painful to remember, and far too easy a target for Pass notes.

Really?
Well, no, but let's just say that Robson has continued to supply the cruel streak in us with plenty of fresh ammunition.

Soldier, Soldier?
At least people used to watch that.

Of course. He's the middle-aged woman's pin-up, the Geordie Guy Ritchie, more vulnerable than Sean Bean, tougher than Hugh Grant.
And less popular with the viewing public than Noel Edmonds.

Why so harsh? He was great in... er...
The Last Musketeer, in which crook-with-a-heart Robson somehow wangles a job teaching fencing at a posh girls' school? Blind Ambition, in which athlete-with-a-heart Robson wins a gold medal at the Paralympics, but loses his wife to his coach?

Must have missed those.
They were slammed as "sentimental gush" by a TV critic who had clearly never heard Robson and Jerome do Unchained Melody. Just 6.9m viewers tuned in to watch Blind Ambition, a figure reputedly causing ITV chiefs to wonder if it was really so clever to have tied the flinty-eyed one into a "golden handcuffs" deal worth £3.75m.

So is ITV looking to escape?
The channel is playing it cool. "Robson Green is one of our most popular acting stars," says a spokesman.

Does he mean actor?
Don't count on it.

Most likely to:
Participate in a testosterone-fuelled action sequence before revealing a tender side.

Least likely to:
Need to borrow a fiver.

Do say:
"6.9m viewers? Remind me again what the BBC's Ten O'Clock News is getting..."

Don't say:
"Oh, my love, my darling, I've hungered for your touch. Etc, etc, etc."

fields.trailText: So is privatisation compatible with rail safety? Despite Tuesday's tragedy death is still, mercifully, a rare event on the railways. Some 10 people are killed each and every day on Britain's roads. Rail remains a safer way to travel.
fields.body:
So is privatisation compatible with rail safety? Despite Tuesday's tragedy death is still, mercifully, a rare event on the railways. Some 10 people are killed each and every day on Britain's roads. Rail remains a safer way to travel.

Also, there is no clear trend in deaths since privatisation. The deaths at Ladbroke Grove, north London, a year ago upped the number of rail deaths in 1999-2000 to the highest figure for a decade. But similar tragedies happened in the days of British Rail. The Clapham rail crash in 1988 resulted in 35 deaths. The chart shows accidents: some increase but not much since Railtrack was sold off in 1996.

Profit is not necessarily incompatible with putting safety first. As Railtrack found this week, there is nothing worse for shareholder value than putting customers' lives at risk. Gerald Corbett's offer to resign shows accidents are not exactly in the interests of rail executives, leaving aside questions of personal liability and corporate manslaughter. Other privatised companies such as BAA, which operates air traffic control around its airports, and British Airways, have good safety records.

Lines of accountability are more to the point. Privatisation has resulted in a complex structure. British Rail was vertically integrated. Railtrack owns the track and 25 separate companies operate the trains. Railtrack is regulated by the Office of the Rail Regulator (ORR). The train companies operate under franchises awarded by the Shadow Strategic Rail Authority (SSRA). Relationships between the parties are governed by complex legal agreements. Overall responsibility for regulating railway safety rests with the health and safety commission and its operational arm, the health and safety executive (HSE).

New Labour decided to work with the grain of privatisation rather than to reverse it. It sought to give strategic direction to the railways with the creation of the SSRA, chaired by Sir Alistair Morton - it will cease to be a shadow and gain new powers later this year, when the transport bill becomes law. At the ORR a new regulator, Tom Winsor, is up and running. As a result of Ladbroke Grove, Railtrack has been required to set up a new non-profit-making company, Railway Safety. Its role is to carry out independent safety assessments and safety audits.

Investment is also important. Railways were starved during the process of privatisation. Since then, investment has increased and the government's 10-year transport plan in July announced a major boost. It commits a total of £60bn to the railways over the next 10 years, nearly half of it from taxpayers. There is still a catch-up job to return the network to the state of repair before privatisation began.

An inquiry by the national audit office published earlier this year concluded that the ORR has found difficulty in establishing how far Railtrack has discharged its obligations to maintain and renew the network. Within a few days the rail regulator is supposed to publish his periodic review which will set the level of charges that Railtrack makes on passenger and freight operators. So on it depends the level of investment that Railtrack will be able to sustain.

But cold calculation will not be enough to satisfy the public. John Prescott promised whatever investment it takes to make the railways safe. Automatic Train Protection (ATP), the more expensive system that ensures that even high-speed trains cannot pass red signals without stopping, has so far been rejected on a cost-benefit analysis that says it is too expensive for the number of lives it would save.

This position is almost certainly unsustainable and if, as likely, ATP is installed, public funding would surely follow.

Hatfield may have consequences for its plans for the National Air Traffic Services (Nats) and London Underground. The "public-private partnership" for air traffic may now be a privatisation too far, more trouble than the £350m it might bring in. It is not too late for the government to choose a public sector or non-profit company alternative. Nothing in the transport bill precludes this.

The Industrial Society's inquiry into paying for the Tube highlighted the HSE's concerns about safety. The partnership arrangement favoured by John Prescott faces the same pitfalls as rail privatisation, dividing the infrastructure between private companies with a public entity operating the trains. Making the case after Hatfield is going to be more difficult even if the question of ownership remains secondary to those about investment and safety standards.

Tony Grayling is a transport specialist at the Institute for Public Policy Research.

webTitle: Gamblers cleared after £3m horse doping inquiry

fields.headline: Gamblers cleared after £3m horse doping inquiry
fields.trailText: Five gamblers were acquitted yesterday after Britain's biggest horse doping inquiry collapsed.
fields.body:
Five gamblers were acquitted yesterday after Britain's biggest horse doping inquiry collapsed.

The investigation into the nobbling of two clear favourites led to one death threat and 16 arrests.

But the acquittals, ordered by the judge at Southwark crown court, south London, brought the £3m, three and-a-half year inquiry to a halt without a single conviction.

The five could not hide their relief at the judge's "no case to answer" ruling after he decided the crown had failed to prove that the men were members of a conspiracy.

Smiles, handshakes and congratulations all round greeted the decision following lengthy legal submissions by the five defending QCs.

The jury was then recalled and directed by Judge Christopher Elwen to return not guilty verdicts on Jason Moore, 30, of Essex; Raymond Butler, 52, of Cricklewood, north-west London; Adam Hodgson, 37, of Langley, Slough; John Matthews, 36, of Slough; and Glen Gill, 34, of Fareham, Hampshire.

All five pleaded not guilty to conspiracy to defraud between March 1 and April 4 1997.

The judge said: "Central to the charge of conspiracy is the idea they were in some way involved in doping horses and thereby defrauding bookmakers and others. There is no evidence that that part of the plot took place."

Whoever injected with sedatives the horses Avanti Express at Exeter and Lively Knight at Plumpton is still free having pocketed a fortune after the acetylpromazine - known as ACP - took effect and the animals lost races.

Head travelling lad Joseph Tuite, who accompanied the horse to Exeter, was not called to give evidence. Now that a court order has been lifted, it can be revealed that Mr Tuite received a death threat in February 1998. But the judge ruled the letter prejudicial and therefore inadmissible.

The judge decided that there was nothing unusual in the level of telephone contact between the defendants. And, as professional gamblers, their betting on the two race days was "not out of line with their normal stakes".

Outside court, Detective Constable Peter Kelly said: "I am not surprised by the judge's decision.

"It was always going to be a difficult case because there is no physical evidence. We know horses were doped but not who by."

Mr Hodgson said: "I've been through hell for the past three years... now I'm going to celebrate with a few glasses of brandy and champagne."


Press Association

fields.headline: The after-life
fields.standfirst:
Few former stars of the political firmament can expect the same high regard in which Donald Dewar is held

Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Among the many words uttered in eulogy for Donald Dewar in Glasgow cathedral yesterday few, if any, were indelicate enough to suggest that Scotland's first first minister in 300 years was lucky in the manner and timing of his death. Such talk is too soon for those who mourn him most.
fields.body:
Among the many words uttered in eulogy for Donald Dewar in Glasgow cathedral yesterday few, if any, were indelicate enough to suggest that Scotland's first first minister in 300 years was lucky in the manner and timing of his death. Such talk is too soon for those who mourn him most.

Yet in the longer perspective it is true. Donald Dewar was a rare politician in all the ways that people wrote and talked about last week, including many who had been abusing him only days earlier. But to die quickly - surrounded by affection - after being instrumental in bringing one's lifetime ambition to fruition is not a fate given to most of us, let alone to the restless souls of politicians.

Contrast the man they buried yesterday with his great friend, John Smith. The contrast is a cruel one. Smith, like Hugh Gaitskell to an earlier Labour generation, remains a might-have-been leader, struck down in 1994 - mercifully quickly, which is better than the long decline which beset such people as Harold Wilson.

But it happened before he had the chance to lead Labour to victory in 1997. A smaller victory than Tony Blair's perhaps, but who knows whether it would have been a smaller government.

No such ill luck for Donald. Devolution may go belly-up from now on, one way or another. It may prove a shining success, as even the Scottish Nationalists under John Swinney quietly embrace the Catalan model (lip service to independence and maximalist autonomy within the Spanish state).

Either way, Dewar's place in his country's history and affections is likely to remain secure long after the hospitals and schools named after him have crumbled. It will not be his fault.

Things do not work that way for most politicians. The mordant Enoch Powell once wrote that "all political careers end in failure." He was thinking of his hero, Joseph Chamberlain, who walked out of Gladstone's Liberal government over Irish home rule, then wrecked the Tory party too over "imperial free trade" but - like Powell himself - lived long enough to see most of his destructive genius brought to nought.

That is the general rule. Churchill said in 1940: "I did not become his majesty's chief minister in order to preside over the dissolution of the British Empire." But of course he did. It is true that not a square foot of territory was decolonised in Churchill's second term (1951-55), but India had already gone under Labour (1947) and by his death in 1965 the bankruptcy sale was almost over.

In his 10-year retirement Churchill, so his doctor later wrote, had longed to die, but couldn't. At least he resigned office just in time. Among his contemporaries Tito of Yugoslavia, Franco of Spain and Charles de Gaulle all hung on both to life and office. For each it ended in tears - tears are still being shed in Belgrade.

FDR, by way of contrast, died, exhausted, a few days before Hitler in April 1945, with victory all but assured. He is with the immortals. Jack Kennedy, a somewhat lesser figure, is too, simply by virtue of a premature martyr's death, grace and style wantonly destroyed - just like Jimmies Dean and Hendrix (but not Elvis), like John (but not Yoko). And like Princess Di.

Old age need not be a burden to the great and good. In our own time both Ted Heath, Conservative prime minister from 1970-74, and Labour's Jim Callaghan show every sign of having embraced greater serenity in old age than in office. Unlike Heath, Callaghan has rarely uttered a word of criticism against his successors. But Sir Edward, now 84, has gamely hung on in the Commons (he will surely retire next time) and seen off the woman who blighted his career. He may even be vindicated on Europe in his lifetime.

Barbara Castle, 90 this month, has stayed magnificently on the ball: a policy player. But Lady Thatcher ... oh dear. Just as it is wholly predictable that amiable John Major will enjoy his retirement, so it was equally certain the day she shed that tear as she left Downing Street in November 1990 that the years ahead would be like Norma Desmond's in Sunset Boulevard. Mr Major's political body may be floating facedown in her swimming pool (will Hague's too?) but her frantic spirit seems to find little peace.

I'm still big, she tells adoring paying audiences in Japan or America, it's the movies that got small. But events have not been kind to her in so many ways, from Pinochet to the former Soviet bloc, as Lech Walesa has just discovered the hard way - 1% of the vote in Poland. Even the credit for Thatcher's ruthless economic reforms may go to others. Poland no longer needs its shipyard hero either. Nothing is more painful than the realisation that the world has moved on. What mattered then does not matter now.

At least Lady Thatcher has Denis, a man who deserves to be a feminist icon for his loyal self-effacement. But even here her arch-rival, Michael Heseltine, has out-smarted her. Hezza too has his family. But he also has his beloved arboretum, painstakingly created at his country seat near Banbury. Trees, like Scottish parliaments, last a long time.

michael.white@theguardian.com

webTitle: Spain is split over naming abusers of women

fields.headline: Spain is split over naming abusers of women
fields.trailText: Plans by one of Spain's best known politicians to publish a blacklist of men who abuse their partners have pitted the country's centre-right government, which sees the proposal as a violation of civil liberties, against women's groups who consider it a breakthrough in their fledgling struggle against domestic violence.
fields.body:
Plans by one of Spain's best known politicians to publish a blacklist of men who abuse their partners have pitted the country's centre-right government, which sees the proposal as a violation of civil liberties, against women's groups who consider it a breakthrough in their fledgling struggle against domestic violence.

The proposal is from the regional president of southern Castille, José Bono, a veteran socialist, who says the move will deter offenders and end "the hypocrisy of those who appear to lead blameless lives while causing abject terror behind closed doors".

But a government spokesman, Pio Cabanillas, denounced it as "shameless populism and vigilante tactics".

The interior minister, Jaime Mayor Oreja, said: "It is false to present this as a miraculous solution or a magic cure. There are none in this area."

The row has served to air the issue of abuse inside the home which has only recently come to light in Spain. Traditionally women suffer in silence with virtually no form of redress.

Domestic violence has only been punishable by law since the late 1970s and many die as a result of it - 51 so far this year.

"This could be a very positive initiative that gives many women the courage they need to come forward," said a spokeswoman for the Federation of Divorced and Separated Women.

"It is very worrying that so many people should appear so concerned about the identity of abusers being publicised," said Cristina Almeida, a feminist lawyer and socialist politician.

Mr Bono says he will press ahead, regardless of the row, taking advantage of the leeway provided by Spain's largely devolved system of government. "If the list saves just one woman it will be worth it," he said.

But Pilar Davila, who runs the government institute responsible for women, said: "Printing such a list would almost certainly be illegal and unconstitutional. There are far more effective ways of dealing with this problem."

fields.headline: High-flier takes a political dive
fields.standfirst: France's top woman MP has left the cabinet to improve her chances of becoming prime minister
fields.trailText: The most powerful woman in French politics, Martine Aubry, resigned from her cabinet post yesterday to run for mayor in the northern town of Lille, a move almost certainly aimed at boosting her chances of returning to higher national office in two years' time.
fields.body:
The most powerful woman in French politics, Martine Aubry, resigned from her cabinet post yesterday to run for mayor in the northern town of Lille, a move almost certainly aimed at boosting her chances of returning to higher national office in two years' time.

The pugnacious but highly popular Ms Aubry was replaced as employment and social affairs minister by the equally ambitious justice minister, Elisabeth Guigou, who has plainly decided that her best route to the top lies at the side of the prime minister, Lionel Jospin.

Both women apparently have their hearts set on Mr Jospin's job after the general election in 2002 if - as seems inevitable - the prime minister runs against Jacques Chirac in presidential polls scheduled for the same year.

"It's a well-orchestrated departure for a well-orchestrated return," said the left-leaning daily Libération. "If fortune shines on Jospin, Aubry will come back as prime minister. If for some reason Jospin does not run, without a doubt she will be the Socialist party's standard bearer in the presidential race."

Ms Aubry, 50, has won admiration for her tenacity in battling to win parliamentary and public support for most of the flagship social and employment bills on which the Jospin government was elected.

She has presided over a fall in unemployment, ushered in a controversial new 35-hour working week, masterminded a major job creation scheme for young people and extended free welfare.

The daughter of a former European Commission president, Jacques Delors, she has an impeccable political pedigree. Her long-awaited move to the Socialist stronghold of Lille only serves to underline the continuing importance of a strong provincial power base in French politics.

More than 90% of MPs in the present French parliament hold local government posts, and more than half are mayors. Past prime ministers such as Pierre Mauroy, Alain Juppé and Raymond Barre have combined their job with running large cities, while Jacques Chirac was RPR party leader, prime minister and mayor of Paris at the same time.

Mr Jospin has tried hard to end this French tradition of combining elected offices, but will probably have to admit defeat faced with Ms Guigou's plans. The new employment minister, 54, is also running for a mayor's job in Avignon next March, but has firmly announced her intention to stay on in the cabinet if she wins.

Known as the ice maiden of French politics, the chic and unflappable Ms Guigou was a financial adviser to President François Mitterrand and junior minister for European affairs in the early 90s.

As Mr Jospin's justice minister, she launched a far-reaching reform of the French judicial system and introduced the innovative Pacs civil solidarity pact giving unmarried couples many of the same legal rights as husband and wife.

She will be replaced by Marylise Lebranchu, 53, who is considered to have performed well as junior minister for commerce and consumer affairs. Mr Jospin said he wanted to keep a woman in the judicial post to retain a "more human, more concrete" eye on judicial affairs.

The cabinet reshuffle may have been managed smoothly, but Ms Aubry's departure marks a further weakening of Mr Jospin's team.

Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the big hitter of the government's honeymoon period, resigned as finance minister last November to fight accusations of illegal accounting at his private legal practice, while Claude Allègre, Mr Jospin's original education minister, was fired last March after failing to win union support.

Mr Strauss-Kahn's replacement, Christian Sautter, lasted just five months and the former interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevènement, resigned last month over Mr Jospin's plans to offer gradual autonomy to Corsica.

Mr Jospin has tried hard to end this French tradition of combining elected offices, but will probably have to admit defeat faced with Ms Guigou's plans. The new employment minister, 54, is also running for a mayor's job in Avignon next March, but has firmly announced her intention to stay on in the cabinet if she wins. Known as the ice maiden of French politics, the chic and unflappable Ms Guigou was a financial adviser to President François Mitterrand and junior minister for European affairs in the early 90s. As Mr Jospin's justice minister, she launched a far-reaching reform of the French judicial system and introduced the innovative Pacs civil solidarity pact giving unmarried couples many of the same legal rights as husband and wife. She will be replaced by Marylise Lebranchu, 53, who is considered to have performed well as junior minister for commerce and consumer affairs. Mr Jospin said he wanted to keep a woman in the judicial post to retain a "more human, more concrete" eye on judicial affairs. The cabinet reshuffle may have been managed smoothly, but Ms Aubry's departure marks a further weakening of Mr Jospin's team. Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the big hitter of the government's honeymoon period, resigned as finance minister last November to fight accusations of illegal accounting at his private legal practice, while Claude Allègre, Mr Jospin's original education minister, was fired last March after failing to win union support. Mr Strauss-Kahn's replacement, Christian Sautter, lasted just five months and the former interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevènement, resigned last month over Mr Jospin's plans to offer gradual autonomy to Corsica.

webTitle: Debate leaves election too close to call

fields.headline: Debate leaves election too close to call
fields.standfirst: Special report: elections 2000
fields.trailText: Al Gore finally did what he needed to do in the last of the three American presidential debates with George W Bush on Tuesday. He scored a win.
fields.body:
Al Gore finally did what he needed to do in the last of the three American presidential debates with George W Bush on Tuesday. He scored a win.

It was only a narrow win, with Mr Bush once again putting in an above-expectations performance. But the battle, if not the war, clearly went to Mr Gore, setting up a neck-and-neck contest for the White House in the last three weeks before the election.

Tuesday's debate, in front of a studio audience of undecided voters in St Louis, was much more combative than the candidates' first two meetings. Both seemed to feel freer than before to highlight major contrasts between their policies, philosophies and personalities. As a result, America now faces not just a closely fought contest, but a contest between two sharply polarised approaches to government.

After being criticised for being too aggressive in the first debate, and too passive in the second, Mr Gore dug back into the populist themes and rhetoric which helped him build a lead over Mr Bush following the August convention season. The lead was subsequently clawed back by Mr Bush.

At the heart of Mr Gore's pitch was the claim that he would continue the eight Clinton-Gore years of economic prosperity, while his Republican opponent would squander it with tax cuts for the wealthy. Mr Gore's advisers said that they intend to make this the defining issue of the final phase of the campaign.

Mr Bush also took his stand on tried-and-tested messages of his own, calling Mr Gore a big spender and a big government man whose time had passed.

At times, each man seemed to be speaking more to the converted than to the undecideds. This underlines the fact that, in an election where turnout is unlikely to exceed 50%, the candidates are now mainly focused on mobilising their core supporters through television advertising in battleground states.

Instant polls among debate watchers confirmed the view among commentators that Mr Gore had bested Mr Bush. A CBS survey gave Mr Gore a five-point lead on the night, while a CNN instant poll gave him a two-point advantage.

The tightness of the contest for the White House was un derlined by four new polls in swing states. In all four - in Florida, Oregon, Pennsylvania and Washington - Mr Gore had only a one or a two-point lead over Mr Bush. A top Gore adviser said yesterday that the vice-president will now concentrate his efforts in Florida, Pennsylvania and Michigan, where he arrived last night.

"I will fight for you," Mr Gore told debate viewers more than once, painting himself as the candidate who could be trusted to deliver on education and health reform, and to safeguard retirement benefits for "hard working families".

Mr Bush, he claimed, was the candidate of big business, who would squander American economic strength by giving large tax cuts to the richest.

In a moment that will doubtless be replayed many times in Gore campaign ads, the vice-president challenged Mr Bush to deny that his plan for tax cuts favours the wealthiest 1% of Americans. "Of course it does," Mr Bush responded. "If you pay the taxes, why shouldn't you get the benefit."

In return, Mr Bush pointed to his Democrat opponent, saying: "This is a big spender." He accused Mr Gore of "proposing the largest increase in federal spending in years", and depicted himself as a fresh outsider untainted by Washington politics.

"I don't like it when the federal government tells us what to do," Mr Bush said.

One of the earliest clashes of the evening was also one of the most emblematic, with Mr Gore saying there was "strong disagreement" between the two men on health care insur ance and forcing Mr Bush on to the defensive about his record on the issue in Texas.

Under pressure, Mr Bush claimed he had "pushed through" a patients' bill of rights as Texas governor. In fact, Mr Bush first vetoed and then refused to sign legislation giving patients the right to sue their health insurance organisations - a distortion which Mr Gore called "unacceptable".

"Here we go again," Mr Gore said after Bush had pledged action against the high cost of prescription drugs for the elderly. "If you want someone who will spin a lot of words ... and then end up supporting legislation that is supported by the big drug companies, this is your man."

webTitle: Oldest cave paintings ever found light up human history

fields.headline: Oldest cave paintings ever found light up human history
fields.trailText: Italians were distinguishing themselves as artists long before the Renaissance and medieval times, it seems.
fields.body:
Italians were distinguishing themselves as artists long before the Renaissance and medieval times, it seems.

Researchers have found images painted some 35,000 years ago - almost certainly the world's oldest cave paintings and possibly man's first artistic creations - in a hill near the north-eastern Italian city of Verona.

The images, presented at a press conference in the city yesterday, were painted in red ochre on rock and represent an animal with an elongated neck (possibly a weasel), a mysterious five-legged animal and a man - thought to be a wizard - wearing a mask with horns. They were found last year on fragments of rock from the walls of the Fumane Cave in the Lessini Hills, north of Verona.

"They are probably the oldest cave paintings, although we cannot affirm that with scientific certainty," said Professor Alberto Broglio, who teaches palaeontology at the university of Ferrara and coordinated the excavation.

The paintings, which could at first have been mistaken for smudges of dirt, may not have the visual impact of the bull daubed on a cave wall at Lascaux in southern France or the deer of the Altamira Cave in Spain, but they are at least 10,000 years older.

Dr Alessandra Astes, director of the Natural History Museum in Verona, said scientists were able to date the paintings, which measure between one and two feet long, through carbon dating and archaeological stratographic techniques, because the rocks had become detached from the cave wall and were buried under later generations of debris.

The figure of the man in the horned mask and with his arms outstretched was extremely rare in early cave paintings, said Dr Astes.

"The find is of enormous scientific significance, which goes far beyond its artistic or stylistic value," she said.

"The find is of exceptional value. I have been working as an archaeologist for 30 years and I have no hesitation in saying that."

Dr Astes believes the images are almost certainly the oldest in Europe and, therefore, in the world.

"No art forms of similar antiquity have been found in Africa, which is, after all, the cradle of humanity," Dr Astes said.

For researchers, who are still excavating the Fumane Cave, the discovery is a crucial link in the history of human life on Earth as well as a first glimpse of the creative instinct that inspired Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo in a later age.

The cave contains traces of Neanderthal man and evidence of habitation by modern Homo sapiens, including sharpened flints, bones and decorations made from sea shells. There are also the remains of a prehistoric hut.

The fragments were originally covered with stalagmites which, Prof Broglio said, helped preserve the images.

"This find completes our picture of the first representatives of modern man and throws light on the debate as to whether he descended from Neanderthal man or was an immigrant from the Middle East," he said.

The find supports recent DNA evidence that modern Homo sapiens were not related to Neanderthal man, the professor said.

He added: "The traces we have found show a clean break between Neanderthal and modern man both in terms of culture and lifestyle. There is an abrupt change in the techniques of decoration and the use of flint and bone tools. Everything changes, in a radical, brutal fashion."

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Highlands
fields.trailText: Highlands
fields.body:
The Highland Bird Report for 1998 that has just been published covers the old counties of Inverness-shire, Ross-shire and Sutherland, which is an area around a million acres larger than Wales. This fascinating account has been compiled by Colin Crooke with the help of nearly 250 contributors.

In The Review Of The Year there is a monthly account of birds seen, such as 68 black-throated divers on the east coast in January, a hoopoe near Lochinver in May, and six little auks on the north coast in October. As regards rarities, perhaps the most remarkable was the record of a woodchat shrike, identified from feathers under a sparrow hawk's plucking post in Ross-shire. There was good news on the re-introduction front for sea eagles - breeding success was the best since the programme began in 1975. Red kites also had their most successful year in terms of numbers of pairs rearing broods and the total that fledged. The success with the kites was marred by three birds being found poisoned during the year.

Equally interesting is what happened to relatively common birds - several species have declined, such as corn buntings, which may well be on the verge of extinction in the area covered by the Report. Other startling and unexpected declines have befallen yellow hammers, lesser redpolls, skylarks and lapwings. And who would ever have thought that house sparrows could become "locally scarce"? The Report is available from Colin Crooke, c/o RSPB North Scotland Office, Etive House, Beechwood Park, Inverness 1V2 3BW, for £5 plus £1 post and packing.

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Jeff Goldblum, actor
fields.trailText: Jeff Goldblum, actor
fields.body:
Early on I was just so thrilled to be acting, I couldn't believe I was getting a chance to act. I was real lucky who I managed to work with, like Robert Altman. Most actors go through their whole career without working with someone of that calibre. It just sort of happened miraculously.

There were, I suppose, breakthroughs - like The Fly - but mostly it felt like stepping stones, one thing leading to another.

Now I seem to get writers saying "Well I wrote this with you in mind." I get a lot of those these days. I occasionally get some that are "too Jeff Goldblum". If I turn them down I have absolutely no idea who gets them next. Who is the B-list Jeff Goldblum?

I get to play a lot of scientists. I find those characters very interesting but I'm not really that scientific, although I did read a book by Carl Sagan recently. That's about the extent of it.

I'm adoring acting at the moment. I've got a stack of movies coming out - there's Chain Of Fools with Salma Hayek and Steve Zahn. Then I did one in Spain called One Of The Hollywood Ten, about the Hollywood blacklist. I did an all-improvised movie called Perfume, about the fashion industry in New York, which I'm kind of excited about seeing. That's with Griffin Dunne and Paul Sorvino. Now I'm up in Vancouver doing Fighting Like Cats And Dogs. Elizabeth Perkins plays my wife - we have a 10-year-old son and, unbeknownst to us, our pets are talking, dancing, fighting and whatnot.

My career seems to be following its own unique way. I can't think of another actor I'd compare myself to, career-wise. Maybe Victor Mature.

 Jeff Goldblum stars in Jurassic Park and The Lost World; the DVD box set is out now (Columbia Tristar)

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Insomnia | Rush Hour | The Sunshine Boys | Conan The Destroyer
fields.body:
Insomnia
(Eric Skjoldbjaerg, 1997)

9.40pm, FilmFour

An unusual and unsettling thriller set in the never-ending day of northern Norway - the harsh light of snow and sun creates as melancholic an effect as the darkest film noir. The film's bleak atmosphere is also down to Stellan Skarsgard, who plays one of two cops investigating the murder of a young girl in the remote town. Deprived of sleep, haunted by the past, and conscience-stricken when he accidentally shoots his partner dead, this is a riveting portrait of a man on the verge of self-destruction.

Rush Hour

(Brett Ratner, 1998)

9.30pm, Sky MovieMax

The indestructible Jackie Chan bounces back for some more martial arts mayhem. He plays a Hong Kong supercop who arrives in LA to find the kidnapped daughter of an old pal; Chris Tucker is the local detective assigned to keep him out of trouble - matching with sheer word-power Chan's acrobatic fighting skills. Amid the usual frenetic, beautifully choreographed action scenes, Ken Leung makes a worthy, high-kicking adversary, but the best of it is in the chalk-and-cheese pairing of Chan and Tucker.

The Sunshine Boys

(Herbert Ross, 1975)

1am, TCM

Neil Simon-scripted comedy about two irascible old men, once a famous vaudeville team, now being reunited for a TV special - and after all those years, they still hate each other. George Burns acts the late Walter Matthau off the screen, while the show chugs on, creaking slightly at the joints.

Conan The Destroyer

(Richard Fleischer, 1984)

3am, Bravo

Fleischer lops off the doom-laden, philosophical nonsense of the earlier Conan The Barbarian and settles into a fast lope of fantasy action, straight out of Robert E Howard's muscle-brained tales. Arnold Schwarzenegger is the wandering Cimmerian, on a quest to restore his lover to life; Grace Jones makes an impressive warrior.
